All rights reserved.\ndoi:10.1093/chinesejil/jmab022\n# Decoding China’s Perspectives on Cyber Warfare\nChaoyi Jiang*\n## Abstract\nThis article examines China’s concerns over the adequacy of existing *jus ad bellum* and *jus in bello* to address cyber warfare, particularly the rules on cyberattacks governed by the *jus in bello*, dual-use infrastructure and war-sustaining facilities, the proportionality of cyberattacks against key infrastructures and the targetability of certain categories of civilians. This article argues that China’s resistance to applying some rules of the *jus in bello* to cyberspace is in line with the “wait and see” approach of most States. But there are two distinctive objectives behind this generalized stance: one is to protect its domestic regulatory power over cyberspace from being bound by disfavoured emerging and existing law, and the other is to build up consensus for a treaty regulating uses of cyber force under the United Nations framework.\n## I. Introduction\n1. International law is a generator and a product of the changing global order. To what extent and how the rise of a new great power will influence international law largely hinges upon the interaction between the rising power and the established powers that have dominated international legal discourse for centuries. The perspectives of China and the established powers differ substantially on many issues, especially those relating to sovereign equality, non-intervention and national security. This can be exemplified by China's perspectives on many issues of cyber warfare in the normative rivalry between the United States (US)-European Union (EU) Camp and the Russia-China Camp, which are competing to influence the making of international law, as well as other countries' domestic policies.²\n2. Notably, China’s growing strength in Internet technology, military capabilities and the digital economy, especially following the 2008 global financial crisis, did not initially bolster its assertiveness in the international lawmaking procedures that seek to identify existing law or generate new law applicable to State behaviour in cyberspace. China was a low-key participant at the early stages of the UN Group of Government Experts on the Developments in the Field of Information and Telecommunications in the Context of Security (“UN GGE”). Its behaviour was found to be passive and frequently concurring with Russia’s stance. The Chinese representatives attending earlier UN GGE meetings were technical officers from the Ministry of Communication rather than diplomats from the Ministry of Foreign affairs (MOFA).⁹ But later, China proved to be willing to act more actively and assertively when it was singled out and its fundamental domestic interests were threatened by the disfavoured norms proposed by the established powers.\n4. In reaction to these Western normative attempts, China has transformed from a low-profile, passive team player under the Russian leadership to a proactive actor that had formed its own agenda. Higher-level officials from the MOFA with expertise in cyber governance started to represent China in diplomatic activities.¹⁰ The ICCIS was developed to counter-balance the diplomatic momentum generated by a series of US activities, including Clinton’s speeches on freedom in cyberspace between 2010-2012, the 2011 International Strategy for Cyberspace and the 2011 Strategy for Operating in Cyberspace. Beijing viewed these activities as attempting to militarize cyberspace and maintain the dominance of the US in cyber governance by interfering in other States’ sovereign right to regulate cyberspace.¹¹\n5. In 2011, the first edition of the ICCIS was submitted two months before the London Conference, a United Kingdom (UK)-sponsored attempt in line with those of the US and their allies. The ICCIS called on States “not to use information and communications technologies (ICTs), including networks, to carry out hostile activities or acts of aggression, pose threats to international peace and security or proliferate information weapons or related technologies”, called for “peaceful settlements of international disputes and improvements in international cooperation in the field of information security”, and emphasized “the important role of the UN in formulating international norms”.¹² An updated edition of the ICCIS with similar wording was circulated at the UNGA in 2015,¹³ possibly intended to gather wider support in the aftermath of the Snowden Disclosures that harmed the US’s credibility in its continuous diplomatic attempts.\n6. The second World Internet Conference in 2015 marked the emergence of China’s own vision of global Internet governance that advocates both respect for sovereignty in cyberspace and international cooperation to “jointly build a community of shared future in cyberspace”. Chinese President XI Jinping highlighted the problems of the current global Internet governance system, including, among other things, the inadequate existing rules governing cyberspace that hardly reflect the perspectives of the majority of countries,\n¹⁰ As noted in ibid., 6.\n¹¹ Ibid., 4-5, 7.\n¹² ICCIS, above n.3, paras.(b), (j).\n¹³ International Code of Conduct for Information Security, Annex to the Letter dated 9 January 2015 from the Permanent Representatives of China, Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, the Russia Federation, Tajikistan and Uzbekistan to the United Nations Addressed to the Secretary-General, UN Doc. One proposal explicitly called on all countries to work together to “contain the abuse of information technology, oppose cyber surveillance and cyberattacks and reject arms race in cyberspace” and “push for the formulation of international cyberspace rules accepted by all parties as well as an international convention against terrorism in cyberspace, improve the legal assistance mechanism to fight cybercrimes and jointly uphold peace and security in cyberspace”.¹⁴\n7. The vision of “Jointly Build a Community with a Shared Future in Cyberspace” was further elaborated by the Organizing Committee of the World Internet Conference in 2019. It urged countries to oppose hostile activities, acts of aggression, cyberattacks, large-scale surveillance operations, unfounded accusations of cyberattacks against other countries and attempts to politicize cybersecurity issues; prevent arms race and military conflict in cyberspace; and remain committed to resolving disputes by peaceful means.¹⁵ In 2020, the Initiative on Jointly Building a Community with a Shared Future in Cyberspace was released amid the COVID-19 pandemic that underpinned the urgency of “achieving shared development, ensuring common security, realizing joint governance, and enjoying benefits”. This document emphasized the need to “exert the roles of the UN Open-ended Working Group (OEWG) and the UN GGE, and support formulating codes, norms and principles of responsible State conduct in cyberspace that are acceptable to all parties under the UN framework”.¹⁶\n8. To assess the implications of China’s rise for the evolution of international law governing the use of force by States in cyberspace, this paper studies the normative initiatives and strategies employed by China in identifying rules of existing law and creating new law applicable to cyber warfare. In light of China’s sovereignty-centric approach to cyber governance, Part II introduces the general stance of China on the adequacy of existing *jus ad bellum* and *jus in bello* to address cyber warfare. Part III evaluates the Chinese perspectives on\n¹⁴ Remarks by H.E. Special attention is paid to legal controversies over the rules on cyberattacks regulated by LOAC, dual-use infrastructure and war-sustaining facilities, the proportionality of cyberattacks against critical infrastructures and the targetability of certain categories of civilians. Part IV examines the rationales behind China's generalized normative proposal and its vague refusal to confirm the applicability of some rules of the jus ad bellum and the jus in bello, while having recognized the general applicability of these two regimes to cyberspace. The last part concludes with a tentative assessment of the nature and the degree of China's normative influence over international lawmaking governing State behaviour in cyberspace and the possible momentum of China's policy in the future.\n## II. China's general stance on applicable law governing cyber warfare\n## II.A. China's sovereignty-centric approach to cyber governance\n9. On 1 March 2017, the MOFA and the Cyberspace Administration jointly issued the first international cyber policy paper of China—the International Strategy of Cooperation on Cyberspace (ISCC)—to comprehensively introduce and explain Beijing's policy and position on issues of cyber-related international affairs.¹⁷ At his daily press briefing following the release, the UN Secretary-General Spokesman Stéphane Dujarric described the ISCC as “a very important report” and suggested that “China has a big role to play” in global cyber governance.¹⁸ The linchpin of China’s cyber diplomacy is the idea of cyber sovereignty, around which China formulates its cybersecurity policies towards three primary objectives. The first is to protect its critical information infrastructure, cyber sovereignty, national security and domestic stability from threats posed by digital power disparity among countries, cybercrimes and cyber terrorism, and external interference with China’s internal\n¹⁷ Statement by Ambassador FU Cong in the Assembly Meeting of the UN Conference on Disarmament on International Strategy of Cooperation on Cyberspace (9 March 2017) (www.china-un.ch/eng/hom/t1444602.htm); also MOFA and the Cyberspace Administration, International Strategy of Cooperation on Cyberspace (1 March 2017) (www.fmprc.gov.cn/mfa_eng/wjb_663304/zzjg_663340/jks_665232/kjlc_665236/qtwt_665250/t1442390.shtml) [hereinafter “ISCC”].\n¹⁸ Daily Press Briefing by the Office of the Spokesperson for the Secretary-General (2 March 2017) (www.un.org/press/en/2017/db170302.doc.htm).\nJiang, Decoding China's Perspectives on Cyber Warfare 263\naffairs. The second is to shape the current global Internet governance and promote the formation of a system of international legal norms in China's favour. The third objective is to convert China's increasing cyber capacity into soft power to mobilize and influence other countries' preferences.¹⁹ Chapter II lays out the three elements of China's proposed idea of cyber sovereignty—regulatory authority, non-interference and sovereign equality, and the security-oriented balanced approach.²⁰\n10. The appeal for cyber sovereignty by China and other like-minded countries takes place at a time when governments' sovereign power over cyberspace is in decline for many reasons, including but not limited to the privatization of cyberspace, the rise of non-State actors and the digital gap between the developed and developing countries. As evidenced by the first and second editions of the Tallinn Manual providing that \"a State may exercise control over cyber infrastructure and activity within its sovereign territory\",²¹ sovereignty in cyberspace is not a revisionist idea by itself. According to the International Group of Experts who drafted the Tallinn Manual 2.0, this premise, which was confirmed by the 2013 Report of the UN GGE,²² is now \"relatively well accepted by the international community\".²³ The US and its allies have held out to this idea in order to sustain the current platform governed by multi-stakeholders under their control.²⁴\n19 ISCC, above n.17, Chapter I: Opportunities and Challenges, Chapter III: Strategic Goals.\n20 Ibid., Chapter II: The Principle of Sovereignty.\n21 Michael Schmitt (general ed.), Tallinn Manual on the International Law Applicable to Cyber Warfare (2013), Rule 1 [hereinafter \"Tallinn Manual\"]; also Michael Schmitt (general ed.) &amp; Liis Vihul (managing ed.), Tallinn Manual 2.0 on The International Law Applicable to Cyber Operations (2017), Rule 1 [hereinafter \"Tallinn Manual 2.0\"].\n22 Report of the UN Group of Governmental Experts on Developments in the Field of Information and Telecommunications in the Context of International Security, UN Doc. It is noteworthy that, among all the technical communities developing the \"law\" of the Internet and managing the global distribution of Internet resources in terms of naming and addresses,²⁵ the ISCC exclusively named the Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers (ICANN) and urged the international community to \"make [ICANN] a truly independent international institution, increase its representations and ensure greater openness and transparency in its decision-making and operation\".²⁶ ICANN has been a highly politicalized organization. It is a Californian corporation created by a 1998 Memorandum of Understanding with the US Department of Commerce to transfer the power to manage and oversee the domain name system (DNS) coordination from the US government to the global community. This agreement was supposed to terminate on 30 September 2000, while subject to further amendments.²⁷ The US government did not end its supervision until October 2016,²⁸ mainly in response to the calling of major Internet technical organizations for freeing ICANN from unilateral oversight of the US as a backlash from the Snowden Disclosures.²⁹ Yet, it is early to tell whether the globalization of ICANN can be genuinely realized, given that most of its key infrastructures remain in the US territory. The deprivation of the top domain of Iraq, \".iq\", by ICANN in the Iraq war under the undue influence of the US government,³⁰ the Snowden Disclosures, and the \"Vault 7\" documents released by WikiLeaks³¹ have demonstrated the capacity and motivation of the US to abuse its dominant position in global Internet governance under the current multi-stakeholder model.\n25 See generally Milton Mueller, Chapter 25: Communications and The Internet, in: Jacob Katz Cogan, Ian Hurd &amp; Ian Johnstone (eds.), The Oxford Handbook of International Organizations (2017), 539-542.\n26 ISCC, above n.17, Chapter IV: Plan of Action.\n27 Memorandum of Understanding Between The US Department of Commerce and ICANN (25 November 1998) (www.icann.org/resources/unthemed-pages/icannmou-1998-11-25-en).\n28 Dave Lee, Has the US Just Given Away the Internet?, BBC News (1 October 2016) (www.bbc.com/news/technology-37527719).\n29 Montevideo Statement on the Future of Internet Cooperation (10 October 2013) (www.icann.org/news/announcement-2013-10-07-en).\n30 See LIANG Yabin, Cyberspace is the New Battlefield for Game of States in the Big Data Era, Study Times (20 October 2014) (http://theory.people.com.cn/n/2014/1020/c40531-25866183.html).\n31 See, e.g., Wikileaks Exposes CIA Interference in French Presidential Elections, The European Union Times (16 February 2017) (www.eutimes.net/2017/02/wikileaks-exposes-cia-interference-in-french-presidential-elections/).\nJiang, Decoding China's Perspectives on Cyber Warfare 265\n12. The label “multi-stakeholder” was only applied to ICANN in the wake of the battles over Internet governance initiated by national governments, which are treated as “stakeholders” on an equal footing with private corporates and members of civil society, during and after the World Summit on the Information Society, as political rhetoric to mobilize non-State actors to help resist governmental interference into Internet governance and to simultaneously make the established self-governance model more palatable to States and the UN system.³² ICANN is a global Internet governance organization possessing monopoly power over the DNS, but it is only subject to the sole jurisdiction of the US under the California Nonprofit Public Benefit Corporation Law.³³ Due to the anticipated objection of the US, to put ICANN under the oversight of the international community of sovereign States³⁴ proves difficult to attain. And an equivalent alternative to ICANN would be not only costly but also highly disruptive for Internet users.³⁵\n13. Aside from open participation, ICANN is not subject to any classic form of internal accountability that commonly exists in private corporations and nonprofit organizations, such as direct accountability mechanisms based on membership or shareholders in the Regional Internet Registries and the open, bottom-up, consensus-based standardization process of the Internet Engineering Task Force.³⁶ Although ICANN self-identifies as championing the bottom-up, consensus-driven, multi-stakeholder model of governance, its policy-making processes manifest a top-down hierarchy, in which issues raised from the grassroots level end up as policy recommendations to be voted at the Board of Directors.³⁷ The Board has “near-absolute” power over the bylaws governing the entirety of processes and can “untrammeled[ly]” decide whether to accept these recommendations in the absence of any binding forms of appeal or review. The critical details and implementations of these contracts are negotiated bilaterally between ICANN and the registrars/registries, largely beyond the influence of general policies developed in the bottom-up representative processes.⁴⁰ To summarize, ICANN seems to employ open participation as a substitute for other missing and more effective accountability mechanisms.⁴¹\n14. In the ISCC, China advocates shifting from the present multi-stakeholder model of global Internet governance to a multilateral State-centric model. In the latter model, a wide range of actors are encouraged to make their respective contributions based on their capacity in the multilateral decision-making processes led by governments, particularly regarding public policies and security.⁴² China favours the UN as the principal forum to coordinate positions of various parties and build international consensus, while other international mechanisms and platforms are called on to complement based on their comparative advantage.⁴³ The establishment of “multilateral, democratic, and transparent international Internet government systems” is listed as a major goal in the Thirteenth Five-Year-Plan for China’s economic and social development from 2016 to 2020.⁴⁴\n## II.B. International normative discourses\n15. The fundamentally divergent approaches to global Internet governance have driven China and the US to contrasting views on the adequacy of existing international law to address cybersecurity issues. China’s position on the adequacy of existing international law had not crystalized until the 2013 UN GGE meeting. Since then, China has accepted, in principle, the general applicability of relevant international law to cyberspace.⁴⁶ Despite this, China has maintained that international lawmaking is demanded to address the issues that are not clearly dealt with by existing *jus ad bellum* and *jus in bello*, as parallel paths to further study the applicability of these two regimes’ established rules to cyber warfare from the perspectives of “maintaining international security, strategic mutual trust and preventing cyber conflicts”.⁴⁷\n17. Although the 2017 ISCC is not written in legal language, it calls for “formulating universally accepted international rules and norms of state behaviour in cyberspace within the framework of the UN” towards the ultimate goal of a “rule-based” global governance system in cyberspace.⁴⁸ Rather than using the word “codifying”, China opted for “formulating” and emphasized the universal acceptance of rules by countries. This wording reveals China’s reluctance to recognize the applicability of some *already existing* rules of international law to cyberspace, mainly because of the under-representation of developing countries in global cyber governance. In its efforts to achieve these objectives, Beijing has been increasingly active in various multilateral lawmaking forums, particularly major UN platforms such as the UNGA, UN GGE, the UN Expert Group on Combating Cybercrime and International Telecommunication Union. For example, along with the promotion of the concepts of cyber sovereignty and “Jointly Build a Community with a Shared Future in Cyberspace” at the World Internet Conference, a State-run annual international forum focusing on the development, use and governance of the Internet, underlying elements of these concepts have also been advocated in China’s Position Paper at the UNGA since 2014 to maintain the momentum and build consensus. These elements include: (1) peaceful use of cyberspace for economic and social development; (2) objection to cyber war and arms race; (3) the development of an international code of conduct for cyberspace under the UN framework that is acceptable to all, such as the two versions of the ICCIS; (4) strengthened international cooperation to combat cybercrimes such as cyber terrorism; and (5) objection to any country’s attempt to overstretch the concept of national security to restrict ICT development and cooperation among other countries or to interfere in other countries’ internal affairs.⁵⁰\n19. These comprehensive and issue-specific normative initiatives unfold the usage of issue linkage under China's overall scheme of the legal framework governing cyberspace, under which the issues of the development and use of the Internet, cyber and data security, cybercrimes, cyber governance and cyber warfare that transcend different fields of international law are simultaneously placed on the agenda of international lawmaking to keep this bundle of issues at the frontline.\n20. In light of the digital divide between the developed and developing countries and the inequitable order of the existing international legal system, China has been aligning normative efforts at regional and South-South forums such as the BRICS, Shanghai Cooperation Organization (SCO), the Asian-African Legal Consultative Organization (AALCO), the ASEAN Regional Forum, China-Arab States Cooperation Forum, Forum of China and the Community of Latin American and Caribbean States in support of lawmaking activities at the UN.⁵³ The progress China has made in enhancing agenda-shaping and coalition-building capacities can be exemplified by the agenda item of \"International Law in Cyberspace\" proposed by China for the 53rd Annual Session of the AALCO⁵⁴ and the data security cooperation initiative signed between the Arab League and China.⁵⁵\n21. Meanwhile, bilateral normative discourses between China and other major powers are ongoing, aiming to figure out common interests and build up consensus for future international lawmaking. In the context of cyber warfare, the US position is that existing LOAC, including its principles of distinction, necessity, and proportionality, applies in cyberspace.59 By contrast, China, Russia, and other SCO members have not agreed to the US stance and played a rival role. In the 2013 Report of the UN GGE, China and Russia managed to exclude any reference to the applicability of international humanitarian law principles in cyberspace, despite the controversial affirmation of the applicability of \"international law\" and the UN Charter.60 The 2015 UN GGE Report explicitly \"notes\" the possible applicability of \"the established international legal principles, including, where applicable, the principles of humanity, necessity, proportionality and distinction\", while cautiously avoiding making any reference to international humanitarian law.61 The wording of this text fails to clarify whether the UN GGE reached a consensus on the applicability of these LOAC principles to cyber activities or merely noted their existence. Moreover, although the 2015 UN GGE Report mentions the prohibition on the threat or use of force against any State's territorial integrity or political independence,62 it does not refer to the right to self-defence against cyberattacks amounting to use of force as an exception to such general prohibition. The ISCC pronounces China's consistent opposition to certain countries' \"Cold War Mentality\" in characterizing international relations in cyberspace as a \"zero-sum game\" and abusing the predominant position in global Internet governance to secure advantages by militarization and deterrence build-up in cyberspace.^[67]^ By calling the international community to adhere to the purposes and principles of the UN Charter, particularly non-use of force and peaceful settlement of disputes, the ISCC articulates the idea of upholding peace through international cooperation and safeguarding a country's own security that underpins \"common security\" of the international community of States \"on the basis of full respect for other countries' security\".^[68]^ Specifically, the ISCC proposes that \"all countries must oppose ICT-backed acts of hostility and aggression, prevent arms race and conflicts in cyberspace and settle disputes through peaceful means\"; China plans to work with other countries to \"curb the abuse of information technology and prevent arms race\n^[63]^ Ibid., para.28(c).\n^[64]^ As noted in: John Markoff and Andrew E. While the ISCC discourages militarization of cyberspace, China plans to enhance its “defense capability in cyberspace” and “expedite the development of a cyber force” with the aim to “prevent a major cyber crisis, safeguard cyberspace security and maintain national security and social stability”.69\n25. At the UN GGE’s fifth session in 2017, the 25 participating States could not reach a consensus, particularly over the right to self-defence and the applicability of international humanitarian law to cyber conflicts. It was reported that the US sought “clear and direct statements on how international law applies to States’ use of ICTs”, including international humanitarian law, the right to self-defence, the law of State responsibility, and countermeasures. Cuba, backed by Russia and China which similarly opposed such an explicit affirmation, argued that following the manuscript of the US would militarize cyberspace and “legitimize unilateral punitive force actions” by “States claiming to be victims of illicit uses of ICTs”. Consequently, this session concluded without issuing a consensus report.70\n26. In December 2018, the First Committee of the UNGA adopted two resolutions to continue the international discussions of norms on responsible State behaviour in cyberspace by establishing two parallel working processes: one is a new GGE sponsored mainly by the US,71 and the other is the OEWG proposed by Russia that allows all interested Member States to participate in further studying the existing rules, norms and principles of responsible behaviour identified by the previous UN GGE reports. The OEWG is also mandated, “if necessary, to introduce changes to them or elaborate additional rules of behaviour”.72 As mentioned previously, China endorsed both the OEWG and the UN GGE in the Initiative on Jointly Building a Community With a Shared Future in Cyberspace released in 2020. Notably, the resolution establishing the OEWG introduces a new issue, namely, “the right and duty of States to combat, within their constitutional prerogatives,\n69 Ibid.\n70 See, e.g., Elaine Korzak, UN GGE on Cybersecurity: The End of an Era?, The Diplomat (31 July 2017) (https://thediplomat.com/2017/07/un-gge-on-cybersecurity-have-china-and-russia-just-made-cyberspace-less-safe/).\n71 UNGA, Advancing Responsible State Behaviour in Cyberspace in the Context of International Security, UN Doc. In May 2021, the 2019-2020 UN GGE completed its mission by adopting a consensus final report to be subsequently endorsed by the UNGA. China is among the 25 countries from which UN GGE experts were appointed. The final report explicitly notes the applicability of international humanitarian law “only in situations of armed conflict” and recalls “the established international legal principles including, where applicable, the principles of humanity, necessity, proportionality and distinction” noted in the 2015 report. In the same paragraph, what comes alongside the reference to LOAC is the UN GGE’s recognition of “the need for further study on how and when these principles apply to the use of ICTs by States” and emphasis that “these principles by no means legitimizes or encourages conflict”.76 Simultaneously, the report provides that in their use of ICTs, States must not intervene directly or indirectly in the internal affairs of another State and shall refrain from the threat or use of force against the territorial integrity or political independence of any State or in any other manner inconsistent with the purposes of the UN.77 The text of the final UN GGE report seems to have adopted the prudent approach of the OEWG. No. A/RES/36/103 (9 December 1981), Annex para.(j).\n75 As noted in: Alex Grigsby, The United Nations Doubles Its Workload on Cyber Norms, and Not Everyone Is Pleased, Council on Foreign Relations (15 November 2018) (www.cfr.org/blog/united-nations-doubles-its-workload-cyber-norms-and-not-everyone-pleased).\n76 Report of the Group of Governmental Experts on Advancing Responsible State Behaviour in Cyberspace in the Context of International Security, Advance Copy (28 May 2021) (https://front.un-arm.org/wp-content/uploads/2021/06/final-report-2019-2021-gge-1-advance-copy.pdf), para.71(f).\n77 Ibid., paras.71(c), (d).\nChinese JIL (2021)\naccepted the applicability of LOAC to cyberspace during an armed conflict while leaving controversial issues of how specific LOAC rules apply to the use of ICTs for further discussions, such as whether cyber-only exchanges can trigger an armed conflict, the scope of cyberattacks regulated by LOAC, the targetability of certain objects in the ICT context, etc.\n## II.C. Possible explanations for China’s opposition\n28. China’s stance on the applicability of LOAC to cyberspace is still evolving with the dynamic international environment, partly explaining why Beijing has refrained from specifying rationales for its resistance to some LOAC rules and how they govern ICT-related activities. Although limited in number, several statements made by Chinese officials on international occasions shed light on this question.\n29. At the 2013 Seoul Conference on Cyberspace, HUANG Huikang, then Legal Adviser of the MOFA, underlined the overemphasis on “making exceptions for cyber warfare or self-defence, while the non-use of force principle has been marginalized” and “the risk of sliding towards the militarization of cyberspace”.78 At the 6th US-China Internet Industry Forum, the Chinese delegation further pointed to the numerous “ambiguities and gaps in existing international law” regarding methods and means of cyber warfare, arguing for the incompetence of existing norms to address new sophisticated problems stemming from ICT development.79\n30. At the 7th US-China Internet Industry Forum in 2015, MA Xinmin, then Deputy Director-General of the Department of Treaty and Law of the MOFA, acknowledged that in principle, existing international law, including “the purposes and principles of the [UN] Charter, such as *jus ad bellum* rule of non-use of force except in self-defence or under UN Security Council’s (SC) authorization [...] and international humanitarian law among others shall be directly applicable to cyberspace.”80 However, he emphasized that applying existing LOAC rules to cyber warfare should be conducted “with great caution”, because of the lack of State practice on cyber warfare\n78 MOFA, Working Together to Build a Harmonious and Progressive International Cyberspace Order, Remarks by Dr HUANG Huikang at the Seoul Conference on Cyberspace (17 October 2013), (www.fmprc.gov.cn/ce/cgmb/chn/wjbxw/P020131021538048406901.doc).\n79 Statement by the Chinese Delegation at the 6th US-China Internet Industrial Forum, 2013 Chinese YIL, 666-67.\n80 MA, above n.46.\nJiang, Decoding China's Perspectives on Cyber Warfare 275\nand the peculiarities of cyberspace, including many legal and technical issues, e.g., identification, tracing and establishment of State responsibility, that are yet to be solved for the application of LOAC to cyberspace.⁸¹ MA also warned of the threats of “aggravating cyberspace militarization and arms race” and the corresponding “pushing for the application of laws of war in that scenario”. He argued that the viewpoints of some States and scholars reflected in the Tallinn Manual illustrate the “military paradigm” of “response to cyberattacks that disregards the principle of non-use of force in international law but over-emphasizes such exceptions as the right to self-defence”, which “clearly does not conform to the international reality and actual needs”.⁸²\n31. In a subsequent paper, MA elaborated that the prevailing challenges States need to address are threats to cybersecurity in times of peace, most of which either are launched by non-State actors and fall under the scope of domestic law, or do not qualify as “use of force” or “armed attacks” governed by international law that apply in times of war but constitute international wrongful acts regulated by the law on State responsibility. In the latter situations, the victim State should first resort to peaceful means such as legal countermeasures or UNSC sanctions, rather than use of force. Accordingly, MA called for both further scrutiny of the applicability of existing rules of the jus ad bellum or the jus in bello to cyberspace and international lawmaking designated for the issues not addressed by these two regimes.⁸³\n32. Quasi-authoritative Chinese sources similarly argue that some Western countries attempt to militarize the Internet through insisting on applying existing rules of the jus ad bellum and the jus in bello to cyberspace.⁸⁴ The Liberation Army Daily straightforwardly criticizes the US for utilizing the Tallinn Manual project to “find legal basis for its cyber warfare policies and military customs”, to maintain the dominant control of the West in cyberspace.⁸⁵\n⁸¹ Ibid., para.24.\n⁸² Ibid., paras.20, 23.\n⁸³ MA, above n.47.\n⁸⁴ See, e.g., Zhong Sheng, The United States Bears Primary Responsibility for Halting Cyber War, People’s Daily (7 February 2013) (http://cpc.people.com.cn/pinglun/n/2013/0207/c78779-20456593.html).\n⁸⁵ LI Ying, The NATO to Find Legal Basis for Manipulation of Cyberspace, Liberation Army Daily (24 October 2014) (www.chinanews.com/mil/2014/10-24/6712323.shtml).\nChinese JIL (2021)\n33. China's concern over the significant power disparity in Internet technology and cyber infrastructure between it and developed countries partly explains its long-term resistance to applying existing *jus ad bellum* and *jus in bello* to cyber warfare prior to the adoption of the final UN GGE report. For example, the following description frequently appeared on Chinese mainstream media: \"The global Internet is built upon 13 [Internet Protocol version (IPv) 4] root servers, 10 of which, including the only key root server, are located in the US. Theoretically, this gives the US the ultimate power to destroy the entire Internet infrastructure of any country.\"⁸⁶ The deprivation of Iraq's top domain by ICANN during the Iraq war is another frequently cited supporting example.⁸⁷ To tackle the issue, China's Ministry of Industry and Information Technology recently approved establishing a DNS root server and a corresponding operating organization by the China Academy of Information and Communications Technology, along with a plan to upgrade the network infrastructure for the IPv6-based network and encourage large-scale adoption of the IPv6 network.⁸⁸\n34. The mainstream view of Chinese scholars on the Tallinn Manual produced under the auspices of NATO is that: By its essence, the Tallinn Manual is not a re-statement or clarification of existing international law but involves the making of new rules on cyber warfare that reflects the distinctive practice and vested interests of the NATO members.⁸⁹ Chinese scholars also highlighted the geographical limitation in the member selection of the Tallinn\n⁸⁶ See, e.g., LI Yi, Chinese Internet, Please Keep the “Root”, Beijing Daily (24 January 2014) (http://news.sina.com.cn/pl/2014-01-22/015929310615.shtml).\n⁸⁷ LIANG, above n.30.\n⁸⁸ Xinhua, China Greenlights Establishment of Root Server, China.org.cn (8 December 2019) (http://english.www.gov.cn/statecouncil/ministries/201912/08/content_WS5dec361ec6d0bcf8c4c1882d.html); Xinhua, China Steps up Deploying IPv6-based Network, China.org.cn (3 May 2019) (www.xinhuanet.com/english/2019-05/03/c_138031821.htm).\n⁸⁹ See, e.g., DING Libai &amp; ZHU Jing, Tallinn Manual Defines and Reflects on Cyber Attack “Force”, 36 Hebei Faxue [Hebei L Sci] (2018), 84; HUANG Zhixiong, Application of International Law in Cyberspace: Establishing Rules of the Game, 38 Huanqiu Falv Pinglun [Global LR] (2016), 13; HUANG Zhixiong, International Legal Issues concerning “Cyber Warfare” and Strategies for China: Focusing on the Field of Jus ad Bellum, 37 Xiandai Faxue [Modern L Sci] (2015), 154; CHEN Qi, Cybersecurity, Cyber War and International Law: From the Perspective of Tallinn Manual, 7 Zhengzhi yu Falv [P Sci L] (2014), 153-56; XU Yijie, Watch Out for the “Tallinn Manual” Used by the NATO to Make “Rules of Cyber War”, 10 Zhongguo Dangzheng Ganbu Luntan [Chinese Cadres Tribune] (2013), 98-99.\nJiang, Decoding China's Perspectives on Cyber Warfare 277\nManual independent International Group of Experts.⁹⁰ Critiques of Chinese scholars on the Tallinn Manual concentrate on its *jus ad bellum* part, particularly section 2, “the use of force”. Specifically, many scholars consider that the Tallinn Manual’s threshold on what cyber operations constitute the use of force within the meaning of Article 2(4) of the UN Charter is too low. In their view, the majority of the selected International Group of Experts, who are supporters of Michael Schmitt’s “scale and effects” approach,⁹¹ artificially create some situations that have never taken place to prove that cyberattacks can result in analogous scale and effects of kinetic and non-kinetic forces. A direct transplantation of existing *jus ad bellum* to cyberspace arguably goes beyond the current practice of most States.⁹² Another major concern of Chinese scholars is that, rather than regulating the means and methods of cyber warfare, the sponsors of the Tallinn Manual intend to seek legal bases to initiate cyber or even kinetic wars. Accordingly, the Tallinn Manual extensively interprets a country’s right of self-defence against non-State actors and anticipatory self-defence against an imminent threat of cyber operations. They hence argue for a higher bar than the Tallinn Manual requirements for invoking the right of self-defence within the meaning of Article 51 of the UN Charter.⁹³\n35. Given the unique features of cyber operations, it can be observed that China has been hesitant about applying specific LOAC rules to the cyber context. What are the “ambiguities and gaps in existing international law” that prevent China from embracing LOAC and the Tallinn Manual at present? In the absence of any official policy, non-authoritative sources shed light on specific controversies focused on the principles of distinction and proportionality in cyberspace.⁹⁴\n⁹⁰ See, e.g., JIANG Yamin, Cyber Great Power Needs to Pay Attention to International Cybersecurity Strategies, People.com, (19 March 2015) (http://theory.people.com.cn/n/2015/0319/c386965-26716864.html).\n⁹¹ Tallinn Manual, above n.21, Rule 11.\n⁹² See, e.g., above n.89, DING &amp; ZHU, 85-86; HUANG (2016), 10-11; HUANG (2015), 150; CHEN, 154.\n⁹³ See, e.g., above n.89, HUANG (2016), 8-9; HUANG (2015), 152; CHEN, 154-55.\n⁹⁴ See, e.g., LI Bojun, Cyber War and the Applicability of the Law of Armed Conflict, 31 Faxue Pinglun [LR] (2013), 62-63; WANG Kongxiang, Legal Questions and Regulation of Civilian Participation in Cyber War, 5 Fazhi Yanjiu [Research on Rule of L] (2013), 100-09; CHEN, above n.89, 158; CAI Lihong, Challenges to the Principle of Distinction by Information Attacks and Strategies, 24 Xian Zhengzhi Xueyuan Xuebao [J Xi’an P Inst PLA] (2011), 95-96.\nChinese JIL (2021)\nFirst, the existence of an armed conflict permits the use of lethal force based solely on the status of an individual or object. Some Chinese scholars argue that cyberattacks, in light of the latest level of technology, are not controllable so as to constrain their effects within the boundaries of military objects and therefore indiscriminate in nature.95 The 2007 nation-wide denial-of-service attacks sweeping over Estonian Internet infrastructure, including the websites and systems of its Parliament, banks, ministries and media, was cited as a typical example of indiscriminate cyberattack,96 although whether there was an armed conflict and whether such activities amounted to attacks within the meaning of LOAC is disputable. Given such practical difficulties in applying the principle of “distinction” in cyberwar, some scholars suspect the application of LOAC will open a gate for illegitimate cyber and kinetic attacks leading to humanitarian disasters.97 For example, despite its title—“Duty of care during attacks on dams, dykes, and nuclear electrical generating stations”, Rule 80 of the Tallinn Manual, along with the US policy that categorizes enemy “war-sustaining” objects as lawful targets, is framed as a disguised affirmation of the legitimacy of attacks on critical, yet highly dangerous infrastructures.98 The Internet was originally designed in a way capable of being immediately transformed from war-supporting civil facilities to war-fighting objects, making the majority of its components dual-use objects. Overwhelming reliance on civilian cyber infrastructure would dramatically expand the scope of targetable objects under LOAC. Accordingly, recognizing the applicability of the LOAC rules on the threshold of armed attacks in cyberspace would be tantamount to authorizing attacks against critical dual-use infrastructures, rendering mass civilians vulnerable to the adverse impacts of not only cyberattacks but also kinetic ones.\nSecond, since the civilian aspect of dual-use cyber infrastructures is relevant only to the attack requirements for proportionality and precaution, the “proportionality” of attacks against objects highly dependent upon Internet or computer control systems is another worrying issue. One scholar quotes John\n95 Ibid., WANG, 107; LIANG, above n.30.\n96 Scheherazade Rehman, Estonia’s Lessons in Cyberwarfare, US News (14 January 2013) (www.usnews.com/opinion/blogs/world-report/2013/01/14/estonia-shows-how-to-build-a-defense-against-cyberwarfare).\n97 CAI, above n.94; CUI Wenbo, The Influence on Chinese Cyber Security Interest of Tallinn Manual, 15 Jiangnan Shehui Xueyuan Xuebao [J Jiangnan Soc U] (2013), 24.\n98 CAI, above n.94, 95; ibid., CUI.\nJiang, Decoding China's Perspectives on Cyber Warfare 279\nHamre, former US Deputy Defense Secretary, who is skeptical about the feasibility of using cyber operations to achieve the designated military objectives, to demonstrate the unexpected collateral damages caused by cyberattacks.⁹⁹ This scholar also considers the current rule of the proportionality of attacks, which factors “the incidental loss of civilian life, injury to civilians, damages to civilian objects, or a combination thereof” into assessing whether such collateral damages would be excessive in relation to “the concrete and direct military advantage anticipated”,¹⁰⁰ as inadequate protection of civilian interests and suggests adding “knock-on effects” into consideration.¹⁰¹\nThird, the distinction between civilian noncombatants and civilians who directly participate in hostilities used to be not an appealing question for Chinese scholars, not only because the Chinese military does not have a tradition of employing civilian contractors, but also because China has not sent its troops to the battlefield for more than thirty years. To reduce costs and obtain technical expertise, the increasing usage of civilians to operate cyberattacks, maintain information weapons, or support cyber combat operations by States has further eroded the distinction between combatants and civilians.¹⁰² It is reasonable for the Chinese military, government and some State-owned-enterprise to recruit civilians for activities related to cyber warfare. Although the law that a civilian who directly participates in hostilities or who adopts a continuous combat function may be lawfully attacked is not in dispute, the targetability of a civilian who assists with cyber operations depends on the answers to two questions: which people are targetable and when they may be targeted. Some Chinese scholars argue that, due to the technical predicament of identity verification and attribution, the applicable LOAC rules fail to provide certainty and predictability for the determination of individual status.¹⁰³\nFourth, another issue closely related to China’s opposition to applying some LOAC rules to cyberspace, namely, what acts may constitute a resort to\n⁹⁹ Ibid., CAI, 96, quoting from Is it Real? It is a separate question under the jus in bello, without prejudice to the question of “use of force” within the meaning of Article 2(4) of the UN Charter. Annex 1 to this Agreement defines “information war” as:\nconfrontation between two or more states in the information space aimed at damaging information systems, processes and resources, critical and other structures, undermining political, economic and social systems, mass psychologic brainwashing to destabilize society and state, as well as to force the state to taking decisions in the interest of an opposing party[.].¹⁰⁴\nAlthough it remains unsettled whether and when an armed conflict, international or non-international, can commence based on a single cyber exchange, the SCO Agreement’s definition of war clearly expands the traditional meaning of armed conflict caused by conventional force under LOAC. Assuming that the term “war” in Annex 1 is not utilized as rhetoric, but rather as the reference of “armed conflict” within the meaning of LOAC, we may tentatively argue that the SCO members consider the existing LOAC’s scope of regulation as underinclusive because it fails to include the cyber actions that can generate political, economic, social and even psychological consequences into the realm of LOAC.\n## III. Examining China’s perspectives on specific rules of LOAC\n36. This part examines the legal or practical grounds supporting China’s views on the four mentioned issues of LOAC. In doing so, this part presents the general contour of various opinions on specific topics, encompassing State practice, positions of the International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC), and applicable Tallinn rules. Relevant treaty provisions and judgments of international judicial bodies will be referred to, if available.\n¹⁰⁴ Annex 1 to the Agreement between the Governments of the Member States of the Shanghai Cooperation Organization on Cooperation in the Field of International Information Security (16 June 2009), List of Basic Terms in the Field of International Information Security (http://cn.io.gov.mo/Legis/International/record/1280.aspx) (Chinese only) and (https://ccdcoe.org/uploads/2018/10/SCO-090616-IISAgreement.pdf) (non-official English translation).\nJiang, Decoding China's Perspectives on Cyber Warfare 281\n## III.A. Cyberattacks regulated by LOAC\n37. Common Article 2 to the Geneva Conventions of 1949 defines an international armed conflict as any “declared war or any other armed conflict which may arise two or more States”, regardless of whether any of them recognizes the state of war. In *Tadić*, the International Criminal Tribunal for the Former Yugoslavia found “an armed conflict exists whenever there is a resort to armed force between States or protracted armed violence between governmental authorities and organized armed groups or between such groups within a State.”¹⁰⁵ Undoubtedly, cyberattacks accompanying any kinetic use of force fall under the sphere of LOAC. As with cyber warfare, the pertinent question is whether a single cyber exchange in the absence of any conventional use of force can trigger an international armed conflict by itself.\n38. The notion “resort to armed force” is not defined under LOAC and is easily confused with the usage of “use of force” under the *jus ad bellum*. Nevertheless, the different objects and purposes of these two regimes entail distinct legal tests of “force”. The *jus ad bellum* specifically regulates inter-State relations and States’ lawful use of force, seeking to maintain peaceful relations among nations by setting up strict conditions for invoking forceful measures, “when States may move beyond non-forceful measures such as diplomacy, economic sanctions, and countermeasures”.¹⁰⁶ By contrast, the *jus in bello* regulates the behaviour of parties to an armed conflict, and its object and purpose are to protect the military and civilian victims of war by prohibiting the harms caused by armed attacks during a conflict that are either unnecessary to effectively accomplish legitimate military objectives or excessive in relation to them.¹⁰⁷ The *jus in bello* does not govern whether the use of force is legitimate under the *jus ad bellum* but imposes restrictions on methods and means of warfare.\n39. Despite the absence of a treaty definition of the notion “armed forces” under LOAC, Article 49(1) of the 1977 Additional Protocol I to the Geneva\n---\n¹⁰⁵ Prosecutor v. Tadić, ICTY Appeals Chamber, Decision on the Defence Motion for Interlocutory Appeal on Jurisdiction (2 October 1995), Case No. IT-94-1-A, para.70.\n¹⁰⁶ Michael Schmitt, “Attack” as a Term of Art in International Law: The Cyber Operations Context, in: Christine Czosseck, Rain Ottis &amp; Katharina Ziolkowski (eds.), Proceedings of the 4th International Conference on Cyber Conflict (2012), 284.\n¹⁰⁷ Cordula Droege, Get off My Cloud: Cyber Warfare, International Humanitarian Law, and the Protection of Civilians, 94 IR Red Cross (2012), 545.\nChinese JIL (2021)\nConventions defines “attack” within the meaning of LOAC as “acts of violence against the adversary, whether in offence or defence”.¹⁰⁸ By concentrating on the term “violence”, Article 49(1) provides a feasible way to access cyberattacks by analogy to the physical violent effects caused by kinetic attacks. The threshold concept of “attack” is selected in light of LOAC’s object and purpose, since only acts that qualify as attacks would be subject to many of its core prohibitions and restrictions. Only qualified attacks would trigger a wide range of legal protections for the civilian population and objects under LOAC. In most cases, an unqualified act beyond the realm of LOAC would fall under the domain of domestic and international human rights law. So far, there appears to be a consensus that as long as a cyber operation attributable to a State has the equivalent effects of kinetic forces, such as death, physical injury to persons, or damages to objects, it would trigger an international armed conflict.¹⁰⁹ Similarly, Rule 30 of the Tallinn Manual suggests that the “armed force” criterion is fulfilled when a cyber operation is reasonably expected to cause injury or death to person or damage or destruction to objects.¹¹⁰ A majority of the independent experts participating in the Tallinn Manual project favour including “loss of functionality” in the definition of damages, although there are various shades of opinions among them.¹¹¹\n40. The ICRC Commentary states that the term “attack” means “combat action”, without further elaboration.¹¹² A paper written by the Head of the ICRC’s Operational Law indicates that the ICRC considers the consequence-based approach as “insufficient to capture the whole range of possible effects of cyber operations and the damage that they can cause, which will not\n108 Additional Protocol I, above n. 100, Art. 49(1).\n109 Nils Melzer, Cyberwarfare and International Law, UN Institute for Disarmament Research Publications (2011), 24 (https://unidir.org/files/publications/pdfs/cyberwarfare-and-international-law-382.pdf); Michael Schmitt, Classification of Cyber Conflict, 17 JCSL (2012), 251, n.25; Heather Harrison Dinniss, Cyber Warfare and the Laws of War (2012), 131; Droege, above n.107, 546; Knut Dörmann, Applicability of the Additional Protocols to Computer Network Attacks, ICRC Resource Centre (19 November 2004), 3 (www.icrc.org/en/doc/resources/documents/misc/68lg92.htm).\n110 Tallinn Manual, above n.21, Rule 30, 106.\n111 Ibid., 108-09.\n112 Yves Sandoz, Christophe Swinarski &amp; Bruno Zimmermann (eds.), Commentary on the Additional Protocols of 8 June 1977 to the Geneva Conventions of 12 August 1949 (1987), para.1880.\nJiang, Decoding China's Perspectives on Cyber Warfare 283\nnecessarily resemble the physical effects of traditional weapons\".¹¹³ Given adequate consideration to the object and purpose of LOAC and the concerns of a gap in protection, especially the protection of civilians from the effects of war, that paper seems to endorse the \"loss of functionality\" approach adopted by the majority view of the Tallinn Manual. Based on this approach, whether a cyber operation amounts to an attack depends on whether it causes the target to lose function, even if the target is not physically damaged.¹¹⁴\n41. States may support the dysfunction approach since cyber operations would be more frequently resorted, not to physically destroy or damage objects, which can be accomplished by using kinetic force, but rather to incapacitate or disrupt the normal functioning of a vital military or dual-use infrastructure.¹¹⁵ For instance, an electrical grid or water supply system might be shut down, and a country's banking or stock-trading system could be manipulated, both without any physical damage. As is demonstrated by the 2007 Estonian denial-of-service attacks, for certain civilian populations, the potential hardship arising from such dysfunction could be far more extensive or severe than the physical destruction of a particular building. Such effects might not be comparable to those caused by physical violence, but they are \"precisely the kind of severe consequences from which [LOAC] seeks to protect the civilian population\".¹¹⁶\n42. According to the dysfunction approach, cyberattacks against military or dual-use infrastructure, such as paralyzing information systems, altering or deleting processes and resources, are attacks that can trigger the application of LOAC, while applying the consequence-based approach would lead to a contrary conclusion. The applicable LOAC rule maintains that cyberattacks resulting in no physical damage are lawful.¹¹⁷ The US-EU camp intends to stay with the existing rule and has codified it in the Tallinn Manual. Although international law evolves to reflect the changing values developed by the international community, most States remain silent on this issue. Whether LOAC should expand its established interpretation of attacks depends on future State practice.\n¹¹³ Droege, above n.107, 546.\n¹¹⁴ Ibid., 546-47.\n¹¹⁵ Ibid.\n¹¹⁶ Ibid., 549.\n¹¹⁷ Schmitt, above n.106, 291.\nChinese JIL (2021)\n43. Part of the SCO Agreement defines war as the “confrontation between two or more States in the information space aimed at damaging information systems, processes, and resources, critical and other structures”. Under this part of the definition, those confrontations that happen without any physical damages would not qualify as attacks and therefore be lawful under LOAC. The remaining part, namely, inter-State confrontations in cyberspace aimed at “undermining political, economic, and social systems, mass psychologic brainwashing to destabilize society and State, as well as to force the State to [take] decisions in the interest of an opposing party”, is unlikely to fall into the scope of attacks under LOAC either.\n44. On Article 49 of Additional Protocol I, the *Bothe, Partsch and Solf Commentary* underlines that attacks refer to “those aspects of military operations that most directly affect the safety of the civilian population and the integrity of civilian objects”.¹¹⁸ It would be difficult to assert that political, economic, social, or even psychological effects of cyber operations could be deemed most directly affecting the personal safety of civilians or the physical integrity of civilian objects. Dissemination of propaganda, espionage, embargoes or other non-physical means of psychological or economic warfare does not fall under the concept of attack in LOAC.¹¹⁹\n45. LOAC endeavours to regulate methods and means of war and the treatments of different groups. Under LOAC, a State wants to protect its civilian population and objects, and at the same time, be able to use lethal force against the belligerent party once an armed conflict commences. An overinclusive definition of “attack” will subject the civilian population to catastrophic consequences that would have been avoided by applying the present definition with a high threshold. Such consideration partly explains why most States remain silent in the face of cyberattacks.¹²⁰\n46. The SCO Agreement’s definition of war demonstrates the six countries’ concerns of adverse impacts by acts that do not qualify as attacks and coincides with Russia’s proposal for non-proliferation of information weapons. But, unlike biological and chemical weapons, the usage of so-called information weapons does not necessarily lead to unnecessary suffering of humans\n¹¹⁸ Michael Bothe, Karl Josef Partsch &amp; Waldemar A. Solf, New Rules for Victims of Armed Conflicts: Commentary on the Two 1977 Protocols Additional to the Geneva Conventions of 1949 (1982), 325.\n¹¹⁹ Ibid., 289.\n¹²⁰ See, e.g., Gary Brown, Why Iran didn’t admit Stuxnet was an attack, 63 Joint Force Quarterly (2011), 71.\nJiang, Decoding China's Perspectives on Cyber Warfare 285\nand might even reduce physical harm compared to the usage of conventional forces regarding the accomplishment of the same military objective. This feature of information weapons makes them not a proper subject matter for a total (or partial) ban. By their features and consequences, unqualified cyberattacks are more suitable to be regulated by regimes other than LOAC for the time being. As demonstrated by the final UN GGE report, leading SCO members, including China, Russia, and Kazakhstan, no longer dispute the applicability of LOAC to cyber operations during an armed conflict, although controversies over, for example, the qualification of single cyber exchange as attacks under the meaning of LOAC, remain unsettled. Hence, the SCO members may continue to advance the broad interpretation of “attack” to build up consensus for new norms while resisting the application of the existing LOAC rules on the threshold of armed attacks.\n## III.B. Dual-use infrastructure and war-sustaining facilities\n47. As a “cardinal principle”¹²¹ of LOAC, the principle of distinction requires that a distinction be made between military and civilian persons and objects and prohibits attacks against civilians and civilian objects in an armed conflict. Article 52(1) of Additional Protocol I defines “civilian objects” in a negative manner as “all objects which are not military objectives”.¹²² Military objectives are those “by their nature, location, purpose or use make an effective contribution to military action and whose total or partial destruction, capture or neutralization, in the circumstances ruling at the time, offers a definite military advantage”.¹²³ According to Rule 39 of the Tallinn Manual, an object cannot be civilian and military simultaneously; its status is either one or the other.¹²⁴ Therefore, the entire dual-use object becomes a military objective from the moment it is used for military action, even if its military use is only “marginal” compared to its civilian use. Such observation represents today’s prevailing view on the qualification of dual-use objects as targetable military objectives.¹²⁵\n¹²¹ Legality of the Threat or Use of Nuclear Weapons, Advisory Opinion, ICJ Reports 1996, 257, para.78.\n¹²² Additional Protocol I, above n. 100, Art. 52(1).\n¹²³ Ibid., Art. 52(2).\n¹²⁴ Tallinn Manual, above n.21, Rule 39 and its Commentary, para.1.\n¹²⁵ See Droege, above n.107, 562; Michael Schmitt, The Law of Cyber Targeting, Tallinn Paper No.7 (2015), 11.\nChinese JIL (2021)\n48. From the perspective of civilian protection, the “potentially non-lethal nature of cyberweapons”¹²⁶ draws concerns over an “expanded target list”¹²⁷ and an obscured assessment of the legality of an attack. In a world where a large part of civilian infrastructure and services are highly reliant on international cyber infrastructure, including the Internet, servers, routers, cables, satellites, and computers, the danger of loss of function, partial damage or complete destruction is evident. For example, approximately 98% of US government communications use civilian-owned and civilian-operated networks.¹²⁸ Under LOAC, belligerent parties can easily target cyber infrastructure as military objectives because mere containing, storing, or transmitting a tiny percentage of military data would render the entire infrastructure a legitimate target.\n49. Several scenarios of consequences of attacks against dual-use cyber infrastructure entail humanitarian concerns for civilian protection. The past decade witnessed the increasing use of cloud computing, the users of which are usually unaware of which server their data is stored on and whether military data is stored on the same server. Cyberspace is an artificial battlefield, where, unlike natural theatres of war, such as land or airspace, travelling military data or weapons (e.g., malware, botnet, or malicious codes) can make not only itself a legitimate target but also the transmitting infrastructure a military objective. It can be a computer system, a communication network, a server or router, a major cable, a satellite, or in the worst case, the entire Internet network system.¹²⁹\n50. The Tallinn Manual provides that “the circumstances under which the Internet in its entirety could be attacked [are] so highly unlikely as to render the possibility purely theoretical at the present time”, and that “virtually any attack against the Internet would have to be limited to certain discrete segments thereof”.¹³⁰ Nevertheless, it also acknowledges that “it may be impossible to know over which part of the network military transmissions, as distinct\n126 Jeffrey T. G. Kelsey, Hacking into International Humanitarian Law: The Principle of Distinction and Neutrality in the Age of Cyber Warfare, 106 Michigan LR (2007-2008), 1439.\n127 Eric Talbot Jensen, Unexpected Consequences from Knock-on Effects: A Different Standard from Computer Network Operations, 18 Am U ILR (2003), 1149.\n128 Eric Talbot Jensen, Cyber Warfare and Precautions against The Effects of Attacks, 88 Texas LR (2010), 1534.\n129 See, generally, Droege, above n.107, 562-65.\n130 Tallinn Manual, above n.21, Rule 39 and its Commentary, para.5.\nJiang, Decoding China's Perspectives on Cyber Warfare 287\nfrom civilian ones, will pass. In such cases, the entire network (or at least those aspects in which transmission is reasonably likely) qualifies as a military objective.”¹³¹\n51. In the physical world, the irrelevance of dual-use objects’ civilian part regarding the principle of distinction is no longer in dispute. In cyberspace, the broad interpretation might lead to extreme situations where nothing civilian remains. More importantly, being a military objective will incur not only attacks in cyberspace but also fatal kinetic attacks. As a result, the fundamental rule that civilian population and objects enjoy general protection against dangers arising from military operations becomes an empty shell, leaving such situations only subject to protection under the principles of proportionality and precaution.\n52. Almost all States and legal commentators agree that the element of “make[s] an effective contribution to military action” in Article 52(2) of Additional Protocol I includes a contribution towards “war-fighting” or “war-supporting” capabilities of the belligerent party.¹³² War-fighting objects refer to those used in combat, while war-supporting objects are what military operations rely on in some “relatively direct sense”.¹³³ In the cyber context, typical war-supporting objects are factories producing hardware or software or other kinds of information weapons,¹³⁴ all of which qualify as military objectives. Controversy on this element concentrates on the “war-sustaining” object policy of the US, which has been adopted by a few States so far.¹³⁵ The majority of Tallinn Manual independent experts refused to include war-sustaining objects into military objectives due to the remote relationship between them and military operations.¹³⁶\n53. The Commander’s Handbook on the Law of Naval Operations of the US extends the expression of Article 52(2) to “effectively contribute to the enemy’s war-fighting or war-sustaining capability”.¹³⁷ The term “war-sustaining” encompasses objects within “an economy or governmental financial system”\n¹³¹ Ibid., para.3.\n¹³² Schmitt, above n.125.\n¹³³ Ibid.\n¹³⁴ Tallinn Manual, above n.21, 131, para.16.\n¹³⁵ Schmitt, above n.125, 12.\n¹³⁶ Tallinn Manual, above n.21, 131, para.16.\n¹³⁷ Department of the Navy and Department of Homeland Security and U.S. Coast Guard, The Commander’s Handbook on the Law of Naval Operations, NWP 1-14M/MCWP 5-12.1/COMDTPUB P5800.7A (July 2007), para.8.2.\nChinese JIL (2021)\nrelied on by the enemy to fund participation in the conflict.¹³⁸ For instance, the revenue from cotton export during the US Civil War enabled the Confederate States to finance and therefore sustain its war.¹³⁹ Contemporary examples are oil industries of the terrorist groups in the Middle East, such as the Islamic State of Iraq and Al-Shams, whose funding of war relied on revenues from oil exports.¹⁴⁰ The rationale behind the war-sustaining approach in the sense of traditional warfare is that the destruction of certain economic objects that are not absolutely “indispensable to civilian survival”, yet currently protected under LOAC, would shorten a conflict and therefore reduce the potential casualty toll and generate societal changes.¹⁴¹\n54. The different effects of cyberattacks and kinetic ones might make cyberattacks against war-sustaining objects more effective in achieving the expected military goal. Using cyber operations to paralyze the infrastructure upon which a central banking system is built, or delete funds from accounts, or change account balances, or manipulate the stock market, will lead to a collapse of the enemy’s confidence. According to the applicable law, many of such cyber operations may not even qualify as attacks under LOAC. Despite the unique advantage of cyberattacks, the military advantage of cyber operations on war-sustaining objects might be indefinite and difficult to articulate.¹⁴² Critiques of war-sustaining objects within the sphere of traditional warfare can apply indiscriminately to cyberspace. There would be no limits to warfare, providing that substantially the entire economy of a country can be considered as war-sustaining.¹⁴³ Consequently, a much broader scope of military objectives that include the enemy’s research and development capabilities would devastate the humanitarian values upheld by the principle of distinction.\n55. To sum up, the Chinese scholars’ view that applying some existing rules of LOAC to cyberspace would potentially “open a gate for humanitarian\n138 Schmitt, above n.125, 12.\n139 US Naval War College, Annotated Supplement to the Commander’s Handbook on the Law of Naval Operations (1997), 400, n.11.\n140 Schmitt, above n.125, 12.\n141 See Charles J. Dunlap, The End of Innocence, Rethinking Noncombatancy in the Post-Kosovo Era, 28 Strategic R (Summer 2002), 9.\n142 US Department of Defense Office of General Counsel, An Assessment of International Legal Issues in Information Operations (May 1999), 8 (https://fas.org/irp/eprint/io-legal.pdf).\n143 Droege, above n.107, 568.\nJiang, Decoding China's Perspectives on Cyber Warfare 289\ndisasters” is reasonable, given that attacks against dual-use infrastructure are currently lawful in most cases. Unless there is a breakthrough in law, attacks against major cyber infrastructure would remain subject to the legal safeguards for civilian protection embodied in the principles of proportionality and precaution. As with Rule 80 of the Tallinn Manual, targeting highly dangerous infrastructure, such as dams, dikes, and nuclear electrical generating stations, violates the established rule enshrined in Article 56 of Additional Protocol I, which explicitly prohibits targeting listed infrastructure even if they constitute military objectives.\n56. Some may argue that, instead of denying the existing law, a government should assume its responsibility to ensure that military data or weapons do not taint civilian facilities. Unfortunately, the present level of technology and the indiscrepable relationship between civilian and military components in global cyberspace holds little promise for such complete separation.\n57. Another alternative proposal pertinent to the Chinese scholars’ argument is to expand the list of “works and installations containing dangerous forces” in Article 56 of Additional Protocol I by analogy so that critical cyber infrastructure could not be made targetable objects.¹⁴⁴ But the hurdle for adequate State support for this effort remains high. It would be difficult to convince States that the potentially nonlethal effects of attacks on cyber infrastructure could be made comparable to that of radioactive materials leak or flood.\n58. China has never embraced the “war-sustaining” approach. As demonstrated by the SCO Agreement’s definition of war, China’s perception of threats to the safety and normal functionality of its cyber infrastructure is more oriented towards cyber operations below the threshold of attacks under LOAC. In other words, a lower bar of attacks capable of triggering the application of LOAC is demanded. Meanwhile, the Chinese scholars who expressed concerns over allowing attacks against dual-use and war-sustaining objects under LOAC might want to remove these objects from LOAC’s list of legitimate military objectives. To simultaneously realize the objectives of the SCO members and the mentioned Chinese scholars would require any cyber operations falling under the SCO Agreement’s definition to only attack objects exclusively used for military purposes and dual-use objects that are neither highly dangerous nor counted as cyber infrastructure. Such handling\n¹⁴⁴ Robin Geiß &amp; Henning Lahmann, Cyber Warfare: Applying the Principle of Distinction in an Interconnected Space, 45 Israel LR (2012), 390.\nChinese JIL (2021)\nmight significantly reduce the legitimate functioning space for cyberattacks and prevent them from doing what they are best at, namely, accomplishing military advantage precisely without causing non-reversible damages of critical civilian infrastructure and having the potential to stay non-violent and reduce collateral losses. Such consequences turn out to be contrary to the humanitarian intentions of these Chinese scholars to reduce the harms suffered by victims of war.\n## III.C. Proportionality of cyberattacks against infrastructures\n59. Given that the interconnectedness of military networks and their heavy reliance on civilian cyber infrastructure has left the principle of distinction virtually empty of contents, the principle of proportionality becomes an ultimate rule for protecting civilian persons and objects. This principle prohibits attacks “which may be expected to cause incidental loss of civilian life, injury to civilians, damage to civilian objects, or a combination thereof, which would be excessive in relation to the concrete and direct military advantage anticipated”.145 In light of the harsh challenges imposed by the unique features of cyber warfare, the actual role that the principle of proportionality can play could not be overstated.\n60. Under LOAC, what can be considered as “excessive” incidental damage to civilian objects in comparison with the expected concrete and direct military advantage remains controversial. The principle of proportionality is “more easily stated than applied in practice”. As a matter of fact, findings of excessive incidental damage to civilian infrastructure are very few and far between as compared to the military advantage.146 Moreover, the proportionality assessment in LOAC is made ex-ante when expected collateral damage is weighed against the anticipated military damage.147 The practical difficulties in ascertaining the expected effects of cyber operations prevent commanders from precisely assessing the potential collateral damages to civilian objects. How to apply this principle in cyberspace hinges on the development of both legal interpretation and technology, the uncertainty of which may jeopardize\n145 Additional Protocol I, above n. 100, Art. 51(5)(b).\n146 ICTY, Final Report to the Prosecutor by the Committee Established to Review the NATO Bombing Campaign Against the Federal Republic of Yugoslavia (13 June 2000), para.19 (www.icty.org/x/file/Press/nato061300.pdf).\n147 Schmitt, above n.125, 19.\nJiang, Decoding China's Perspectives on Cyber Warfare 291\nthis principle’s ability to prevent significant collateral damages to civilian objects in cyber warfare.\n61. In the digital era, incidental damages to civilian objects will no longer be limited to physical ones but also the loss of functionality of civilian cyber infrastructure. Therefore, in order to accommodate the special needs of cyber warfare, several opinions calling for modifications of the assessment of “collateral damages to civilian objects” have emerged. For example, it is suggested that more weight should be given to temporary consequences regarding cyberattacks, for the temporary incapacity of critical systems would incur more severe consequences than mere inconvenience, such as in situations where loss of life may be caused by the inability of hospitals to communicate vital information.¹⁴⁸ But existing LOAC fails to provide any legal basis for this. The paradoxical applicable law is described as:\nwhereas the destruction of a single civilian car would amount to legally relevant, albeit rather insignificant, ‘collateral damage’, the disconnection of thousands or millions of households, companies and public services from the Internet or other communication services, or the severance of online financial transactions for a country’s entire economy and the corresponding economic and societal effects as such would not count as relevant elements to be factored into the proportionality calculus.¹⁴⁹\n62. Similarly, some scholars propose to include “knock-on effects” of cyber-attacks in the proportionality calculations when such an effect would not have occurred “but for” the attack.¹⁵⁰ “Knock-on effects” refer to those generated by the initial effects of the attack.¹⁵¹ Both the 1990-1992 Gulf War and the NATO action in the former Yugoslavia illustrate that the knock-on effects of targeting electricity grid may cause more harm to the affected civilians than the direct effect of these attacks themselves.¹⁵² Although existing law has not touched upon this issue, most scholars seem to agree that knock-on effects\n¹⁴⁸ Oona Hathaway, et al., The Law of Cyber-Attack, 100 California LR (2012), 851.\n¹⁴⁹ Geiß &amp; Lahmann, above n.144, 397.\n¹⁵⁰ Michael Schmitt, Heather Harrison Dinniss &amp; Thomas C. Wingfield, Computers and War: The Legal Battlespace, Background Paper Prepared for the Informal High-Level Expert Meeting on Current Challenges to International Humanitarian Law (25-27 June 2004), 8-9 (www.hpcresearch.org/sites/default/files/publications/schmittetal.pdf).\n¹⁵¹ Ibid., 8.\n¹⁵² Dinniss, above n.109, 205.\nChinese JIL (2021)\nshould be part of the proportionality analysis to the extent they are “reasonably foreseeable”,[153] which resonates with the term “expected” in Additional Protocol I.\n63. Commentary to Rule 51 of the Tallinn Manual includes both direct and indirect effects of attacks in the proportionality assessment.[154] The former means “the immediate, first-order consequences, unaltered by intervening events or mechanisms”, and the latter refers to “the delayed and/or displaced second-, third-, and higher-order consequences of action, created through intermediate events or mechanisms”. Without deliberately using the same term, the Tallinn Manual adopts the “knock-on effects” approach, factoring “any indirect effects that should be expected by those individuals planning, approving, or executing a cyberattack” into the proportionality evaluation.[155] Such indirect effects can be exemplified by accidents involving transportation systems or malware inserted into a military computer system spread to other civilian computer systems and thereafter disables them, where those risks are or should have been expected. Such indirect effects may result from blocking the Global Positioning Satellite data or disrupting the Global Positioning System.[156] Inconvenience, irritation, stress, or fear caused by cyber operations are explicitly excluded from collateral damages to civilian objects.[157]\n64. The Chinese scholars' view on the theoretical and practical difficulties in applying the present law on proportionality concurs with the mainstream view among international law commentators. The Tallinn Manual's rules and commentaries on this principle are early attempts to codify the prevailing treaty interpretation, contributing to an enhanced relief valve of attacks against critical cyber infrastructure. The Chinese scholars' critiques of Rule 80 of the Tallinn Manual, which permits attacks against highly dangerous infrastructure, were not made in conjunction with Rule 51, becoming an interpretation out of context. The proportionality assessment under existing law disillusions those who wish to use it to make up for the failure of rules regarding the principle of distinction in protecting civilian safety. If the applicable LOAC rules regarding the principles of distinction and proportionality remain unchanged, the principle of precaution would be the only safeguard left.\n153 Schmitt, above n.150.\n154 Tallinn Manual, above n.21, 160, para.6.\n155 Ibid.\n156 Ibid.\n157 Ibid., para.5.\nJiang, Decoding China's Perspectives on Cyber Warfare 293\n## III.D. Targetable civilians\n65. Article 51(3) of the Additional Protocol I¹⁵⁸ and Article 13(3)¹⁵⁹ of the Protocol Additional to the Geneva Conventions of 12 August 1949 and relating to the Protection of Victims of Non-International Armed Conflicts provides that, if civilians engage in conducts amounting to “direct participation in hostilities”, their protection against direct military attacks would be suspended. In cyber warfare, “for such time” as civilians directly participate in hostilities, they not only become legitimate targets of military operations but also are bound by LOAC rules governing the conduct of hostilities. Furthermore, such civilians should not be factored into the proportionality calculation. They are not considered for the principle of precaution that aims to avoid or minimize incidental harm to civilians.¹⁶⁰\n66. Civilians may be targeted for direct participation in hostilities.
