No. A/RES/36/103 (9 December 1981), Annex para.(j). 75 As noted in: Alex Grigsby, The United Nations Doubles Its Workload on Cyber Norms, and Not Everyone Is Pleased, Council on Foreign Relations (15 November 2018) (www.cfr.org/blog/united-nations-doubles-its-workload-cyber-norms-and-not-everyone-pleased). 76 Report of the Group of Governmental Experts on Advancing Responsible State Behaviour in Cyberspace in the Context of International Security, Advance Copy (28 May 2021) (https://front.un-arm.org/wp-content/uploads/2021/06/final-report-2019-2021-gge-1-advance-copy.pdf), para.71(f). 77 Ibid., paras.71(c), (d). Chinese JIL (2021) accepted the applicability of LOAC to cyberspace during an armed conflict while leaving controversial issues of how specific LOAC rules apply to the use of ICTs for further discussions, such as whether cyber-only exchanges can trigger an armed conflict, the scope of cyberattacks regulated by LOAC, the targetability of certain objects in the ICT context, etc. ## II.C. Possible explanations for China’s opposition",
        "28": "China’s stance on the applicability of LOAC to cyberspace is still evolving with the dynamic international environment, partly explaining why Beijing has refrained from specifying rationales for its resistance to some LOAC rules and how they govern ICT-related activities. Although limited in number, several statements made by Chinese officials on international occasions shed light on this question.",
        "29": "At the 2013 Seoul Conference on Cyberspace, HUANG Huikang, then Legal Adviser of the MOFA, underlined the overemphasis on “making exceptions for cyber warfare or self-defence, while the non-use of force principle has been marginalized” and “the risk of sliding towards the militarization of cyberspace”.78 At the 6th US-China Internet Industry Forum, the Chinese delegation further pointed to the numerous “ambiguities and gaps in existing international law” regarding methods and means of cyber warfare, arguing for the incompetence of existing norms to address new sophisticated problems stemming from ICT development.79",
        "30": "At the 7th US-China Internet Industry Forum in 2015, MA Xinmin, then Deputy Director-General of the Department of Treaty and Law of the MOFA, acknowledged that in principle, existing international law, including “the purposes and principles of the [UN] Charter, such as *jus ad bellum* rule of non-use of force except in self-defence or under UN Security Council’s (SC) authorization [...] and international humanitarian law among others shall be directly applicable to cyberspace.”80 However, he emphasized that applying existing LOAC rules to cyber warfare should be conducted “with great caution”, because of the lack of State practice on cyber warfare 78 MOFA, Working Together to Build a Harmonious and Progressive International Cyberspace Order, Remarks by Dr HUANG Huikang at the Seoul Conference on Cyberspace (17 October 2013), (www.fmprc.gov.cn/ce/cgmb/chn/wjbxw/P020131021538048406901.doc). 79 Statement by the Chinese Delegation at the 6th US-China Internet Industrial Forum, 2013 Chinese YIL, 666-67. 80 MA, above n.46. Jiang, Decoding China's Perspectives on Cyber Warfare 275 and the peculiarities of cyberspace, including many legal and technical issues, e.g., identification, tracing and establishment of State responsibility, that are yet to be solved for the application of LOAC to cyberspace.⁸¹ MA also warned of the threats of “aggravating cyberspace militarization and arms race” and the corresponding “pushing for the application of laws of war in that scenario”. He argued that the viewpoints of some States and scholars reflected in the Tallinn Manual illustrate the “military paradigm” of “response to cyberattacks that disregards the principle of non-use of force in international law but over-emphasizes such exceptions as the right to self-defence”, which “clearly does not conform to the international reality and actual needs”.⁸²",
        "31": "In a subsequent paper, MA elaborated that the prevailing challenges States need to address are threats to cybersecurity in times of peace, most of which either are launched by non-State actors and fall under the scope of domestic law, or do not qualify as “use of force” or “armed attacks” governed by international law that apply in times of war but constitute international wrongful acts regulated by the law on State responsibility. In the latter situations, the victim State should first resort to peaceful means such as legal countermeasures or UNSC sanctions, rather than use of force. Accordingly, MA called for both further scrutiny of the applicability of existing rules of the jus ad bellum or the jus in bello to cyberspace and international lawmaking designated for the issues not addressed by these two regimes.⁸³",
        "32": "Quasi-authoritative Chinese sources similarly argue that some Western countries attempt to militarize the Internet through insisting on applying existing rules of the jus ad bellum and the jus in bello to cyberspace.⁸⁴ The Liberation Army Daily straightforwardly criticizes the US for utilizing the Tallinn Manual project to “find legal basis for its cyber warfare policies and military customs”, to maintain the dominant control of the West in cyberspace.⁸⁵ ⁸¹ Ibid., para.24. ⁸² Ibid., paras.20, 23. ⁸³ MA, above n.47. ⁸⁴ See, e.g., Zhong Sheng, The United States Bears Primary Responsibility for Halting Cyber War, People’s Daily (7 February 2013) (http://cpc.people.com.cn/pinglun/n/2013/0207/c78779-20456593.html). ⁸⁵ LI Ying, The NATO to Find Legal Basis for Manipulation of Cyberspace, Liberation Army Daily (24 October 2014) (www.chinanews.com/mil/2014/10-24/6712323.shtml). Chinese JIL (2021)",
        "33": "China's concern over the significant power disparity in Internet technology and cyber infrastructure between it and developed countries partly explains its long-term resistance to applying existing *jus ad bellum* and *jus in bello* to cyber warfare prior to the adoption of the final UN GGE report. For example, the following description frequently appeared on Chinese mainstream media: \"The global Internet is built upon 13 [Internet Protocol version (IPv) 4] root servers, 10 of which, including the only key root server, are located in the US. Theoretically, this gives the US the ultimate power to destroy the entire Internet infrastructure of any country.\"⁸⁶ The deprivation of Iraq's top domain by ICANN during the Iraq war is another frequently cited supporting example.⁸⁷ To tackle the issue, China's Ministry of Industry and Information Technology recently approved establishing a DNS root server and a corresponding operating organization by the China Academy of Information and Communications Technology, along with a plan to upgrade the network infrastructure for the IPv6-based network and encourage large-scale adoption of the IPv6 network.⁸⁸",
        "34": "The mainstream view of Chinese scholars on the Tallinn Manual produced under the auspices of NATO is that: By its essence, the Tallinn Manual is not a re-statement or clarification of existing international law but involves the making of new rules on cyber warfare that reflects the distinctive practice and vested interests of the NATO members.⁸⁹ Chinese scholars also highlighted the geographical limitation in the member selection of the Tallinn ⁸⁶ See, e.g., LI Yi, Chinese Internet, Please Keep the “Root”, Beijing Daily (24 January 2014) (http://news.sina.com.cn/pl/2014-01-22/015929310615.shtml). ⁸⁷ LIANG, above n.30. ⁸⁸ Xinhua, China Greenlights Establishment of Root Server, China.org.cn (8 December 2019) (http://english.www.gov.cn/statecouncil/ministries/201912/08/content_WS5dec361ec6d0bcf8c4c1882d.html); Xinhua, China Steps up Deploying IPv6-based Network, China.org.cn (3 May 2019) (www.xinhuanet.com/english/2019-05/03/c_138031821.htm). ⁸⁹ See, e.g., DING Libai &amp; ZHU Jing, Tallinn Manual Defines and Reflects on Cyber Attack “Force”, 36 Hebei Faxue [Hebei L Sci] (2018), 84; HUANG Zhixiong, Application of International Law in Cyberspace: Establishing Rules of the Game, 38 Huanqiu Falv Pinglun [Global LR] (2016), 13; HUANG Zhixiong, International Legal Issues concerning “Cyber Warfare” and Strategies for China: Focusing on the Field of Jus ad Bellum, 37 Xiandai Faxue [Modern L Sci] (2015), 154; CHEN Qi, Cybersecurity, Cyber War and International Law: From the Perspective of Tallinn Manual, 7 Zhengzhi yu Falv [P Sci L] (2014), 153-56; XU Yijie, Watch Out for the “Tallinn Manual” Used by the NATO to Make “Rules of Cyber War”, 10 Zhongguo Dangzheng Ganbu Luntan [Chinese Cadres Tribune] (2013), 98-99. Jiang, Decoding China's Perspectives on Cyber Warfare 277 Manual independent International Group of Experts.⁹⁰ Critiques of Chinese scholars on the Tallinn Manual concentrate on its *jus ad bellum* part, particularly section 2, “the use of force”. Specifically, many scholars consider that the Tallinn Manual’s threshold on what cyber operations constitute the use of force within the meaning of Article 2(4) of the UN Charter is too low. In their view, the majority of the selected International Group of Experts, who are supporters of Michael Schmitt’s “scale and effects” approach,⁹¹ artificially create some situations that have never taken place to prove that cyberattacks can result in analogous scale and effects of kinetic and non-kinetic forces. A direct transplantation of existing *jus ad bellum* to cyberspace arguably goes beyond the current practice of most States.⁹² Another major concern of Chinese scholars is that, rather than regulating the means and methods of cyber warfare, the sponsors of the Tallinn Manual intend to seek legal bases to initiate cyber or even kinetic wars. Accordingly, the Tallinn Manual extensively interprets a country’s right of self-defence against non-State actors and anticipatory self-defence against an imminent threat of cyber operations. They hence argue for a higher bar than the Tallinn Manual requirements for invoking the right of self-defence within the meaning of Article 51 of the UN Charter.⁹³",
        "35": "Given the unique features of cyber operations, it can be observed that China has been hesitant about applying specific LOAC rules to the cyber context. What are the “ambiguities and gaps in existing international law” that prevent China from embracing LOAC and the Tallinn Manual at present? In the absence of any official policy, non-authoritative sources shed light on specific controversies focused on the principles of distinction and proportionality in cyberspace.⁹⁴ ⁹⁰ See, e.g., JIANG Yamin, Cyber Great Power Needs to Pay Attention to International Cybersecurity Strategies, People.com, (19 March 2015) (http://theory.people.com.cn/n/2015/0319/c386965-26716864.html). ⁹¹ Tallinn Manual, above n.21, Rule 11. ⁹² See, e.g., above n.89, DING &amp; ZHU, 85-86; HUANG (2016), 10-11; HUANG (2015), 150; CHEN, 154. ⁹³ See, e.g., above n.89, HUANG (2016), 8-9; HUANG (2015), 152; CHEN, 154-55. ⁹⁴ See, e.g., LI Bojun, Cyber War and the Applicability of the Law of Armed Conflict, 31 Faxue Pinglun [LR] (2013), 62-63; WANG Kongxiang, Legal Questions and Regulation of Civilian Participation in Cyber War, 5 Fazhi Yanjiu [Research on Rule of L] (2013), 100-09; CHEN, above n.89, 158; CAI Lihong, Challenges to the Principle of Distinction by Information Attacks and Strategies, 24 Xian Zhengzhi Xueyuan Xuebao [J Xi’an P Inst PLA] (2011), 95-96. Chinese JIL (2021) First, the existence of an armed conflict permits the use of lethal force based solely on the status of an individual or object. Some Chinese scholars argue that cyberattacks, in light of the latest level of technology, are not controllable so as to constrain their effects within the boundaries of military objects and therefore indiscriminate in nature.95 The 2007 nation-wide denial-of-service attacks sweeping over Estonian Internet infrastructure, including the websites and systems of its Parliament, banks, ministries and media, was cited as a typical example of indiscriminate cyberattack,96 although whether there was an armed conflict and whether such activities amounted to attacks within the meaning of LOAC is disputable. Given such practical difficulties in applying the principle of “distinction” in cyberwar, some scholars suspect the application of LOAC will open a gate for illegitimate cyber and kinetic attacks leading to humanitarian disasters.97 For example, despite its title—“Duty of care during attacks on dams, dykes, and nuclear electrical generating stations”, Rule 80 of the Tallinn Manual, along with the US policy that categorizes enemy “war-sustaining” objects as lawful targets, is framed as a disguised affirmation of the legitimacy of attacks on critical, yet highly dangerous infrastructures.98 The Internet was originally designed in a way capable of being immediately transformed from war-supporting civil facilities to war-fighting objects, making the majority of its components dual-use objects. Overwhelming reliance on civilian cyber infrastructure would dramatically expand the scope of targetable objects under LOAC. Accordingly, recognizing the applicability of the LOAC rules on the threshold of armed attacks in cyberspace would be tantamount to authorizing attacks against critical dual-use infrastructures, rendering mass civilians vulnerable to the adverse impacts of not only cyberattacks but also kinetic ones. Second, since the civilian aspect of dual-use cyber infrastructures is relevant only to the attack requirements for proportionality and precaution, the “proportionality” of attacks against objects highly dependent upon Internet or computer control systems is another worrying issue. One scholar quotes John 95 Ibid., WANG, 107; LIANG, above n.30. 96 Scheherazade Rehman, Estonia’s Lessons in Cyberwarfare, US News (14 January 2013) (www.usnews.com/opinion/blogs/world-report/2013/01/14/estonia-shows-how-to-build-a-defense-against-cyberwarfare). 97 CAI, above n.94; CUI Wenbo, The Influence on Chinese Cyber Security Interest of Tallinn Manual, 15 Jiangnan Shehui Xueyuan Xuebao [J Jiangnan Soc U] (2013), 24. 98 CAI, above n.94, 95; ibid., CUI. Jiang, Decoding China's Perspectives on Cyber Warfare 279 Hamre, former US Deputy Defense Secretary, who is skeptical about the feasibility of using cyber operations to achieve the designated military objectives, to demonstrate the unexpected collateral damages caused by cyberattacks.⁹⁹ This scholar also considers the current rule of the proportionality of attacks, which factors “the incidental loss of civilian life, injury to civilians, damages to civilian objects, or a combination thereof” into assessing whether such collateral damages would be excessive in relation to “the concrete and direct military advantage anticipated”,¹⁰⁰ as inadequate protection of civilian interests and suggests adding “knock-on effects” into consideration.¹⁰¹ Third, the distinction between civilian noncombatants and civilians who directly participate in hostilities used to be not an appealing question for Chinese scholars, not only because the Chinese military does not have a tradition of employing civilian contractors, but also because China has not sent its troops to the battlefield for more than thirty years. To reduce costs and obtain technical expertise, the increasing usage of civilians to operate cyberattacks, maintain information weapons, or support cyber combat operations by States has further eroded the distinction between combatants and civilians.¹⁰² It is reasonable for the Chinese military, government and some State-owned-enterprise to recruit civilians for activities related to cyber warfare. Although the law that a civilian who directly participates in hostilities or who adopts a continuous combat function may be lawfully attacked is not in dispute, the targetability of a civilian who assists with cyber operations depends on the answers to two questions: which people are targetable and when they may be targeted. Some Chinese scholars argue that, due to the technical predicament of identity verification and attribution, the applicable LOAC rules fail to provide certainty and predictability for the determination of individual status.¹⁰³ Fourth, another issue closely related to China’s opposition to applying some LOAC rules to cyberspace, namely, what acts may constitute a resort to ⁹⁹ Ibid., CAI, 96, quoting from Is it Real? Is it Hype?, Interview with John Hamre, PBS Frontline (18 February 2003) (www.pbs.org/wgbh/pages/frontline/shows/cyberwar/interviews/hamre.html). ¹⁰⁰ Protocol Additional to the Geneva Conventions of 12 August 1949, and relating to the Protection of Victims of International Armed Conflicts, 1125 UNTS 3, Art. 57(2)(a)(iii) and 57(2)(b) [hereinafter “Additional Protocol I”]. ¹⁰¹ CAI, above n.94, 96. ¹⁰² Susan Brenner, Cyber Threats: The Emerging Fault Lines of the Nation State (2009), 197. ¹⁰³ See, e.g., LI, above n.94, 62; WANG, above n.94, 103-09. Chinese JIL (2021) armed force that triggers the application of LOAC, is hinted by the Agreement between the Governments of the Member States of the Shanghai Cooperation Organization on Cooperation in the Field of International Information Security (“SCO Agreement”). It is a separate question under the jus in bello, without prejudice to the question of “use of force” within the meaning of Article 2(4) of the UN Charter. Annex 1 to this Agreement defines “information war” as: confrontation between two or more states in the information space aimed at damaging information systems, processes and resources, critical and other structures, undermining political, economic and social systems, mass psychologic brainwashing to destabilize society and state, as well as to force the state to taking decisions in the interest of an opposing party[.].¹⁰⁴ Although it remains unsettled whether and when an armed conflict, international or non-international, can commence based on a single cyber exchange, the SCO Agreement’s definition of war clearly expands the traditional meaning of armed conflict caused by conventional force under LOAC. Assuming that the term “war” in Annex 1 is not utilized as rhetoric, but rather as the reference of “armed conflict” within the meaning of LOAC, we may tentatively argue that the SCO members consider the existing LOAC’s scope of regulation as underinclusive because it fails to include the cyber actions that can generate political, economic, social and even psychological consequences into the realm of LOAC. ## III. Examining China’s perspectives on specific rules of LOAC",
        "36": "This part examines the legal or practical grounds supporting China’s views on the four mentioned issues of LOAC. In doing so, this part presents the general contour of various opinions on specific topics, encompassing State practice, positions of the International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC), and applicable Tallinn rules. Relevant treaty provisions and judgments of international judicial bodies will be referred to, if available. ¹⁰⁴ Annex 1 to the Agreement between the Governments of the Member States of the Shanghai Cooperation Organization on Cooperation in the Field of International Information Security (16 June 2009), List of Basic Terms in the Field of International Information Security (http://cn.io.gov.mo/Legis/International/record/1280.aspx) (Chinese only) and (https://ccdcoe.org/uploads/2018/10/SCO-090616-IISAgreement.pdf) (non-official English translation). Jiang, Decoding China's Perspectives on Cyber Warfare 281 ## III.A. Cyberattacks regulated by LOAC",
        "37": "Common Article 2 to the Geneva Conventions of 1949 defines an international armed conflict as any “declared war or any other armed conflict which may arise two or more States”, regardless of whether any of them recognizes the state of war. In *Tadić*, the International Criminal Tribunal for the Former Yugoslavia found “an armed conflict exists whenever there is a resort to armed force between States or protracted armed violence between governmental authorities and organized armed groups or between such groups within a State.”¹⁰⁵ Undoubtedly, cyberattacks accompanying any kinetic use of force fall under the sphere of LOAC. As with cyber warfare, the pertinent question is whether a single cyber exchange in the absence of any conventional use of force can trigger an international armed conflict by itself.",
        "38": "The notion “resort to armed force” is not defined under LOAC and is easily confused with the usage of “use of force” under the *jus ad bellum*. Nevertheless, the different objects and purposes of these two regimes entail distinct legal tests of “force”. The *jus ad bellum* specifically regulates inter-State relations and States’ lawful use of force, seeking to maintain peaceful relations among nations by setting up strict conditions for invoking forceful measures, “when States may move beyond non-forceful measures such as diplomacy, economic sanctions, and countermeasures”.¹⁰⁶ By contrast, the *jus in bello* regulates the behaviour of parties to an armed conflict, and its object and purpose are to protect the military and civilian victims of war by prohibiting the harms caused by armed attacks during a conflict that are either unnecessary to effectively accomplish legitimate military objectives or excessive in relation to them.¹⁰⁷ The *jus in bello* does not govern whether the use of force is legitimate under the *jus ad bellum* but imposes restrictions on methods and means of warfare.",
        "39": "Despite the absence of a treaty definition of the notion “armed forces” under LOAC, Article 49(1) of the 1977 Additional Protocol I to the Geneva --- ¹⁰⁵ Prosecutor v. Tadić, ICTY Appeals Chamber, Decision on the Defence Motion for Interlocutory Appeal on Jurisdiction (2 October 1995), Case No. IT-94-1-A, para.70. ¹⁰⁶ Michael Schmitt, “Attack” as a Term of Art in International Law: The Cyber Operations Context, in: Christine Czosseck, Rain Ottis &amp; Katharina Ziolkowski (eds.), Proceedings of the 4th International Conference on Cyber Conflict (2012), 284. ¹⁰⁷ Cordula Droege, Get off My Cloud: Cyber Warfare, International Humanitarian Law, and the Protection of Civilians, 94 IR Red Cross (2012), 545. Chinese JIL (2021) Conventions defines “attack” within the meaning of LOAC as “acts of violence against the adversary, whether in offence or defence”.¹⁰⁸ By concentrating on the term “violence”, Article 49(1) provides a feasible way to access cyberattacks by analogy to the physical violent effects caused by kinetic attacks. The threshold concept of “attack” is selected in light of LOAC’s object and purpose, since only acts that qualify as attacks would be subject to many of its core prohibitions and restrictions. Only qualified attacks would trigger a wide range of legal protections for the civilian population and objects under LOAC. In most cases, an unqualified act beyond the realm of LOAC would fall under the domain of domestic and international human rights law. So far, there appears to be a consensus that as long as a cyber operation attributable to a State has the equivalent effects of kinetic forces, such as death, physical injury to persons, or damages to objects, it would trigger an international armed conflict.¹⁰⁹ Similarly, Rule 30 of the Tallinn Manual suggests that the “armed force” criterion is fulfilled when a cyber operation is reasonably expected to cause injury or death to person or damage or destruction to objects.¹¹⁰ A majority of the independent experts participating in the Tallinn Manual project favour including “loss of functionality” in the definition of damages, although there are various shades of opinions among them.¹¹¹",
        "40": "The ICRC Commentary states that the term “attack” means “combat action”, without further elaboration.¹¹² A paper written by the Head of the ICRC’s Operational Law indicates that the ICRC considers the consequence-based approach as “insufficient to capture the whole range of possible effects of cyber operations and the damage that they can cause, which will not 108 Additional Protocol I, above n. 100, Art. 49(1). 109 Nils Melzer, Cyberwarfare and International Law, UN Institute for Disarmament Research Publications (2011), 24 (https://unidir.org/files/publications/pdfs/cyberwarfare-and-international-law-382.pdf); Michael Schmitt, Classification of Cyber Conflict, 17 JCSL (2012), 251, n.25; Heather Harrison Dinniss, Cyber Warfare and the Laws of War (2012), 131; Droege, above n.107, 546; Knut Dörmann, Applicability of the Additional Protocols to Computer Network Attacks, ICRC Resource Centre (19 November 2004), 3 (www.icrc.org/en/doc/resources/documents/misc/68lg92.htm). 110 Tallinn Manual, above n.21, Rule 30, 106. 111 Ibid., 108-09. 112 Yves Sandoz, Christophe Swinarski &amp; Bruno Zimmermann (eds.), Commentary on the Additional Protocols of 8 June 1977 to the Geneva Conventions of 12 August 1949 (1987), para.1880. Jiang, Decoding China's Perspectives on Cyber Warfare 283 necessarily resemble the physical effects of traditional weapons\".¹¹³ Given adequate consideration to the object and purpose of LOAC and the concerns of a gap in protection, especially the protection of civilians from the effects of war, that paper seems to endorse the \"loss of functionality\" approach adopted by the majority view of the Tallinn Manual. Based on this approach, whether a cyber operation amounts to an attack depends on whether it causes the target to lose function, even if the target is not physically damaged.¹¹⁴",
        "41": "States may support the dysfunction approach since cyber operations would be more frequently resorted, not to physically destroy or damage objects, which can be accomplished by using kinetic force, but rather to incapacitate or disrupt the normal functioning of a vital military or dual-use infrastructure.¹¹⁵ For instance, an electrical grid or water supply system might be shut down, and a country's banking or stock-trading system could be manipulated, both without any physical damage. As is demonstrated by the 2007 Estonian denial-of-service attacks, for certain civilian populations, the potential hardship arising from such dysfunction could be far more extensive or severe than the physical destruction of a particular building. Such effects might not be comparable to those caused by physical violence, but they are \"precisely the kind of severe consequences from which [LOAC] seeks to protect the civilian population\".¹¹⁶",
        "42": "According to the dysfunction approach, cyberattacks against military or dual-use infrastructure, such as paralyzing information systems, altering or deleting processes and resources, are attacks that can trigger the application of LOAC, while applying the consequence-based approach would lead to a contrary conclusion. The applicable LOAC rule maintains that cyberattacks resulting in no physical damage are lawful.¹¹⁷ The US-EU camp intends to stay with the existing rule and has codified it in the Tallinn Manual. Although international law evolves to reflect the changing values developed by the international community, most States remain silent on this issue. Whether LOAC should expand its established interpretation of attacks depends on future State practice. ¹¹³ Droege, above n.107, 546. ¹¹⁴ Ibid., 546-47. ¹¹⁵ Ibid. ¹¹⁶ Ibid., 549. ¹¹⁷ Schmitt, above n.106, 291. Chinese JIL (2021)",
        "43": "Part of the SCO Agreement defines war as the “confrontation between two or more States in the information space aimed at damaging information systems, processes, and resources, critical and other structures”. Under this part of the definition, those confrontations that happen without any physical damages would not qualify as attacks and therefore be lawful under LOAC. The remaining part, namely, inter-State confrontations in cyberspace aimed at “undermining political, economic, and social systems, mass psychologic brainwashing to destabilize society and State, as well as to force the State to [take] decisions in the interest of an opposing party”, is unlikely to fall into the scope of attacks under LOAC either.",
        "44": "On Article 49 of Additional Protocol I, the *Bothe, Partsch and Solf Commentary* underlines that attacks refer to “those aspects of military operations that most directly affect the safety of the civilian population and the integrity of civilian objects”.¹¹⁸ It would be difficult to assert that political, economic, social, or even psychological effects of cyber operations could be deemed most directly affecting the personal safety of civilians or the physical integrity of civilian objects. Dissemination of propaganda, espionage, embargoes or other non-physical means of psychological or economic warfare does not fall under the concept of attack in LOAC.¹¹⁹",
        "45": "LOAC endeavours to regulate methods and means of war and the treatments of different groups. Under LOAC, a State wants to protect its civilian population and objects, and at the same time, be able to use lethal force against the belligerent party once an armed conflict commences. An overinclusive definition of “attack” will subject the civilian population to catastrophic consequences that would have been avoided by applying the present definition with a high threshold. Such consideration partly explains why most States remain silent in the face of cyberattacks.¹²⁰",
        "46": "The SCO Agreement’s definition of war demonstrates the six countries’ concerns of adverse impacts by acts that do not qualify as attacks and coincides with Russia’s proposal for non-proliferation of information weapons. But, unlike biological and chemical weapons, the usage of so-called information weapons does not necessarily lead to unnecessary suffering of humans ¹¹⁸ Michael Bothe, Karl Josef Partsch &amp; Waldemar A. Solf, New Rules for Victims of Armed Conflicts: Commentary on the Two 1977 Protocols Additional to the Geneva Conventions of 1949 (1982), 325. ¹¹⁹ Ibid., 289. ¹²⁰ See, e.g., Gary Brown, Why Iran didn’t admit Stuxnet was an attack, 63 Joint Force Quarterly (2011), 71. Jiang, Decoding China's Perspectives on Cyber Warfare 285 and might even reduce physical harm compared to the usage of conventional forces regarding the accomplishment of the same military objective. This feature of information weapons makes them not a proper subject matter for a total (or partial) ban. By their features and consequences, unqualified cyberattacks are more suitable to be regulated by regimes other than LOAC for the time being. As demonstrated by the final UN GGE report, leading SCO members, including China, Russia, and Kazakhstan, no longer dispute the applicability of LOAC to cyber operations during an armed conflict, although controversies over, for example, the qualification of single cyber exchange as attacks under the meaning of LOAC, remain unsettled. Hence, the SCO members may continue to advance the broad interpretation of “attack” to build up consensus for new norms while resisting the application of the existing LOAC rules on the threshold of armed attacks. ## III.B. Dual-use infrastructure and war-sustaining facilities",
        "47": "As a “cardinal principle”¹²¹ of LOAC, the principle of distinction requires that a distinction be made between military and civilian persons and objects and prohibits attacks against civilians and civilian objects in an armed conflict. Article 52(1) of Additional Protocol I defines “civilian objects” in a negative manner as “all objects which are not military objectives”.¹²² Military objectives are those “by their nature, location, purpose or use make an effective contribution to military action and whose total or partial destruction, capture or neutralization, in the circumstances ruling at the time, offers a definite military advantage”.¹²³ According to Rule 39 of the Tallinn Manual, an object cannot be civilian and military simultaneously; its status is either one or the other.¹²⁴ Therefore, the entire dual-use object becomes a military objective from the moment it is used for military action, even if its military use is only “marginal” compared to its civilian use. Such observation represents today’s prevailing view on the qualification of dual-use objects as targetable military objectives.¹²⁵ ¹²¹ Legality of the Threat or Use of Nuclear Weapons, Advisory Opinion, ICJ Reports 1996, 257, para.78. ¹²² Additional Protocol I, above n. 100, Art. 52(1). ¹²³ Ibid., Art. 52(2). ¹²⁴ Tallinn Manual, above n.21, Rule 39 and its Commentary, para.1. ¹²⁵ See Droege, above n.107, 562; Michael Schmitt, The Law of Cyber Targeting, Tallinn Paper No.7 (2015), 11. Chinese JIL (2021)",
        "48": "From the perspective of civilian protection, the “potentially non-lethal nature of cyberweapons”¹²⁶ draws concerns over an “expanded target list”¹²⁷ and an obscured assessment of the legality of an attack. In a world where a large part of civilian infrastructure and services are highly reliant on international cyber infrastructure, including the Internet, servers, routers, cables, satellites, and computers, the danger of loss of function, partial damage or complete destruction is evident. For example, approximately 98% of US government communications use civilian-owned and civilian-operated networks.¹²⁸ Under LOAC, belligerent parties can easily target cyber infrastructure as military objectives because mere containing, storing, or transmitting a tiny percentage of military data would render the entire infrastructure a legitimate target.",
        "49": "Several scenarios of consequences of attacks against dual-use cyber infrastructure entail humanitarian concerns for civilian protection. The past decade witnessed the increasing use of cloud computing, the users of which are usually unaware of which server their data is stored on and whether military data is stored on the same server. Cyberspace is an artificial battlefield, where, unlike natural theatres of war, such as land or airspace, travelling military data or weapons (e.g., malware, botnet, or malicious codes) can make not only itself a legitimate target but also the transmitting infrastructure a military objective. It can be a computer system, a communication network, a server or router, a major cable, a satellite, or in the worst case, the entire Internet network system.¹²⁹",
        "50": "The Tallinn Manual provides that “the circumstances under which the Internet in its entirety could be attacked [are] so highly unlikely as to render the possibility purely theoretical at the present time”, and that “virtually any attack against the Internet would have to be limited to certain discrete segments thereof”.¹³⁰ Nevertheless, it also acknowledges that “it may be impossible to know over which part of the network military transmissions, as distinct 126 Jeffrey T. G. Kelsey, Hacking into International Humanitarian Law: The Principle of Distinction and Neutrality in the Age of Cyber Warfare, 106 Michigan LR (2007-2008), 1439. 127 Eric Talbot Jensen, Unexpected Consequences from Knock-on Effects: A Different Standard from Computer Network Operations, 18 Am U ILR (2003), 1149. 128 Eric Talbot Jensen, Cyber Warfare and Precautions against The Effects of Attacks, 88 Texas LR (2010), 1534. 129 See, generally, Droege, above n.107, 562-65. 130 Tallinn Manual, above n.21, Rule 39 and its Commentary, para.5. Jiang, Decoding China's Perspectives on Cyber Warfare 287 from civilian ones, will pass. In such cases, the entire network (or at least those aspects in which transmission is reasonably likely) qualifies as a military objective.”¹³¹",
        "51": "In the physical world, the irrelevance of dual-use objects’ civilian part regarding the principle of distinction is no longer in dispute. In cyberspace, the broad interpretation might lead to extreme situations where nothing civilian remains. More importantly, being a military objective will incur not only attacks in cyberspace but also fatal kinetic attacks. As a result, the fundamental rule that civilian population and objects enjoy general protection against dangers arising from military operations becomes an empty shell, leaving such situations only subject to protection under the principles of proportionality and precaution.",
        "52": "Almost all States and legal commentators agree that the element of “make[s] an effective contribution to military action” in Article 52(2) of Additional Protocol I includes a contribution towards “war-fighting” or “war-supporting” capabilities of the belligerent party.¹³² War-fighting objects refer to those used in combat, while war-supporting objects are what military operations rely on in some “relatively direct sense”.¹³³ In the cyber context, typical war-supporting objects are factories producing hardware or software or other kinds of information weapons,¹³⁴ all of which qualify as military objectives. Controversy on this element concentrates on the “war-sustaining” object policy of the US, which has been adopted by a few States so far.¹³⁵ The majority of Tallinn Manual independent experts refused to include war-sustaining objects into military objectives due to the remote relationship between them and military operations.¹³⁶",
        "53": "The Commander’s Handbook on the Law of Naval Operations of the US extends the expression of Article 52(2) to “effectively contribute to the enemy’s war-fighting or war-sustaining capability”.¹³⁷ The term “war-sustaining” encompasses objects within “an economy or governmental financial system” ¹³¹ Ibid., para.3. ¹³² Schmitt, above n.125. ¹³³ Ibid. ¹³⁴ Tallinn Manual, above n.21, 131, para.16. ¹³⁵ Schmitt, above n.125, 12. ¹³⁶ Tallinn Manual, above n.21, 131, para.16. ¹³⁷ Department of the Navy and Department of Homeland Security and U.S. Coast Guard, The Commander’s Handbook on the Law of Naval Operations, NWP 1-14M/MCWP 5-12.1/COMDTPUB P5800.7A (July 2007), para.8.2. Chinese JIL (2021) relied on by the enemy to fund participation in the conflict.¹³⁸ For instance, the revenue from cotton export during the US Civil War enabled the Confederate States to finance and therefore sustain its war.¹³⁹ Contemporary examples are oil industries of the terrorist groups in the Middle East, such as the Islamic State of Iraq and Al-Shams, whose funding of war relied on revenues from oil exports.¹⁴⁰ The rationale behind the war-sustaining approach in the sense of traditional warfare is that the destruction of certain economic objects that are not absolutely “indispensable to civilian survival”, yet currently protected under LOAC, would shorten a conflict and therefore reduce the potential casualty toll and generate societal changes.¹⁴¹",
        "54": "The different effects of cyberattacks and kinetic ones might make cyberattacks against war-sustaining objects more effective in achieving the expected military goal. Using cyber operations to paralyze the infrastructure upon which a central banking system is built, or delete funds from accounts, or change account balances, or manipulate the stock market, will lead to a collapse of the enemy’s confidence. According to the applicable law, many of such cyber operations may not even qualify as attacks under LOAC. Despite the unique advantage of cyberattacks, the military advantage of cyber operations on war-sustaining objects might be indefinite and difficult to articulate.¹⁴² Critiques of war-sustaining objects within the sphere of traditional warfare can apply indiscriminately to cyberspace. There would be no limits to warfare, providing that substantially the entire economy of a country can be considered as war-sustaining.¹⁴³ Consequently, a much broader scope of military objectives that include the enemy’s research and development capabilities would devastate the humanitarian values upheld by the principle of distinction.",
        "55": "To sum up, the Chinese scholars’ view that applying some existing rules of LOAC to cyberspace would potentially “open a gate for humanitarian 138 Schmitt, above n.125, 12. 139 US Naval War College, Annotated Supplement to the Commander’s Handbook on the Law of Naval Operations (1997), 400, n.11. 140 Schmitt, above n.125, 12. 141 See Charles J. Dunlap, The End of Innocence, Rethinking Noncombatancy in the Post-Kosovo Era, 28 Strategic R (Summer 2002), 9. 142 US Department of Defense Office of General Counsel, An Assessment of International Legal Issues in Information Operations (May 1999), 8 (https://fas.org/irp/eprint/io-legal.pdf). 143 Droege, above n.107, 568. Jiang, Decoding China's Perspectives on Cyber Warfare 289 disasters” is reasonable, given that attacks against dual-use infrastructure are currently lawful in most cases. Unless there is a breakthrough in law, attacks against major cyber infrastructure would remain subject to the legal safeguards for civilian protection embodied in the principles of proportionality and precaution. As with Rule 80 of the Tallinn Manual, targeting highly dangerous infrastructure, such as dams, dikes, and nuclear electrical generating stations, violates the established rule enshrined in Article 56 of Additional Protocol I, which explicitly prohibits targeting listed infrastructure even if they constitute military objectives.",
        "56": "Some may argue that, instead of denying the existing law, a government should assume its responsibility to ensure that military data or weapons do not taint civilian facilities. Unfortunately, the present level of technology and the indiscrepable relationship between civilian and military components in global cyberspace holds little promise for such complete separation.",
        "57": "Another alternative proposal pertinent to the Chinese scholars’ argument is to expand the list of “works and installations containing dangerous forces” in Article 56 of Additional Protocol I by analogy so that critical cyber infrastructure could not be made targetable objects.¹⁴⁴ But the hurdle for adequate State support for this effort remains high. It would be difficult to convince States that the potentially nonlethal effects of attacks on cyber infrastructure could be made comparable to that of radioactive materials leak or flood.",
        "58": "China has never embraced the “war-sustaining” approach. As demonstrated by the SCO Agreement’s definition of war, China’s perception of threats to the safety and normal functionality of its cyber infrastructure is more oriented towards cyber operations below the threshold of attacks under LOAC. In other words, a lower bar of attacks capable of triggering the application of LOAC is demanded. Meanwhile, the Chinese scholars who expressed concerns over allowing attacks against dual-use and war-sustaining objects under LOAC might want to remove these objects from LOAC’s list of legitimate military objectives. To simultaneously realize the objectives of the SCO members and the mentioned Chinese scholars would require any cyber operations falling under the SCO Agreement’s definition to only attack objects exclusively used for military purposes and dual-use objects that are neither highly dangerous nor counted as cyber infrastructure. Such handling ¹⁴⁴ Robin Geiß &amp; Henning Lahmann, Cyber Warfare: Applying the Principle of Distinction in an Interconnected Space, 45 Israel LR (2012), 390. Chinese JIL (2021) might significantly reduce the legitimate functioning space for cyberattacks and prevent them from doing what they are best at, namely, accomplishing military advantage precisely without causing non-reversible damages of critical civilian infrastructure and having the potential to stay non-violent and reduce collateral losses. Such consequences turn out to be contrary to the humanitarian intentions of these Chinese scholars to reduce the harms suffered by victims of war. ## III.C. Proportionality of cyberattacks against infrastructures",
        "59": "Given that the interconnectedness of military networks and their heavy reliance on civilian cyber infrastructure has left the principle of distinction virtually empty of contents, the principle of proportionality becomes an ultimate rule for protecting civilian persons and objects. This principle prohibits attacks “which may be expected to cause incidental loss of civilian life, injury to civilians, damage to civilian objects, or a combination thereof, which would be excessive in relation to the concrete and direct military advantage anticipated”.145 In light of the harsh challenges imposed by the unique features of cyber warfare, the actual role that the principle of proportionality can play could not be overstated.",
        "60": "Under LOAC, what can be considered as “excessive” incidental damage to civilian objects in comparison with the expected concrete and direct military advantage remains controversial. The principle of proportionality is “more easily stated than applied in practice”. As a matter of fact, findings of excessive incidental damage to civilian infrastructure are very few and far between as compared to the military advantage.146 Moreover, the proportionality assessment in LOAC is made ex-ante when expected collateral damage is weighed against the anticipated military damage.147 The practical difficulties in ascertaining the expected effects of cyber operations prevent commanders from precisely assessing the potential collateral damages to civilian objects. How to apply this principle in cyberspace hinges on the development of both legal interpretation and technology, the uncertainty of which may jeopardize 145 Additional Protocol I, above n. 100, Art. 51(5)(b). 146 ICTY, Final Report to the Prosecutor by the Committee Established to Review the NATO Bombing Campaign Against the Federal Republic of Yugoslavia (13 June 2000), para.19 (www.icty.org/x/file/Press/nato061300.pdf). 147 Schmitt, above n.125, 19. Jiang, Decoding China's Perspectives on Cyber Warfare 291 this principle’s ability to prevent significant collateral damages to civilian objects in cyber warfare.",
        "61": "In the digital era, incidental damages to civilian objects will no longer be limited to physical ones but also the loss of functionality of civilian cyber infrastructure. Therefore, in order to accommodate the special needs of cyber warfare, several opinions calling for modifications of the assessment of “collateral damages to civilian objects” have emerged. For example, it is suggested that more weight should be given to temporary consequences regarding cyberattacks, for the temporary incapacity of critical systems would incur more severe consequences than mere inconvenience, such as in situations where loss of life may be caused by the inability of hospitals to communicate vital information.¹⁴⁸ But existing LOAC fails to provide any legal basis for this. The paradoxical applicable law is described as: whereas the destruction of a single civilian car would amount to legally relevant, albeit rather insignificant, ‘collateral damage’, the disconnection of thousands or millions of households, companies and public services from the Internet or other communication services, or the severance of online financial transactions for a country’s entire economy and the corresponding economic and societal effects as such would not count as relevant elements to be factored into the proportionality calculus.¹⁴⁹",
        "62": "Similarly, some scholars propose to include “knock-on effects” of cyber-attacks in the proportionality calculations when such an effect would not have occurred “but for” the attack.¹⁵⁰ “Knock-on effects” refer to those generated by the initial effects of the attack.¹⁵¹ Both the 1990-1992 Gulf War and the NATO action in the former Yugoslavia illustrate that the knock-on effects of targeting electricity grid may cause more harm to the affected civilians than the direct effect of these attacks themselves.¹⁵² Although existing law has not touched upon this issue, most scholars seem to agree that knock-on effects ¹⁴⁸ Oona Hathaway, et al., The Law of Cyber-Attack, 100 California LR (2012), 851. ¹⁴⁹ Geiß &amp; Lahmann, above n.144, 397. ¹⁵⁰ Michael Schmitt, Heather Harrison Dinniss &amp; Thomas C. Wingfield, Computers and War: The Legal Battlespace, Background Paper Prepared for the Informal High-Level Expert Meeting on Current Challenges to International Humanitarian Law (25-27 June 2004), 8-9 (www.hpcresearch.org/sites/default/files/publications/schmittetal.pdf). ¹⁵¹ Ibid., 8. ¹⁵² Dinniss, above n.109, 205. Chinese JIL (2021) should be part of the proportionality analysis to the extent they are “reasonably foreseeable”,[153] which resonates with the term “expected” in Additional Protocol I.",
        "63": "Commentary to Rule 51 of the Tallinn Manual includes both direct and indirect effects of attacks in the proportionality assessment.[154] The former means “the immediate, first-order consequences, unaltered by intervening events or mechanisms”, and the latter refers to “the delayed and/or displaced second-, third-, and higher-order consequences of action, created through intermediate events or mechanisms”. Without deliberately using the same term, the Tallinn Manual adopts the “knock-on effects” approach, factoring “any indirect effects that should be expected by those individuals planning, approving, or executing a cyberattack” into the proportionality evaluation.[155] Such indirect effects can be exemplified by accidents involving transportation systems or malware inserted into a military computer system spread to other civilian computer systems and thereafter disables them, where those risks are or should have been expected. Such indirect effects may result from blocking the Global Positioning Satellite data or disrupting the Global Positioning System.[156] Inconvenience, irritation, stress, or fear caused by cyber operations are explicitly excluded from collateral damages to civilian objects.[157]",
        "64": "The Chinese scholars' view on the theoretical and practical difficulties in applying the present law on proportionality concurs with the mainstream view among international law commentators. The Tallinn Manual's rules and commentaries on this principle are early attempts to codify the prevailing treaty interpretation, contributing to an enhanced relief valve of attacks against critical cyber infrastructure. The Chinese scholars' critiques of Rule 80 of the Tallinn Manual, which permits attacks against highly dangerous infrastructure, were not made in conjunction with Rule 51, becoming an interpretation out of context. The proportionality assessment under existing law disillusions those who wish to use it to make up for the failure of rules regarding the principle of distinction in protecting civilian safety. If the applicable LOAC rules regarding the principles of distinction and proportionality remain unchanged, the principle of precaution would be the only safeguard left. 153 Schmitt, above n.150. 154 Tallinn Manual, above n.21, 160, para.6. 155 Ibid. 156 Ibid. 157 Ibid., para.5. Jiang, Decoding China's Perspectives on Cyber Warfare 293 ## III.D. Targetable civilians",
        "65": "Article 51(3) of the Additional Protocol I¹⁵⁸ and Article 13(3)¹⁵⁹ of the Protocol Additional to the Geneva Conventions of 12 August 1949 and relating to the Protection of Victims of Non-International Armed Conflicts provides that, if civilians engage in conducts amounting to “direct participation in hostilities”, their protection against direct military attacks would be suspended. In cyber warfare, “for such time” as civilians directly participate in hostilities, they not only become legitimate targets of military operations but also are bound by LOAC rules governing the conduct of hostilities. Furthermore, such civilians should not be factored into the proportionality calculation. They are not considered for the principle of precaution that aims to avoid or minimize incidental harm to civilians.¹⁶⁰",
        "66": "Civilians may be targeted for direct participation in hostilities. Currently, given the complexity of this issue, there is no authoritative guidance on which activities qualify as direct participation.¹⁶¹ The present State practice, the jurisprudence of international judicial bodies and prevailing academic views adopt a case-by-case determination method through exemplification rather than illustration.¹⁶² To address when civilians may be targeted, the ICRC sponsored a five-year research project in 2003 and produced its *Interpretive Guidance on the Notion of Direct Participation in Hostilities under International Humanitarian Law* (“Interpretive Guidance”).¹⁶³",
        "67": "In this document, the ICRC proposes three “constitutive elements” of direct participation in hostilities: (1) an act that negatively impacts the enemy’s military effort, or in which harm is intended (threshold of harm); (2) a relatively direct nexus between that act and the resulting harm, or that act constituting an “integral part” of a coordinated military operation likely to cause the said harm (direct causation), and (3) linkage to the armed conflict --- 158 Additional Protocol I, above n. 100, Art. 51(3). 159 Protocol Additional to the Geneva Conventions of 12 August 1949, and relating to the Protection of Victims of Non-International Armed Conflicts, 1125 UNTS 609 (7 December 1978), Art. 13(3). 160 Melzer, above n.109, 27. 161 Michael Schmitt, Deconstructing Direct Participation in Hostilities: The Constitutive Elements, 42 NYU JILP (2010), 699. 162 Ibid., 705-09. 163 ICRC, Interpretive Guidance on the Notion of Direct Participation in Hostilities under International Humanitarian Law (prepared by Nils Melzer) (May 2009) (www.icrc.org/eng/assets/files/other/icrc-002-0990.pdf). Chinese JIL (2021) (belligerent nexus).¹⁶⁴ Although these criteria were generally accepted, the Interpretive Guidance has drawn strong criticism from scholars.¹⁶⁵ These scholars argued that it is both underinclusive as to improperly exclude some forms of direct participation and overinclusive as to incorrectly permit attacks against some civilians and civilian property.¹⁶⁶",
        "68": "There is no reason to distinguish cyber operations from kinetic operations regarding how civilian conducts qualify as direct participation in hostilities, as most controversies are not cyber-specific. Critiques of the Interpretive Guidance in conventional warfare do not necessarily stand in cyberspace. According to the “threshold of harm” element, an act amounting to hostility does not have to qualify as an attack within the meaning of LOAC, which indispensably entails the infliction of death, injury, or destruction on military personnel and objects. “Essentially any consequence adversely affecting the military operations or military capacity” of an opposing party would satisfy the test.¹⁶⁷ Compared to the difficulties in arming civilians with traditional weapons, the technical barrier to cyber armed civilians is almost non-existent. It is too easy for civilians to have the know-how to conduct harmful cyber activities.¹⁶⁸ Therefore, in cyber warfare, “the pool of targetable individuals could be extremely large in future conflicts, far more than is the case in classic conflict.”¹⁶⁹",
        "69": "Espionage activities, including gathering and disseminating intelligence of military tactics and operations by cyber means, or hacking into the enemy system to identify enemy vulnerabilities, would both suffice. Engaging in developing cyber defence systems, such as encryption technology, firewalls or anti-virus software, also falls under this category. However, the element of “direct causation” defines them as causing only “indirect harm” because such individual conduct “merely builds up or maintains the capacity of a party to 164 Ibid., 46. 165 See, i.e., Kenneth Watkin, Opportunity Lost: Organized Armed Groups and the ICRC “Direct Participation in Hostilities” Interpretive Guidance, 42 NYU JILP (2010), 641-95; Schmitt, above n.161, 697-740; Bill Boothby, “And for Such Time as”: The Time Dimension to Direct Participation in Hostilities, 42 NYU JILP (2010), 741-68; W. Hays Park, Part IX of the ICRC “Direct Participation in Hostilities” Study: No Mandate, No Expertise, and Legally Incorrect, 42 NYU JILP (2010), 769-830. 166 See Schmitt, above n.161, 712-38. 167 Above n.163, 47. 168 Schmitt, above n.125, 15. 169 Ibid. Jiang, Decoding China's Perspectives on Cyber Warfare 295 harm its adversary\".170 Considering the Interpretive Guidance as sacrificing military necessity for exaggerated civilian protection, commentators suggest expanding the current interpretation of direct hostilities to capacity-building acts, namely, those espionage and development activities specific to a particular cyber operation or enemy system.171",
        "70": "Nevertheless, the unique features of cyber warfare demand particular attention paid to certain issues in cyberspace. Commentators questioned the rationality of the ICRC's interpretation of the term \"for such time\" when a direct participant can be targeted.172 The ICRC provides that this period covers preparatory measures of a specific act of direct participation, deployment to or return from the activity concerned.173 They argued that the restrictive interpretation has dramatically narrowed the window of targetability, rendering this standard particularly impractical in cyber warfare.174 There is usually no deployment to or return from cyber operations since most of them are controlled remotely.",
        "71": "More importantly, the duration of cyber operations can be extremely short, sometimes even too brief to identify the attacker.175 Or, in some cases, for example, a surreptitiously emplaced logic bomb, the effect of cyber operations can be long-delayed.176 A better approach is suggested to cure this deficiency: To characterise an individual who engages in multiple cyber operations that are part of an on-going cyber campaign as a direct participant targetable throughout the period of activity. Once the individual definitively withdraws from participation, he or she regains their protection from attack, and not before.177 This approach seems more promising but might still lead to scary consequences. For civilian computer operators working in closed military facilities, 170 Above n.163, 53. 171 Michael Schmitt, Cyber Operations and the Jus in Bello: Key Issues, in: Daria P. Wollschaeger &amp; Raul Pedrozo (eds.), International Law and the Changing Character of War (International Law Studies, Vol. 87) (2011), 101. 172 See generally above n.165; Schmitt, above n.125, 14-16. 173 Above n.163, 65-68. 174 See, e.g., Schmitt, above n.125, 14-16. 175 Ibid., 16. 176 Schmitt, above n.171, 102. 177 Schmitt, above n.125, 16. Chinese JIL (2021) their targetability would not expire after work but become a portable threat travelling with them and making their family members and neighbours legitimate collateral damage. As the debate continues, any resolution must grant sufficient consideration to the safety of civilians.",
        "72": "Cyber warfare also presents peculiar questions to the controversy over which members of an organized armed group are targetable between the ICRC and the NATO members. Members of organized armed groups are the other category of civilians that are legitimate targets of military operations.^[178]^ According to the Interpretive Guidance, only those with a “continuous combat function” can be attacked.^[179]^ The NATO members and Israel favour including all members of a group formed to conduct hostilities.^[180]^ These countries criticize the requirement of “continuous combat function” as affording greater protection to members of organized groups than members of the armed forces, whereas the former enjoy no right to engage in hostilities while the latter does.^[181]^ In the human-made theatre in cyberspace, where distinguishing members of organized armed groups from civilians can be far more difficult and uncertain than on physical battlefields, the additional requirement of ensuring that a member performs “continuous combat function” seems impractical and unnecessary. After all, LOAC’s presumption of civilian status in the case of doubt has offered adequate protection for such members.^[182]^",
        "73": "At first sight, the Chinese scholars’ view tends to see the problem as a practical one of attribution and verification rather than one of law. Nonetheless, such difficulties give rise to debates about legal issues specific to cyber warfare. To the degree that the targetability of civilians is concerned, the critiques of the Interpretive Guidance mainly stem from practical difficulties, before or at the moment of targeting, in distinguishing members of armed groups or civilians directly participating in hostilities from civilians.",
        "74": "For capacity-building or -maintaining conduct that involves espionage or development activities by cyber means, it would be premature to argue that China is willing to waive its right to attack civilians that severely harm its military operation or capacity. But given its general defensive stance on security 178 Melzer, above n.109, 29. 179 Above n.163, 71. 180 See Michael Schmitt, The Interpretive Guidance on the Notion of Direct Participation in Hostilities: A Critical Analysis, 1 Harvard Nat’l S J (2010), 21-24. 181 Schmitt, above n.171, 100. 182 Additional Protocol I, above n.100, Art. 50(1). Jiang, Decoding China's Perspectives on Cyber Warfare 297 issues, China is neither likely to embrace the broader approach that covers such “indirect” conduct. If China ends up agreeing with the applicability of LOAC rules on this issue, it might favour the ICRC’s restrictive standard of “for such time” and “continuous combat function”, not only because of China’s defensive rather than offensive approach to the use of force, but also because of its humanitarian considerations to protect the lives of a large number of civilians relate—occupationally to activities that have a bearing on military operations, or personally to someone occasionally carrying out conduct of hostilities—from lethal attacks.",
        "75": "For the purpose of civilian protection, the better approach for States turns out to be recruiting only military personnel, ideally with uniforms and other distinctive marks, for military operations by cyber means. While accessible in theory, the transformation of non-State cyber actors into national forces would be time-consuming. As a reminder, the privateers were not completely abandoned by States until the time when the maritime powers had developed strong navies, which were capable of forcing the armed merchants who refused to integrate into the navy to put down their weapons in exchange for State protection on the high seas and defeating privates and enemy fleets.^[183]^ ## IV. The objectives of China’s normative proposals",
        "76": "Based on its limited number of available official statements and practices, China’s opposition to the applicability of some LOAC rules in cyberspace remains vague and general from a legal perspective. The SCO Agreement’s expansive version of cyber “war” indicates that China’s earlier position did not distinguish armed conflicts from other situations, although the application of LOAC hinges on such a differentiation. Apart from the catchall interpretation of cyberattacks, many Chinese scholars expressed concerns over the adequacy of the LOAC rules governing the targetability of dual-use infrastructure and certain groups of civilians and the principle of proportionality. These concerns are not groundless both in terms of law and practice. In fact, the ICRC’s views on the three issues, or even some corresponding rules of the Tallinn Manual, address their concerns well. The practice of the US and its allies that China opposes has not hardened into customary international law binding on all ^[183]^ Florian Egloff, Cybersecurity and the Age of Privateering: A Historical Analogy, Cyber Studies Programme Working Paper No. 1 (March 2015), 3-6, 9 (www.politics.ox.ac.uk/publications/cybersecurity-and-the-age-of-privateering-a-historical-analogy.html). Chinese JIL (2021) States that fail to maintain persistent objection to it. These facts have contributed to China's incremental acceptance of the general applicability of LOAC to the cyber context despite many remaining controversies over how specific LOAC rules should be interpreted and applied to cyber operations.",
        "77": "As with China's concerns over the Tallinn Manual's overemphasis on the military paradigm of responses to cyberattacks in international legal discourse, which threatens to derogate from the principle of non-use of force and to abuse the right to self-defence, a more diverse group of experts was composed to draft the second version of the Tallinn Manual, to address the criticisms of the limited diversity of the group of experts participating in drafting the first version of the Tallinn Manual[184] and this group's overreliance on Western legal sources.[185] There were three non-Western experts from China, Belarus and Thailand, among the nine experts who participated in the formulation process of Tallinn Manual 2.0.[186] The scope of the Tallinn Manual 2.0 expands from \"above the threshold\" cyber operations whose \"scale and effects are comparable to non-cyber operations rising to the level of a use of force\"[187] or which are \"executed in the context of an armed conflict that [is] subject to the LOAC\"[188] to \"below the threshold\" cyber operations that take place in peacetime and fall outside the regulatory scope of the jus ad bellum and the jus in bello.",
        "78": "The threshold of use of force functions as a firewall that separates cyber operations which can trigger the exercise of the right to self-defence by a victim State from cyber operations that can entail only pacific countermeasures. As previously mentioned, a major concern of China points to the Tallinn Manual's threshold on which cyber operations constitute use of force within the meaning of Article 2(4) of the UN Charter. The Chinese perspective considers it as a low standard intended to accommodate some States' strategic 184 Dieter Fleck, Searching for International Rules Applicable to Cyber Warfare—A Critical First Assessment of the New Tallinn Manual, 18 JCSL (2013), 335; Ido Kilovaty, Cyber Warfare and the Jus ad Bellum Challenge: Evaluation in the Light of the Tallinn Manual on International Law Applicable to Cyber Warfare, 5 Am U Nat'l S L Brief (2014), 108. 185 Kirsten E. Eichensehr, Book Review: Tallinn Manual on the International Law Applicable to Cyber Warfare, 108 AJIL (2014), 587-88. 186 HUANG Zhixiong, Tallinn Manual 2.0: Influence and Inspirations, 3 Zhongguo Xinxi Anquan [China Info S] (2018), 84. 187 Tallinn Manual 2.0, above n.21, Rule 69, 330. 188 Ibid., Rule 80, 375. Jiang, Decoding China's Perspectives on Cyber Warfare 299 needs to expansively interpret the right to self-defence under Article 51 of the UN Charter in order to justify their use of force against other States.",
        "79": "Rule 69 and Rule 71 of the Tallinn Manual 2.0 were drafted by the International Group of Experts of the Tallinn Manual and incorporated in the second version without being discussed by the experts of the Tallinn Manual 2.0. Rule 69 stipulates the “scale and effects” approach.¹⁸⁹ Rule 71 provides that only “a State that is the target of a cyber operation that rises to the level of an armed attack may exercise its inherent right of self-defence”.¹⁹⁰ The International Group of Experts of the Tallinn Manual reached a consensus that the scale of effects of cyber operations causing physical consequences can be considered as comparable to those of kinetic operations and hence the use of force under the *jus ad bellum*.¹⁹¹ But they contested over the status of cyber operations that have no consequences in the physical world but can lead to serious consequences.¹⁹²",
        "80": "Some Western scholars identified the failure of Rule 69 to include cyber operations having no physical consequences but can cause temporary suspension of operational functionality,¹⁹³ result in alteration and destruction of data or code,¹⁹⁴ or involve “psychological operation” and “cyber espionage”,¹⁹⁵ as a major shortcoming of the Tallinn Rules.¹⁹⁶ Accordingly, they considered the definition of “use of force” adopted by the Tallinn Rules 189 Ibid. 190 Tallinn Manual 2.0, above n.21, Rule 71, 339. 191 See, e.g., Ido Kilovaty, Virtual Violence-Disruptive Cyberspace Operations as “Attacks” Under International Humanitarian Law, 23 Michigan Telecomm &amp; Tech LR (2016), 145-46. 192 See above n.184, Fleck, 336-37; Kilovaty, 116. 193 Tallinn Manual 2.0, above n.21, 21; Michael N. Schmitt, International Law in Cyberspace: The Koh Speech and Tallinn Manual Juxtaposed, 54 Harvard JIL (2012), 20. 194 Mačák Kubo, Military Objectives 2.0: The Case for Interpreting Computer Data as Objects Under International Humanitarian Law, 48 Israel LR (2015), 78; Heather A. Harrison Dinniss, The Nature of Objects: Targeting Networks and the Challenge of Defining Military Objectives, 48 Israel LR (2015), 54. 195 Ido Kilovaty, Violence in Cyberspace: Are Disruptive Cyberspace Operations Legal under International Humanitarian Law?, Just Security (3 March 2017) (www.justsecurity.org/38291/violence-cyberspace-disruptive-cyberspace-operations-legal-international-humanitarian-law/); Marco Roscini, Cyber Operations and the Use of Force in International Law (2014), 240-42. 196 Dan Efrony &amp; Yuval Shany, A Rule Book on the Shelf? Tallinn Manual 2.0 on Cyberoperations and Subsequent State Practice, 112 AJIL (2018), 590. Chinese JIL (2021) as “narrow”, blaming the experts for their overreliance on “a consequence-based gravity test in the jus ad bellum”.¹⁹⁷ In addition to the perceived narrow prohibition against the use of cyber force, they considered the Tallinn Rules’ construction of the right to self-defence as even narrower, given the significant difficulties in establishing causal links between multiple consequences and a cyber operation added to the difficulties of attributing a cyber operation to a State or a non-State actor.¹⁹⁸ Although the notion of anticipatory self-defence, which has long been a concern of China and an old controversy in the international law circle with a new incarnation, was adopted in the Tallinn Rules,¹⁹⁹ the practical difficulties in detecting the preparations for launching a cyberattack and further determining whether a cyberattack is imminent render the requirements for resorting to using force on the ground of anticipatory self-defence highly demanding.²⁰⁰",
        "81": "Consequently, the victim State’s response in most cases would be limited to measures falling below the threshold of use of force, such as countermeasures²⁰¹ or referring the matter to the UNSC.²⁰² By far, the International Group of Experts who drafted the Tallinn Rules have identified only the Stuxnet attack as meeting the Tallinn threshold of use of force; some experts considered it as meeting the higher “scale and effects” threshold of an armed attack that can trigger the application of LOAC.²⁰³ Even American military lawyers and scholars, who are deemed by their Chinese counterparts as seeking to militarize cyberspace through lowering the threshold of use of force, have admitted that, “the prevailing view is that most, if not all, documented cyber actions taken by States to date have fallen below the ‘use of force’ threshold.”²⁰⁴ Apart from the narrowly construed right to self-defence in situations of armed conflicts, Rule 20 of the Tallinn Manual 2.0 provides a broader right of States to take countermeasures in time of peace, “whether cyber in nature or not, in response to a breach of an international legal 197 Ibid. 198 Ibid., 591. 199 Above n.21, Tallinn Manual, Rule 15; Tallinn Manual 2.0, Rule 73. 200 Tallinn Manual 2.0, n.21, 351-53; Eichensehr, above n.185, 587. 201 Tallinn Manual 2.0, n.21, Rule 20, 161. 202 Ibid., Rule 76, 357. 203 Ibid., 342. 204 Gary Corn &amp; Eric Jensen, The Technicolor Zone of Cyberspace–Part I, Just Security (30 May 2018) (www.justsecurity.org/57217/technicolor-zone-cyberspace-part/). Jiang, Decoding China's Perspectives on Cyber Warfare 301 obligation that is owned by another State”.²⁰⁵ Nevertheless, the exercise of this right by States is subject to similar difficulties in attribution, in addition to a set of conditions, including notification, proportionality,²⁰⁶ and the exclusion of measures amounting to uses of force.",
        "82": "The narrow construction of the right to self-defence and countermeasures under the Tallinn Rules demonstrates the reluctance of the International Group of Experts to permissibly authorize a State to undertake unilateral acts that would result in effects in the territory of another State, in another word, a strong pro-sovereignty inclination of the Tallinn Rules. In contrast, the US and the UK argued that sovereignty did not by itself constitute a specific rule of international law that cyber operations might violate, but rather a foundational principle of international law that undergirds specific rules of international law, such as the prohibition against the use of force under Article 2(4) of the UN Charter and the rule of non-intervention under customary international law. In these two countries’ view, such a principle has no binding effect, and low-scale cyber operations deployed by a State that generate effects in another State’s territory but do not breach any of these specific rules, do not violate international law merely because of their incompatibility with the abstract principle of sovereignty.²⁰⁷ This controversy over the status of sovereignty remains unsettled in the final UN GGE report mainly due to the UK’s active participation in the UN GGE. Yet NATO’s Allied Joint Doctrine for Cyberspace Operations released in 2020 has endorsed the status of sovereignty as a rule of international law in a footnote, with the UK as the only NATO member having reserved on that footnote.²⁰⁸",
        "83": "Therefore, although the Tallinn Rules were developed under the auspices of NATO, they represent neither the exceptional perspectives of some States such as the US or the UK nor the collective views of the NATO members. Throughout the Hague Process, during the drafting of the Tallinn Rules, where legal advisors from 50 States were given the opportunity to 205 Tallinn Manual 2.0, above n.21, Rule 38, 111. 206 Ibid., 120, 127. 207 As noted in: Michael Schmitt, US Transparency Regarding International Law in Cyberspace, Just Security (15 November 2016) (www.justsecurity.org/34465/transparency-international-law-cyberspace/); also Corn &amp; Jensen, above n.204. 208 North Atlantic Treaty Organization Allied Joint Publication-3.20, Allied Joint Doctrine For Cyberspace Operations (Edition A Version 1) (29 January 2020), Footnote 26 and GBR’s Reservation (https://assets.publishing.service.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/899678/doctrine_nato_cyberspace_operations_ajp_3_20_1_.pdf). Chinese JIL (2021) express their legal positions to shape the codification process, many States maintained a persistent policy of silence and ambiguity on the specificities of existing or emerging norms regulating cyberspace.²⁰⁹ Meanwhile, the International Group of Experts of the Tallinn Manual 2.0, together with the Dutch Ministry of Foreign Affairs, convened two consultative meetings in April 2015 and February 2016 with representatives from more than one hundred States, including China.²¹⁰",
        "84": "The technological difficulties in credibly attributing responsibility for cyber operations, the ongoing controversies over which existing rules apply to cyberspace, their contents, the suitability of the prevailing international legal framework as the primary method to regulate inter-State behaviour in cyberspace, and political and strategic considerations that have prevented States from making public attributions and invoking their rights to take responsive measures, all have contributed to the “wait and see” approach adopted by most States towards utilizing rules and norms of international law, including the Tallinn Rules, to regulate cyber operations.²¹¹ These factors cast doubt over the ripeness of codifying applicable international law in these areas. The limited State practice and opinio juris partly explain China’s “wait and see” stance, which is in line with the mainstream approach in order to preserve a degree of operational flexibility in the face of technological development and the dynamic international environment.²¹²",
        "85": "To summarize, China’s long-term insistence on the non-applicability of the right to self-defence and some LOAC rules to cyberspace does not only conform to the development trend of international normative discourses but also contributes to fuelling this momentum. Sovereign control of cyberspace has been increasingly reviving, and the focus of international legal discourse has shifted from the military paradigm concentrated on the jus ad bellum and the jus in bello to the prism of general rules of international law governing State behaviour in peacetime. The current landscape of international law identification and development reflects and underpins most concerns of China 209 Efrony &amp; Yuval Shany, above n.196, 588. 210 HUANG, above n.186, 84-85. 211 Efrony &amp; Yuval Shany, above n.196, 584, 588, 633, 639, 648, 653 (2018). 212 See, e.g., ZHU Lingling, Deduction and Development of State Responsibility Attribution in Cyber Attacks from the Perspective of Tallinn Manual Version 2.0, 1 Dangdai Faxue [Contemporary LR] (2019), 77-78; HUANG Zhixiong, New Trends of International Rule-making for Cyberspace: Some Considerations Based Tallinn Manual 2.0, 1 Xiamen Daxue Xuebao [J Xiamen U] (2018), 5-6. Jiang, Decoding China's Perspectives on Cyber Warfare 303 and many other like-minded States, while the Tallinn Rules serve as one of the early efforts rather than the concluding remark of ongoing international legal discourses.",
        "86": "However, there are two residual concerns of China not reflected in the mainstream State practice following the publication of the two versions of the Tallinn Manual. They are underscored by the elements of cyber sovereignty proposed by China that call for the prohibition of using ICT, information and communications networks to carry out hostile activities or acts of aggression or arms race, and the OEWG resolution's reiteration of the need for introducing additional rules of behaviour regarding States' right to combat interference in their internal affairs through the dissemination of false and distorted news and States' duty to abstain from engaging in such activities. One is external threats posed by more powerful States which may utilize their digital advantages to threaten China's national security and social stability, and the other is external limitations, either from emerging norms of international law or other established powers, of China's exercise of regulatory power over content transmitted in cyberspace to combat such threats.",
