Harrison Dinniss, The Nature of Objects: Targeting Networks and the Challenge of Defining Military Objectives, 48 Israel LR (2015), 54.\n195 Ido Kilovaty, Violence in Cyberspace: Are Disruptive Cyberspace Operations Legal under International Humanitarian Law?, Just Security (3 March 2017) (www.justsecurity.org/38291/violence-cyberspace-disruptive-cyberspace-operations-legal-international-humanitarian-law/); Marco Roscini, Cyber Operations and the Use of Force in International Law (2014), 240-42.\n196 Dan Efrony &amp; Yuval Shany, A Rule Book on the Shelf? Tallinn Manual 2.0 on Cyberoperations and Subsequent State Practice, 112 AJIL (2018), 590.\nChinese JIL (2021)\nas “narrow”, blaming the experts for their overreliance on “a consequence-based gravity test in the jus ad bellum”.¹⁹⁷ In addition to the perceived narrow prohibition against the use of cyber force, they considered the Tallinn Rules’ construction of the right to self-defence as even narrower, given the significant difficulties in establishing causal links between multiple consequences and a cyber operation added to the difficulties of attributing a cyber operation to a State or a non-State actor.¹⁹⁸ Although the notion of anticipatory self-defence, which has long been a concern of China and an old controversy in the international law circle with a new incarnation, was adopted in the Tallinn Rules,¹⁹⁹ the practical difficulties in detecting the preparations for launching a cyberattack and further determining whether a cyberattack is imminent render the requirements for resorting to using force on the ground of anticipatory self-defence highly demanding.²⁰⁰\n81. Consequently, the victim State’s response in most cases would be limited to measures falling below the threshold of use of force, such as countermeasures²⁰¹ or referring the matter to the UNSC.²⁰² By far, the International Group of Experts who drafted the Tallinn Rules have identified only the Stuxnet attack as meeting the Tallinn threshold of use of force; some experts considered it as meeting the higher “scale and effects” threshold of an armed attack that can trigger the application of LOAC.²⁰³ Even American military lawyers and scholars, who are deemed by their Chinese counterparts as seeking to militarize cyberspace through lowering the threshold of use of force, have admitted that, “the prevailing view is that most, if not all, documented cyber actions taken by States to date have fallen below the ‘use of force’ threshold.”²⁰⁴ Apart from the narrowly construed right to self-defence in situations of armed conflicts, Rule 20 of the Tallinn Manual 2.0 provides a broader right of States to take countermeasures in time of peace, “whether cyber in nature or not, in response to a breach of an international legal\n197 Ibid.\n198 Ibid., 591.\n199 Above n.21, Tallinn Manual, Rule 15; Tallinn Manual 2.0, Rule 73.\n200 Tallinn Manual 2.0, n.21, 351-53; Eichensehr, above n.185, 587.\n201 Tallinn Manual 2.0, n.21, Rule 20, 161.\n202 Ibid., Rule 76, 357.\n203 Ibid., 342.\n204 Gary Corn &amp; Eric Jensen, The Technicolor Zone of Cyberspace–Part I, Just Security (30 May 2018) (www.justsecurity.org/57217/technicolor-zone-cyberspace-part/).\nJiang, Decoding China's Perspectives on Cyber Warfare 301\nobligation that is owned by another State”.²⁰⁵ Nevertheless, the exercise of this right by States is subject to similar difficulties in attribution, in addition to a set of conditions, including notification, proportionality,²⁰⁶ and the exclusion of measures amounting to uses of force.\n82. The narrow construction of the right to self-defence and countermeasures under the Tallinn Rules demonstrates the reluctance of the International Group of Experts to permissibly authorize a State to undertake unilateral acts that would result in effects in the territory of another State, in another word, a strong pro-sovereignty inclination of the Tallinn Rules. In contrast, the US and the UK argued that sovereignty did not by itself constitute a specific rule of international law that cyber operations might violate, but rather a foundational principle of international law that undergirds specific rules of international law, such as the prohibition against the use of force under Article 2(4) of the UN Charter and the rule of non-intervention under customary international law. In these two countries’ view, such a principle has no binding effect, and low-scale cyber operations deployed by a State that generate effects in another State’s territory but do not breach any of these specific rules, do not violate international law merely because of their incompatibility with the abstract principle of sovereignty.²⁰⁷ This controversy over the status of sovereignty remains unsettled in the final UN GGE report mainly due to the UK’s active participation in the UN GGE. Yet NATO’s Allied Joint Doctrine for Cyberspace Operations released in 2020 has endorsed the status of sovereignty as a rule of international law in a footnote, with the UK as the only NATO member having reserved on that footnote.²⁰⁸\n83. Therefore, although the Tallinn Rules were developed under the auspices of NATO, they represent neither the exceptional perspectives of some States such as the US or the UK nor the collective views of the NATO members. Throughout the Hague Process, during the drafting of the Tallinn Rules, where legal advisors from 50 States were given the opportunity to\n205 Tallinn Manual 2.0, above n.21, Rule 38, 111.\n206 Ibid., 120, 127.\n207 As noted in: Michael Schmitt, US Transparency Regarding International Law in Cyberspace, Just Security (15 November 2016) (www.justsecurity.org/34465/transparency-international-law-cyberspace/); also Corn &amp; Jensen, above n.204.\n208 North Atlantic Treaty Organization Allied Joint Publication-3.20, Allied Joint Doctrine For Cyberspace Operations (Edition A Version 1) (29 January 2020), Footnote 26 and GBR’s Reservation (https://assets.publishing.service.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/899678/doctrine_nato_cyberspace_operations_ajp_3_20_1_.pdf).\nChinese JIL (2021)\nexpress their legal positions to shape the codification process, many States maintained a persistent policy of silence and ambiguity on the specificities of existing or emerging norms regulating cyberspace.²⁰⁹ Meanwhile, the International Group of Experts of the Tallinn Manual 2.0, together with the Dutch Ministry of Foreign Affairs, convened two consultative meetings in April 2015 and February 2016 with representatives from more than one hundred States, including China.²¹⁰\n84. The technological difficulties in credibly attributing responsibility for cyber operations, the ongoing controversies over which existing rules apply to cyberspace, their contents, the suitability of the prevailing international legal framework as the primary method to regulate inter-State behaviour in cyberspace, and political and strategic considerations that have prevented States from making public attributions and invoking their rights to take responsive measures, all have contributed to the “wait and see” approach adopted by most States towards utilizing rules and norms of international law, including the Tallinn Rules, to regulate cyber operations.²¹¹ These factors cast doubt over the ripeness of codifying applicable international law in these areas. The limited State practice and opinio juris partly explain China’s “wait and see” stance, which is in line with the mainstream approach in order to preserve a degree of operational flexibility in the face of technological development and the dynamic international environment.²¹²\n85. To summarize, China’s long-term insistence on the non-applicability of the right to self-defence and some LOAC rules to cyberspace does not only conform to the development trend of international normative discourses but also contributes to fuelling this momentum. Sovereign control of cyberspace has been increasingly reviving, and the focus of international legal discourse has shifted from the military paradigm concentrated on the jus ad bellum and the jus in bello to the prism of general rules of international law governing State behaviour in peacetime. The current landscape of international law identification and development reflects and underpins most concerns of China\n209 Efrony &amp; Yuval Shany, above n.196, 588.\n210 HUANG, above n.186, 84-85.\n211 Efrony &amp; Yuval Shany, above n.196, 584, 588, 633, 639, 648, 653 (2018).\n212 See, e.g., ZHU Lingling, Deduction and Development of State Responsibility Attribution in Cyber Attacks from the Perspective of Tallinn Manual Version 2.0, 1 Dangdai Faxue [Contemporary LR] (2019), 77-78; HUANG Zhixiong, New Trends of International Rule-making for Cyberspace: Some Considerations Based Tallinn Manual 2.0, 1 Xiamen Daxue Xuebao [J Xiamen U] (2018), 5-6.\nJiang, Decoding China's Perspectives on Cyber Warfare 303\nand many other like-minded States, while the Tallinn Rules serve as one of the early efforts rather than the concluding remark of ongoing international legal discourses.\n86. However, there are two residual concerns of China not reflected in the mainstream State practice following the publication of the two versions of the Tallinn Manual. They are underscored by the elements of cyber sovereignty proposed by China that call for the prohibition of using ICT, information and communications networks to carry out hostile activities or acts of aggression or arms race, and the OEWG resolution's reiteration of the need for introducing additional rules of behaviour regarding States' right to combat interference in their internal affairs through the dissemination of false and distorted news and States' duty to abstain from engaging in such activities. One is external threats posed by more powerful States which may utilize their digital advantages to threaten China's national security and social stability, and the other is external limitations, either from emerging norms of international law or other established powers, of China's exercise of regulatory power over content transmitted in cyberspace to combat such threats.\n87. Therefore, in addition to the mentioned concerns addressed by the mainstream State practice, China has employed its generalized and vague resistance to the applicability of some rules of the jus ad bellum and the jus in bello to cyberspace as bargaining leverage to achieve another two objectives in international legal discourse: (1) to build up consensus for a new treaty regulating all use of cyber forces, or a disarmament treaty banning all or at least some types of information weapons, and (2) to block the formation of new law that would limit its domestic regulatory power over cyberspace and prevent disfavoured existing law from binding on its exercise of sovereign power in cyberspace.\n88. The first objective of China's opposition to an explicit affirmation of the right to self-defence and the applicability of some LOAC rules to the cyber context, namely, to build up consensus for a disarmament treaty on the use of information weapons under the auspice of the UN, emanates from the nature of States' right to self-defence. It is an inherent right reserved for States to\nChinese JIL (2021)\nresort to force by its own decision after the enshrinement of a general prohibition of uses of force in the UN Charter.²¹³\n89. As evidenced by the controversies over anticipatory self-defence in the drafting processes of the Tallinn Rules, diverse concepts and practices regarding the preconditions for the commencement of self-defence and the limitations to the exercise of this right have been invoked and contested by States. Whether Article 51 of the UN Charter allows anticipatory or pre-emptive self-defence before an armed attack occurs has long been a major point of contention. The US, the UK, Israel and some other States have construed Article 51 in a permissible manner by referring to the Caroline doctrine under customary international law, based on which they have often resorted to force. The UNSC has condemned some of such practices; the International Court of Justice took the restrictive view in the judgments of the Corfu Channel case,²¹⁴ the Nicaragua case,²¹⁵ and other decisions afterwards.²¹⁶ The restrictive approach limits States' right to self-defence under Article 51 of the UN Charter to situations where an armed attack has already taken place, excluding anticipatory self-defence. From the perspective of the degree of compliance, the effectiveness of the general prohibition of use of force is questionable. But none of these States supporting permissive interpretations dares to bluntly admit the existence of a violation or defy this universally accepted rule, although they always use various factual and legal arguments to justify their breaches.\n90. In the same vein, it is not practically feasible to ensure effective observance of a norm prohibiting use of force in cyberspace, especially by these States that are frequent invokers of anticipatory self-defence. Therefore, what China and other SCO members seek is rather to influence the norm-formulation process at the UN that reflects how the international community of States characterizes a situation or act in question, e.g., as a violation of the proposed norm, and whether most States have a willingness to suppress such dubious acts. In the interim, China has not come up with a clear and concrete stance on how to develop a standard resembling Article 2(4) and Article 51 of the UN Charter in judging the legality and legitimacy of State behaviour concerning use of cyber force. More importantly, concluding new treaties for\n213 UN Charter, 1 UNTS XVI (24 October 1945), Arts. 2(4).\n214 Corfu Channel Case (UK v. Albania), Merits, ICJ Reports 1949, 4, 35.\n215 Military and Paramilitary Activities in and against Nicaragua (Nicaragua v. US), Merits, ICJ Reports 1986, 103, para.194.\n216 See Onuma Yasuaki, International Law in a Transcivilizational World (2017), 614-17.\nJiang, Decoding China's Perspectives on Cyber Warfare 305\nwarfare or a disarmament treaty would be more challenging than adapting existing law through interpretation.\n91. Cyber disarmament is more unrealistic in today's international political environment than the nonproliferation of nuclear weapons, especially in light of the recent backlashes against the Treaty on the Nonproliferation of Nuclear Weapons provoked by the Iran and North Korea nuclear crises. All nuclear-weapon States except China, which abstained, voted against a UNGA resolution proposing to convene the first UN conference aimed at achieving a legally binding ban on nuclear weapons.²¹⁷ On 22 January 2021, the Treaty on the Prohibition of Nuclear Weapons, the first multilateral agreement that bans nuclear weapons, entered into force. Although 85 States have signed and 50 of them have ratified this treaty, the non-participation of all nine States possessing nuclear weapons renders the efficacy of the treaty questionable.²¹⁸ Additionally, as manifested by Cuba's objection to an endorsement of the right to self-defence in the 2017 UN GGE report, the States that do not enjoy conventional military superiority over their adversaries may have asymmetric advantages in cyberspace, which they are reluctant to give up.²¹⁹ Therefore, a cyber disarmament treaty would lack the support of both major cyber powers and the rest of the weaker cyber-armed States.\n92. In the aftermath of the Snowden Disclosures in 2013 and the WikiLeaks disclosures lasting from mid-2016 to date, a rising trend of nationalism has taken place in many countries that used to stand in line with the US-EU camp, such as Brazil and Germany, pushing these countries to start thinking how to defend their \"data sovereignty\". The rise of cybersecurity nationalism has undermined international norm-making efforts, including trade negotiations between the EU and the US and the US attempts to promote norms of Internet freedom globally.²²⁰ There is no reason that cybersecurity discourse would stay intact.\n²¹⁷ Tariq Rauf, 2017: The Year in Which Nuclear Weapons Could be Banned?, Stockholm International Peace Research Institute Commentary (20 March 2017) (www.sipri.org/commentary/essay/2017/2017-year-which-nuclear-weapons-could-be-banned).\n²¹⁸ See generally, Treaty on the Prohibition of Nuclear Weapons (22 January 2021) (www.nti.org/learn/treaties-and-regimes/treaty-on-the-prohibition-of-nuclear-weapons/).\n²¹⁹ Arun M. Sukumar, The UN GGE Failed: Is International Law in Cyberspace Doomed as Well?, Lawfare (4 July 2017) (www.lawfareblog.com/un-gge-failed-international-law-cyberspace-doomed-well).\n²²⁰ Mueller, above n.25, 555.\nChinese JIL (2021)\n93. Given the unique features of cyber operations and the Internet, even a treaty in the style of the Treaty on the Nonproliferation of Nuclear Weapons would have little practical significance in deterring the abuse and misuse of force in cyberspace. The refrainment of most States, including the US, in most cyber tensions with other States, from resorting to the prevailing international legal framework in dealing with inter-State cyber relations, highlights the limitations of normative approaches in functioning as a general taboo for irresponsible activities in cyberspace by not only State but also private actors.\n94. Compared to conventional and nuclear weapons, the technical barriers to entry in cyber warfare are so low that non-State actors and countries that are conceivably weak by the standards of hard powers can play a significant role on par with powerful countries at low levels of cost. Cyberattacks can be conducted by any actor having an electronic device and connected to the Internet. The interconnectivity of the network enables any actor to stay geographically remote from where they commit cyberattacks. Simultaneously, unlike classic military operations that rely upon territorial linkages, this interconnectivity severely decreases the degree of State control over actors and activities. The life of a treaty, particularly a disarmament treaty, rests in its enforcement. The construction of a credible monitoring and enforcement mechanism would prove to be the utmost hurdle for a cyber disarmament treaty.\n95. Probably having realized the lack of feasibility and political will among States to negotiate a cyber disarmament treaty, China has softened, to some degree, its stance against the alleged militarization of cyberspace. In the most up-to-date white paper on China's military strategy issued in 2015, China plans to \"expedite the development of a cyber force, and enhance its capabilities of cyberspace situation awareness, cyber defence [...] so as to stem major cyber crises, ensure national network and information security, and maintain national security and social stability\". The ISCC further confirms that \"enhanced defence capability in cyberspace is an important part of China's endeavour to modernize its national defence and armed forces\", while restricting China's development of a cyber force to defensive capability.\n221 State Council Information Office, China's Military Strategy (May 2015), Chapter IV: Building and Development of China's Armed Forces (www.chinadaily.com.cn/china/2015-05/26/content_20820628_4.htm).\n222 ISCC, above n.17, Chapter III: Strategic Goals.\n223 Ibid., Chapter I: Opportunities and Challenges &amp; Chapter III: Strategic Goals.\nJiang, Decoding China's Perspectives on Cyber Warfare 307\n## IV.B. Sovereign control over the Internet vs non-intervention\n96. The changes in the global context of disarmament and China's position regarding use of force in the cyber context have rendered the proposed second objective of China more salient. The central bone of contention in the normative competitions between the SCO members and the Western powers rests upon whether information and data transmitted in cyberspace shall be made subject to the jurisdiction of the territorial State, although both sides have reached a consensus on the applicability of sovereignty as part of international law in cyberspace. At the core of this debate is how to draw the lines between the realms of domestic law and international law as consensual erosion of State sovereignty to be applied equally to all States.\n97. The US holds the view that, although sovereignty gives a State the right to control over cyber infrastructure and activities within its territory, the exercise of such jurisdiction by the territorial State, encompassing the use and access to the Internet, must comply with that State's obligations under applicable international law, particularly international human rights law. While noting that the freedom of expression may be restricted in situations such as the incitement of imminent terrorist violence, the US considers \"certain censorship and content control, including blocking websites simply because they contain content that criticizes a leader, a government policy, or an ideology, or because the content espouses particular religious beliefs\" as constituting State violations of international human rights law.²²⁴\n98. China likely views this reference to international human rights law as a pretext for Western attempts to conceptually undermine the scope of sovereign powers by narrowing the content of *domaine réservé* in the context of Internet governance. China claims for cyber sovereignty that includes not only cyber infrastructure within its territory but also its jurisdiction over data and the regulation and monitoring of the content of information flowing over cyberspace.²²⁵ Consciously aware that the scope of a State's internal matters and the international legal limitations to that State's exercise of sovereign power over internal matters evolve over time, China has consistently resisted non-reciprocal and non-voluntary restrictions on its exercise of sovereignty.\n²²⁴ Egan, above n.45, 15-17.\n²²⁵ See, e.g., National Security Law of the People's Republic of China (2015), art. 25; XI Jinping, Keynote Speech at the opening ceremony of the 2nd World Internet Conference (16 December 2015) (www.wuzhenwic.org/2015-12/16/c_47521.htm).\nChinese JIL (2021)\n99. From Beijing's perspective, the nature of the Tallinn Manual 2.0 as a product formulated under the domination of Western powers was not changed solely by the increased diversity in the composition of the International Group of Experts participating in the drafting process, because the newly-added matters reflect foremostly Western perspectives and concerns. The Tallinn Manual 2.0 does not touch upon the sovereignty of a State over potential data; it only mentions sovereign power over any cyber infrastructure located within States' territory and activities associated with that cyber infrastructure. Similar problems exist in the Tallinn Rules concerning jurisdiction, which overwhelmingly emphasize the limitations imposed by international human rights law to the exercise of sovereignty in cyberspace.²²⁶\n100. In the domestic sphere, China invokes cyber sovereignty to underpin its regulation over data and information in cyberspace. As shown in the SCO Agreement's wording of \"mass psychologic brainwashing to destabilize society and State, as well as to force the State to take decisions to the interest of an opposing party\", China is always wary of potential foreign interference. The propaganda and liaison roles played by online social networking servers, such as Facebook and Twitter, in the \"Arab Spring\" that led to social unrest, political turmoil and regime-changes in Northern African and Western Asian countries, and the exposure of the massive surveillance by the US National Security Agency in the PRISM program have strengthened the Chinese conviction of the need for Internet censorship to block and filter information in cyberspace that is harmful to China's social stability and national security.²²⁷ In the trend of the global revival of cyber sovereignty, China strengthens its sovereignty-based regulatory power by referring to similar censorship practices of other States, such as the US, Australia, Italy, Germany, France, the UK, and Korea that once held opposing views, regarding the information about terrorism, incitement to hate crimes, pornography, violence and other crimes involving the usage of the Internet.²²⁸\n101. In the international sphere, China has employed cyber sovereignty as a shield against some Western States' attempts to compel it to change the\n²²⁶ HUANG, above n.212.\n²²⁷ HUANG Zhixiong, Regulation of Cyber Information: A Component Implicitly Covered by Cyber Sovereignty, 3 Guojia Zhili [Nat'l Governance Wkly] (2016), 33-34.\n²²⁸ Xinlian, From the US to Australia: How States Regulate the Internet, China Daily (17 May 2016) (http://world.chinadaily.com.cn/2016-05/17/content_25321844.htm).\nJiang, Decoding China's Perspectives on Cyber Warfare 309\ncurrent model of Internet governance by either resorting to non-legal advocacy for Internet freedom or invoking relevant international law, especially the rules of international human rights law on the right to freedom of expression, association, and the media, and the right to access to information. Google's withdrawal from the Chinese market in 2010 was a representative example of the former means where a leading multinational company threatened the Chinese government for a policy change under the instructions of some Western countries.²²⁹ Additionally, the Chinese government has been alarmed by soft law norms applicable in peacetime that are proposed by some Western countries, such as relevant code of conduct on responsible State behaviour in cyberspace at the 2016-2017 UN GGE meetings. Such non-binding norms are intended to circumvent the advocacy of Russia and China to formulate new rules to regulate State behaviour regarding cybersecurity in the form of a treaty at the forum of the UN and may gradually harden into binding law.²³⁰\n102. This argument likely explains why Cuba, Russia and China refused to explicitly affirm the right to self-defence and the applicability of international humanitarian law in the cyber context in the 2017 UN GGE report, while having accepted the general applicability of existing *jus ad bellum* and *jus in bello* to cyberspace since the publication of the 2015 UN GGE consensus report. The crucial factor that prevented these States from reaching a consensus with the Western countries was the opposing camp's intention to introduce \"clear and direct statements on how international law applies to States' use of ICTs\"²³¹ in the UN GGE report, which threatened to restrict States' right to regulate the content of and access to information. The UN GGE report is a non-binding statement, but it may serve as proof of State practice and *opinio juris* in ascertaining whether certain international law applies to a participating State signing onto the consensus report and the extent to which the included law limits the endorsing State's right to regulate domestic affairs. Although these countries have recognized the applicability of LOAC to cyber operations during an armed conflict upon the adoption of the final UN GGE report, residual disagreements over how specific LOAC rules apply to ICT-related activities remain prominent between them and the Western countries.\n²²⁹ HUANG, above n.227, 34.\n²³⁰ HUANG Zhixiong, Norms of Responsible State Behavior in Cyberspace: Origin, Impact and Response, 1 Dangdai Faxue [Contemporary LR] (2019), 68-69.\n²³¹ Korzak, above n.70.\nChinese JIL (2021)\n103. The law governing the right to self-defence and means and methods of warfare is dominated by the practice of remarkably few established powers because the major ground of resorting to anticipatory self-defence and a large portion of LOAC is customary international law, which has been developed by these “specially affected” States to advance their interests.²³² For newly rising powers such as China, failing to meet the requirements of “persistent objector” before and after the birth of a rule at concern would not relieve their obligation to comply. A successful example where a contrary practice of a large number of weaker States makes a few powerful States switch from an established rule of customary international law to an emerging new rule is rare.²³³ It is extremely difficult for a militarily disadvantaged State that lacks field experience to replicate such a strategy in areas involving force.\n104. To prevent coercive erosions of its sovereignty, China’s strategy is to embed a firewall at the most representative and democratic lawmaking forum to obstruct the convenient transplantation of power disparity from the *jus ad bellum* and the *jus in bello* to the special regimes of international law that constitute cornerstones of an evolving global system of Internet governance. A treaty negotiated at a more egalitarian forum such as the UNGA would enable the Chinese perspectives to carry greater weight in forming international law among a large number of similarly disadvantaged countries. And lawmaking in the form of treaty allows a less advanced State such as China to pick and choose elastically from treaties and their provisions according to its goals.\nV. Conclusion\n105. To summarize, the above analyses suggest that behind China’s general and vague opposition to an explicit affirmation of the applicability of specific LOAC rules to cyberspace and the right of self-defence in cyberspace is China’s profound concern that doing so would acquiesce to the encroachment of its sovereignty and unlock Pandora’s box of coercive external interferences with its independence in determining the mode of domestic Internet governance and the path of development.\n106. Has China’s growing strength in Internet technology, military capabilities and digital economy driven it to pursue a more proactive and enterprising approach to reshaping international law governing the domain of cyber\n²³² Alan Boyle &amp; Christine Chinkin, The Making of International Law (2007), 28-29.\n²³³ Ibid., 29.\nJiang, Decoding China's Perspectives on Cyber Warfare 311\nwarfare so as to build up a competitive advantage against the established powers? At first glance, Beijing's long-term resistance to confirming the applicability of existing *jus ad bellum* and *jus in bello* to cyberspace before the adoption of the final UN GGE report, amid the exaggerated normative rivalry between the Russia-China Camp and the US-EU Camp, appeared to corroborate this argument. However, closer scrutiny reveals that, the conceptual generalization and ambiguity in China's resisting stance stems from the same premises underpinning the mainstream \"wait and see\" approach of most States towards utilizing international law as the primary means to regulate or justify their cyberoperations. Following the \"wait and see\" trend of State practice, China has agreed to the general applicability of the *jus ad bellum*, the *jus in bello*, and law on State responsibility for international wrongful acts, but still resists the applicability of some specific rules in cyberspace, e.g., the right to self-defence and some LOAC rules, to allow for flexibility in responding to cyber technology development in attribution and the evolvement of international law.\n107. Despite the recent developments in its cyber defensive capacity, China remains disadvantaged as a rising power with weaker military capacity and less normative influence. China's normative proposals, exemplified by the ICCIS, serves more as bargaining leverage to protect itself from being bound by the existing or emerging law supported by the established powers, but unfavourable to itself, and also to move the focus of international legal discourse from the paradigm of military responses to cyberattacks concentrated in the *jus ad bellum* and the *jus in bello* to that of international law governing State behaviour in peacetime. China's normative efforts are largely defensive, given that Beijing chooses to prioritize its interests in defending against possible use of force either triggered by an alleged cyberattack or carried out in the means of cyber operations, over its offensive interests in staying less constrained in the use of cyber force.\n108. Because of the special features of how existing *jus ad bellum* and *jus in bello* were made, the normative influence of China and its SCO allies is not sufficient, at this moment, to change the practice of the frequent users of force, to come up with a norm promising effective observance by these States, or to veto the formation of new law proposed by these States at concern. The return of sovereign control in cyberspace and the focus shift of international legal discourse result from a set of factors, e.g., the limitations of current technologies and existing law, with the normative efforts of the SCO members having contributed to this global trend.\nChinese JIL (2021)\n109. But these countries can still resist the imposition of non-consensual norms upon themselves in the domain of cyberspace, obstruct the codification of disfavoured norms, and influence how other States characterize and respond to a situation involving cyber operations. This is why the seemingly unfeasible idea of an international cyber disarmament treaty concluded under the framework of the UN remains on the table. The UNSC's monopoly of authorizing the use of force and the UNGA's feature as one of the most egalitarian forums for international lawmaking make the UN the favourable forum relied on by rising powers such as China to build resilience against other lawmaking processes where established powers play a greater role, e.g., the development of customary international law or soft law in less representative forums.",

    "© The Author(s) 2021. Published by Oxford University Press. All rights reserved.\ndoi:10.1093/chinesejil/jmab022\n\n# Decoding China’s Perspectives on Cyber Warfare\n\nChaoyi Jiang*\n\n## Abstract\n\nThis article examines China’s concerns over the adequacy of existing *jus ad bellum* and *jus in bello* to address cyber warfare, particularly the rules on cyberattacks governed by the *jus in bello*, dual-use infrastructure and war-sustaining facilities, the proportionality of cyberattacks against key infrastructures and the targetability of certain categories of civilians. This article argues that China’s resistance to applying some rules of the *jus in bello* to cyberspace is in line with the “wait and see” approach of most States. But there are two distinctive objectives behind this generalized stance: one is to protect its domestic regulatory power over cyberspace from being bound by disfavoured emerging and existing law, and the other is to build up consensus for a treaty regulating uses of cyber force under the United Nations framework.\n\n## I. Introduction\n\n1. International law is a generator and a product of the changing global order. To what extent and how the rise of a new great power will influence international law largely hinges upon the interaction between the rising power and the established powers that have dominated international legal discourse for centuries. The perspectives of China and the established powers differ substantially on many issues, especially those relating to sovereign equality, non-intervention and national security. This can be exemplified by China's perspectives on many issues of cyber warfare in the normative rivalry between the United States (US)-European Union (EU) Camp and the Russia-China Camp, which are competing to influence the making of international law, as well as other countries' domestic policies.²\n\n2. Notably, China’s growing strength in Internet technology, military capabilities and the digital economy, especially following the 2008 global financial crisis, did not initially bolster its assertiveness in the international lawmaking procedures that seek to identify existing law or generate new law applicable to State behaviour in cyberspace. China was a low-key participant at the early stages of the UN Group of Government Experts on the Developments in the Field of Information and Telecommunications in the Context of Security (“UN GGE”). Its behaviour was found to be passive and frequently concurring with Russia’s stance. The Chinese representatives attending earlier UN GGE meetings were technical officers from the Ministry of Communication rather than diplomats from the Ministry of Foreign affairs (MOFA).⁹ But later, China proved to be willing to act more actively and assertively when it was singled out and its fundamental domestic interests were threatened by the disfavoured norms proposed by the established powers.\n\n4. In reaction to these Western normative attempts, China has transformed from a low-profile, passive team player under the Russian leadership to a proactive actor that had formed its own agenda. Higher-level officials from the MOFA with expertise in cyber governance started to represent China in diplomatic activities.¹⁰ The ICCIS was developed to counter-balance the diplomatic momentum generated by a series of US activities, including Clinton’s speeches on freedom in cyberspace between 2010-2012, the 2011 International Strategy for Cyberspace and the 2011 Strategy for Operating in Cyberspace. Beijing viewed these activities as attempting to militarize cyberspace and maintain the dominance of the US in cyber governance by interfering in other States’ sovereign right to regulate cyberspace.¹¹\n\n5. In 2011, the first edition of the ICCIS was submitted two months before the London Conference, a United Kingdom (UK)-sponsored attempt in line with those of the US and their allies. The ICCIS called on States “not to use information and communications technologies (ICTs), including networks, to carry out hostile activities or acts of aggression, pose threats to international peace and security or proliferate information weapons or related technologies”, called for “peaceful settlements of international disputes and improvements in international cooperation in the field of information security”, and emphasized “the important role of the UN in formulating international norms”.¹² An updated edition of the ICCIS with similar wording was circulated at the UNGA in 2015,¹³ possibly intended to gather wider support in the aftermath of the Snowden Disclosures that harmed the US’s credibility in its continuous diplomatic attempts.\n\n6. The second World Internet Conference in 2015 marked the emergence of China’s own vision of global Internet governance that advocates both respect for sovereignty in cyberspace and international cooperation to “jointly build a community of shared future in cyberspace”. The vision of “Jointly Build a Community with a Shared Future in Cyberspace” was further elaborated by the Organizing Committee of the World Internet Conference in 2019. It urged countries to oppose hostile activities, acts of aggression, cyberattacks, large-scale surveillance operations, unfounded accusations of cyberattacks against other countries and attempts to politicize cybersecurity issues; prevent arms race and military conflict in cyberspace; and remain committed to resolving disputes by peaceful means.¹⁵ In 2020, the Initiative on Jointly Building a Community with a Shared Future in Cyberspace was released amid the COVID-19 pandemic that underpinned the urgency of “achieving shared development, ensuring common security, realizing joint governance, and enjoying benefits”. This document emphasized the need to “exert the roles of the UN Open-ended Working Group (OEWG) and the UN GGE, and support formulating codes, norms and principles of responsible State conduct in cyberspace that are acceptable to all parties under the UN framework”.¹⁶\n\n8. To assess the implications of China’s rise for the evolution of international law governing the use of force by States in cyberspace, this paper studies the normative initiatives and strategies employed by China in identifying rules of existing law and creating new law applicable to cyber warfare. In light of China’s sovereignty-centric approach to cyber governance, Part II introduces the general stance of China on the adequacy of existing *jus ad bellum* and *jus in bello* to address cyber warfare. China's general stance on applicable law governing cyber warfare\n\n## II.A. China's sovereignty-centric approach to cyber governance\n\n9. On 1 March 2017, the MOFA and the Cyberspace Administration jointly issued the first international cyber policy paper of China—the International Strategy of Cooperation on Cyberspace (ISCC)—to comprehensively introduce and explain Beijing's policy and position on issues of cyber-related international affairs.¹⁷ At his daily press briefing following the release, the UN Secretary-General Spokesman Stéphane Dujarric described the ISCC as “a very important report” and suggested that “China has a big role to play” in global cyber governance.¹⁸ The linchpin of China’s cyber diplomacy is the idea of cyber sovereignty, around which China formulates its cybersecurity policies towards three primary objectives. The first is to protect its critical information infrastructure, cyber sovereignty, national security and domestic stability from threats posed by digital power disparity among countries, cybercrimes and cyber terrorism, and external interference with China’s internal\n\n¹⁷ Statement by Ambassador FU Cong in the Assembly Meeting of the UN Conference on Disarmament on International Strategy of Cooperation on Cyberspace (9 March 2017) (www.china-un.ch/eng/hom/t1444602.htm); also MOFA and the Cyberspace Administration, International Strategy of Cooperation on Cyberspace (1 March 2017) (www.fmprc.gov.cn/mfa_eng/wjb_663304/zzjg_663340/jks_665232/kjlc_665236/qtwt_665250/t1442390.shtml) [hereinafter “ISCC”].\n\n¹⁸ Daily Press Briefing by the Office of the Spokesperson for the Secretary-General (2 March 2017) (www.un.org/press/en/2017/db170302.doc.htm).",

The appeal for cyber sovereignty by China and other like-minded countries takes place at a time when governments' sovereign power over cyberspace is in decline for many reasons, including but not limited to the privatization of cyberspace, the rise of non-State actors and the digital gap between the developed and developing countries. As evidenced by the first and second editions of the Tallinn Manual providing that \"a State may exercise control over cyber infrastructure and activity within its sovereign territory\",²¹ sovereignty in cyberspace is not a revisionist idea by itself. According to the International Group of Experts who drafted the Tallinn Manual 2.0, this premise, which was confirmed by the 2013 Report of the UN GGE,²² is now \"relatively well accepted by the international community\".²³ The US and its allies have held out to this idea in order to sustain the current platform governed by multi-stakeholders under their control.²⁴\n\n19 ISCC, above n.17, Chapter I: Opportunities and Challenges, Chapter III: Strategic Goals.\n20 Ibid., Chapter II: The Principle of Sovereignty.\n21 Michael Schmitt (general ed.), Tallinn Manual on the International Law Applicable to Cyber Warfare (2013), Rule 1 [hereinafter \"Tallinn Manual\"]; also Michael Schmitt (general ed.) &amp; Liis Vihul (managing ed.), Tallinn Manual 2.0 on The International Law Applicable to Cyber Operations (2017), Rule 1 [hereinafter \"Tallinn Manual 2.0\"].\n22 Report of the UN Group of Governmental Experts on Developments in the Field of Information and Telecommunications in the Context of International Security, UN Doc. It is noteworthy that, among all the technical communities developing the \"law\" of the Internet and managing the global distribution of Internet resources in terms of naming and addresses,²⁵ the ISCC exclusively named the Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers (ICANN) and urged the international community to \"make [ICANN] a truly independent international institution, increase its representations and ensure greater openness and transparency in its decision-making and operation\".²⁶ ICANN has been a highly politicalized organization. It is a Californian corporation created by a 1998 Memorandum of Understanding with the US Department of Commerce to transfer the power to manage and oversee the domain name system (DNS) coordination from the US government to the global community. This agreement was supposed to terminate on 30 September 2000, while subject to further amendments.²⁷ The US government did not end its supervision until October 2016,²⁸ mainly in response to the calling of major Internet technical organizations for freeing ICANN from unilateral oversight of the US as a backlash from the Snowden Disclosures.²⁹ Yet, it is early to tell whether the globalization of ICANN can be genuinely realized, given that most of its key infrastructures remain in the US territory. Aside from open participation, ICANN is not subject to any classic form of internal accountability that commonly exists in private corporations and nonprofit organizations, such as direct accountability mechanisms based on membership or shareholders in the Regional Internet Registries and the open, bottom-up, consensus-based standardization process of the Internet Engineering Task Force.³⁶ Although ICANN self-identifies as championing the bottom-up, consensus-driven, multi-stakeholder model of governance, its policy-making processes manifest a top-down hierarchy, in which issues raised from the grassroots level end up as policy recommendations to be voted at the Board of Directors.³⁷ The Board has “near-absolute” power over the bylaws governing the entirety of processes and can “untrammeled[ly]” decide whether to accept these recommendations in the absence of any binding forms of appeal or review. In its efforts to achieve these objectives, Beijing has been increasingly active in various multilateral lawmaking forums, particularly major UN platforms such as the UNGA, UN GGE, the UN Expert Group on Combating Cybercrime and International Telecommunication Union. For example, along with the promotion of the concepts of cyber sovereignty and “Jointly Build a Community with a Shared Future in Cyberspace” at the World Internet Conference, a State-run annual international forum focusing on the development, use and governance of the Internet, underlying elements of these concepts have also been advocated in China’s Position Paper at the UNGA since 2014 to maintain the momentum and build consensus. These elements include: (1) peaceful use of cyberspace for economic and social development; (2) objection to cyber war and arms race; (3) the development of an international code of conduct for cyberspace under the UN framework that is acceptable to all, such as the two versions of the ICCIS; (4) strengthened international cooperation to combat cybercrimes such as cyber terrorism; and (5) objection to any country’s attempt to overstretch the concept of national security to restrict ICT development and cooperation among other countries or to interfere in other countries’ internal affairs.⁵⁰\n\n19. These comprehensive and issue-specific normative initiatives unfold the usage of issue linkage under China's overall scheme of the legal framework governing cyberspace, under which the issues of the development and use of the Internet, cyber and data security, cybercrimes, cyber governance and cyber warfare that transcend different fields of international law are simultaneously placed on the agenda of international lawmaking to keep this bundle of issues at the frontline.\n\n20. In light of the digital divide between the developed and developing countries and the inequitable order of the existing international legal system, China has been aligning normative efforts at regional and South-South forums such as the BRICS, Shanghai Cooperation Organization (SCO), the Asian-African Legal Consultative Organization (AALCO), the ASEAN Regional Forum, China-Arab States Cooperation Forum, Forum of China and the Community of Latin American and Caribbean States in support of lawmaking activities at the UN.⁵³ The progress China has made in enhancing agenda-shaping and coalition-building capacities can be exemplified by the agenda item of \"International Law in Cyberspace\" proposed by China for the 53rd Annual Session of the AALCO⁵⁴ and the data security cooperation initiative signed between the Arab League and China.⁵⁵\n\n21. Meanwhile, bilateral normative discourses between China and other major powers are ongoing, aiming to figure out common interests and build up consensus for future international lawmaking.     "Chinese JIL (2021)\n\nnoticeable landmark is an agreement reached by the US and China in 2015 over mutual refrain from knowingly conducting or supporting cyber-enabled theft of intellectual property and further efforts in identifying and promoting appropriate norms of State behaviour in cyberspace.57 The first US-China Law Enforcement and Cybersecurity Dialogue in 2017 once signalled a possibility for greater cooperation.58 However, since 2018, the deterioration of these countries' bilateral relations has stagnated confidence-building measures towards further coordination and cooperation.\n\n22. In the context of cyber warfare, the US position is that existing LOAC, including its principles of distinction, necessity, and proportionality, applies in cyberspace.59 By contrast, China, Russia, and other SCO members have not agreed to the US stance and played a rival role. In the 2013 Report of the UN GGE, China and Russia managed to exclude any reference to the applicability of international humanitarian law principles in cyberspace, despite the controversial affirmation of the applicability of \"international law\" and the UN Charter.60 The 2015 UN GGE Report explicitly \"notes\" the possible applicability of \"the established international legal principles, including, where applicable, the principles of humanity, necessity, proportionality and distinction\", while cautiously avoiding making any reference to international humanitarian law.61 The wording of this text fails to clarify whether the UN GGE reached a consensus on the applicability of these LOAC principles to cyber activities or merely noted their existence.     "Chinese JIL (2021)\n\naccepted the applicability of LOAC to cyberspace during an armed conflict while leaving controversial issues of how specific LOAC rules apply to the use of ICTs for further discussions, such as whether cyber-only exchanges can trigger an armed conflict, the scope of cyberattacks regulated by LOAC, the targetability of certain objects in the ICT context, etc.\n\n## II.C. Possible explanations for China’s opposition\n\n28. China’s stance on the applicability of LOAC to cyberspace is still evolving with the dynamic international environment, partly explaining why Beijing has refrained from specifying rationales for its resistance to some LOAC rules and how they govern ICT-related activities. Although limited in number, several statements made by Chinese officials on international occasions shed light on this question.\n\n29. At the 2013 Seoul Conference on Cyberspace, HUANG Huikang, then Legal Adviser of the MOFA, underlined the overemphasis on “making exceptions for cyber warfare or self-defence, while the non-use of force principle has been marginalized” and “the risk of sliding towards the militarization of cyberspace”.78 At the 6th US-China Internet Industry Forum, the Chinese delegation further pointed to the numerous “ambiguities and gaps in existing international law” regarding methods and means of cyber warfare, arguing for the incompetence of existing norms to address new sophisticated problems stemming from ICT development.79\n\n30. At the 7th US-China Internet Industry Forum in 2015, MA Xinmin, then Deputy Director-General of the Department of Treaty and Law of the MOFA, acknowledged that in principle, existing international law, including “the purposes and principles of the [UN] Charter, such as *jus ad bellum* rule of non-use of force except in self-defence or under UN Security Council’s (SC) authorization [...] and international humanitarian law among others shall be directly applicable to cyberspace.”80 However, he emphasized that applying existing LOAC rules to cyber warfare should be conducted “with great caution”, because of the lack of State practice on cyber warfare\n\n78 MOFA, Working Together to Build a Harmonious and Progressive International Cyberspace Order, Remarks by Dr HUANG Huikang at the Seoul Conference on Cyberspace (17 October 2013), (www.fmprc.gov.cn/ce/cgmb/chn/wjbxw/P020131021538048406901.doc).\n\n79 Statement by the Chinese Delegation at the 6th US-China Internet Industrial Forum, 2013 Chinese YIL, 666-67.\n\n80 MA, above n.46.",
    "Jiang, Decoding China's Perspectives on Cyber Warfare 275\n\nand the peculiarities of cyberspace, including many legal and technical issues, e.g., identification, tracing and establishment of State responsibility, that are yet to be solved for the application of LOAC to cyberspace.⁸¹ MA also warned of the threats of “aggravating cyberspace militarization and arms race” and the corresponding “pushing for the application of laws of war in that scenario”. He argued that the viewpoints of some States and scholars reflected in the Tallinn Manual illustrate the “military paradigm” of “response to cyberattacks that disregards the principle of non-use of force in international law but over-emphasizes such exceptions as the right to self-defence”, which “clearly does not conform to the international reality and actual needs”.⁸²\n\n31. In a subsequent paper, MA elaborated that the prevailing challenges States need to address are threats to cybersecurity in times of peace, most of which either are launched by non-State actors and fall under the scope of domestic law, or do not qualify as “use of force” or “armed attacks” governed by international law that apply in times of war but constitute international wrongful acts regulated by the law on State responsibility. In the latter situations, the victim State should first resort to peaceful means such as legal countermeasures or UNSC sanctions, rather than use of force.     "Jiang, Decoding China's Perspectives on Cyber Warfare 277\n\nManual independent International Group of Experts.⁹⁰ Critiques of Chinese scholars on the Tallinn Manual concentrate on its *jus ad bellum* part, particularly section 2, “the use of force”. Specifically, many scholars consider that the Tallinn Manual’s threshold on what cyber operations constitute the use of force within the meaning of Article 2(4) of the UN Charter is too low. In their view, the majority of the selected International Group of Experts, who are supporters of Michael Schmitt’s “scale and effects” approach,⁹¹ artificially create some situations that have never taken place to prove that cyberattacks can result in analogous scale and effects of kinetic and non-kinetic forces. A direct transplantation of existing *jus ad bellum* to cyberspace arguably goes beyond the current practice of most States.⁹² Another major concern of Chinese scholars is that, rather than regulating the means and methods of cyber warfare, the sponsors of the Tallinn Manual intend to seek legal bases to initiate cyber or even kinetic wars. Accordingly, the Tallinn Manual extensively interprets a country’s right of self-defence against non-State actors and anticipatory self-defence against an imminent threat of cyber operations. They hence argue for a higher bar than the Tallinn Manual requirements for invoking the right of self-defence within the meaning of Article 51 of the UN Charter.⁹³\n\n35. Given the unique features of cyber operations, it can be observed that China has been hesitant about applying specific LOAC rules to the cyber context. What are the “ambiguities and gaps in existing international law” that prevent China from embracing LOAC and the Tallinn Manual at present?     "Chinese JIL (2021)\n\nFirst, the existence of an armed conflict permits the use of lethal force based solely on the status of an individual or object. Some Chinese scholars argue that cyberattacks, in light of the latest level of technology, are not controllable so as to constrain their effects within the boundaries of military objects and therefore indiscriminate in nature.95 The 2007 nation-wide denial-of-service attacks sweeping over Estonian Internet infrastructure, including the websites and systems of its Parliament, banks, ministries and media, was cited as a typical example of indiscriminate cyberattack,96 although whether there was an armed conflict and whether such activities amounted to attacks within the meaning of LOAC is disputable.
