    "Chinese JIL (2021)\n\narmed force that triggers the application of LOAC, is hinted by the Agreement between the Governments of the Member States of the Shanghai Cooperation Organization on Cooperation in the Field of International Information Security (“SCO Agreement”). It is a separate question under the jus in bello, without prejudice to the question of “use of force” within the meaning of Article 2(4) of the UN Charter. Annex 1 to this Agreement defines “information war” as:\n\nconfrontation between two or more states in the information space aimed at damaging information systems, processes and resources, critical and other structures, undermining political, economic and social systems, mass psychologic brainwashing to destabilize society and state, as well as to force the state to taking decisions in the interest of an opposing party[.].¹⁰⁴\n\nAlthough it remains unsettled whether and when an armed conflict, international or non-international, can commence based on a single cyber exchange, the SCO Agreement’s definition of war clearly expands the traditional meaning of armed conflict caused by conventional force under LOAC. Assuming that the term “war” in Annex 1 is not utilized as rhetoric, but rather as the reference of “armed conflict” within the meaning of LOAC, we may tentatively argue that the SCO members consider the existing LOAC’s scope of regulation as underinclusive because it fails to include the cyber actions that can generate political, economic, social and even psychological consequences into the realm of LOAC.\n\n## III. Examining China’s perspectives on specific rules of LOAC\n\n36. This part examines the legal or practical grounds supporting China’s views on the four mentioned issues of LOAC. In doing so, this part presents the general contour of various opinions on specific topics, encompassing State practice, positions of the International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC), and applicable Tallinn rules. Relevant treaty provisions and judgments of international judicial bodies will be referred to, if available.\n\n¹⁰⁴ Annex 1 to the Agreement between the Governments of the Member States of the Shanghai Cooperation Organization on Cooperation in the Field of International Information Security (16 June 2009), List of Basic Terms in the Field of International Information Security (http://cn.io.gov.mo/Legis/International/record/1280.aspx) (Chinese only) and (https://ccdcoe.org/uploads/2018/10/SCO-090616-IISAgreement.pdf) (non-official English translation).",
    "Jiang, Decoding China's Perspectives on Cyber Warfare 281\n\n## III.A. Cyberattacks regulated by LOAC\n\n37. Common Article 2 to the Geneva Conventions of 1949 defines an international armed conflict as any “declared war or any other armed conflict which may arise two or more States”, regardless of whether any of them recognizes the state of war. In *Tadić*, the International Criminal Tribunal for the Former Yugoslavia found “an armed conflict exists whenever there is a resort to armed force between States or protracted armed violence between governmental authorities and organized armed groups or between such groups within a State.”¹⁰⁵ Undoubtedly, cyberattacks accompanying any kinetic use of force fall under the sphere of LOAC. As with cyber warfare, the pertinent question is whether a single cyber exchange in the absence of any conventional use of force can trigger an international armed conflict by itself.\n\n38. The notion “resort to armed force” is not defined under LOAC and is easily confused with the usage of “use of force” under the *jus ad bellum*. Nevertheless, the different objects and purposes of these two regimes entail distinct legal tests of “force”. The *jus ad bellum* specifically regulates inter-State relations and States’ lawful use of force, seeking to maintain peaceful relations among nations by setting up strict conditions for invoking forceful measures, “when States may move beyond non-forceful measures such as diplomacy, economic sanctions, and countermeasures”.¹⁰⁶ By contrast, the *jus in bello* regulates the behaviour of parties to an armed conflict, and its object and purpose are to protect the military and civilian victims of war by prohibiting the harms caused by armed attacks during a conflict that are either unnecessary to effectively accomplish legitimate military objectives or excessive in relation to them.¹⁰⁷ The *jus in bello* does not govern whether the use of force is legitimate under the *jus ad bellum* but imposes restrictions on methods and means of warfare.\n\n39. Despite the absence of a treaty definition of the notion “armed forces” under LOAC, Article 49(1) of the 1977 Additional Protocol I to the Geneva\n\n---\n\n¹⁰⁵ Prosecutor v. Tadić, ICTY Appeals Chamber, Decision on the Defence Motion for Interlocutory Appeal on Jurisdiction (2 October 1995), Case No. IT-94-1-A, para.70.\n\n¹⁰⁶ Michael Schmitt, “Attack” as a Term of Art in International Law: The Cyber Operations Context, in: Christine Czosseck, Rain Ottis &amp; Katharina Ziolkowski (eds.), Proceedings of the 4th International Conference on Cyber Conflict (2012), 284.\n\n¹⁰⁷ Cordula Droege, Get off My Cloud: Cyber Warfare, International Humanitarian Law, and the Protection of Civilians, 94 IR Red Cross (2012), 545.",
    "Chinese JIL (2021)\n\nConventions defines “attack” within the meaning of LOAC as “acts of violence against the adversary, whether in offence or defence”.¹⁰⁸ By concentrating on the term “violence”, Article 49(1) provides a feasible way to access cyberattacks by analogy to the physical violent effects caused by kinetic attacks. The threshold concept of “attack” is selected in light of LOAC’s object and purpose, since only acts that qualify as attacks would be subject to many of its core prohibitions and restrictions. Only qualified attacks would trigger a wide range of legal protections for the civilian population and objects under LOAC. In most cases, an unqualified act beyond the realm of LOAC would fall under the domain of domestic and international human rights law. So far, there appears to be a consensus that as long as a cyber operation attributable to a State has the equivalent effects of kinetic forces, such as death, physical injury to persons, or damages to objects, it would trigger an international armed conflict.¹⁰⁹ Similarly, Rule 30 of the Tallinn Manual suggests that the “armed force” criterion is fulfilled when a cyber operation is reasonably expected to cause injury or death to person or damage or destruction to objects.¹¹⁰ A majority of the independent experts participating in the Tallinn Manual project favour including “loss of functionality” in the definition of damages, although there are various shades of opinions among them.¹¹¹\n\n40. The ICRC Commentary states that the term “attack” means “combat action”, without further elaboration.¹¹² A paper written by the Head of the ICRC’s Operational Law indicates that the ICRC considers the consequence-based approach as “insufficient to capture the whole range of possible effects of cyber operations and the damage that they can cause, which will not\n\n108 Additional Protocol I, above n. 100, Art. 49(1).\n109 Nils Melzer, Cyberwarfare and International Law, UN Institute for Disarmament Research Publications (2011), 24 (https://unidir.org/files/publications/pdfs/cyberwarfare-and-international-law-382.pdf); Michael Schmitt, Classification of Cyber Conflict, 17 JCSL (2012), 251, n.25; Heather Harrison Dinniss, Cyber Warfare and the Laws of War (2012), 131; Droege, above n.107, 546; Knut Dörmann, Applicability of the Additional Protocols to Computer Network Attacks, ICRC Resource Centre (19 November 2004), 3 (www.icrc.org/en/doc/resources/documents/misc/68lg92.htm).\n110 Tallinn Manual, above n.21, Rule 30, 106.\n111 Ibid., 108-09.\n112 Yves Sandoz, Christophe Swinarski &amp; Bruno Zimmermann (eds.), Commentary on the Additional Protocols of 8 June 1977 to the Geneva Conventions of 12 August 1949 (1987), para.1880.",
    "Jiang, Decoding China's Perspectives on Cyber Warfare 283\n\nnecessarily resemble the physical effects of traditional weapons\".¹¹³ Given adequate consideration to the object and purpose of LOAC and the concerns of a gap in protection, especially the protection of civilians from the effects of war, that paper seems to endorse the \"loss of functionality\" approach adopted by the majority view of the Tallinn Manual. Based on this approach, whether a cyber operation amounts to an attack depends on whether it causes the target to lose function, even if the target is not physically damaged.¹¹⁴\n\n41. States may support the dysfunction approach since cyber operations would be more frequently resorted, not to physically destroy or damage objects, which can be accomplished by using kinetic force, but rather to incapacitate or disrupt the normal functioning of a vital military or dual-use infrastructure.¹¹⁵ For instance, an electrical grid or water supply system might be shut down, and a country's banking or stock-trading system could be manipulated, both without any physical damage. As is demonstrated by the 2007 Estonian denial-of-service attacks, for certain civilian populations, the potential hardship arising from such dysfunction could be far more extensive or severe than the physical destruction of a particular building. Such effects might not be comparable to those caused by physical violence, but they are \"precisely the kind of severe consequences from which [LOAC] seeks to protect the civilian population\".¹¹⁶\n\n42. According to the dysfunction approach, cyberattacks against military or dual-use infrastructure, such as paralyzing information systems, altering or deleting processes and resources, are attacks that can trigger the application of LOAC, while applying the consequence-based approach would lead to a contrary conclusion. The applicable LOAC rule maintains that cyberattacks resulting in no physical damage are lawful.¹¹⁷ The US-EU camp intends to stay with the existing rule and has codified it in the Tallinn Manual. Although international law evolves to reflect the changing values developed by the international community, most States remain silent on this issue. Whether LOAC should expand its established interpretation of attacks depends on future State practice.\n\n¹¹³ Droege, above n.107, 546.\n¹¹⁴ Ibid., 546-47.\n¹¹⁵ Ibid.\n¹¹⁶ Ibid., 549.\n¹¹⁷ Schmitt, above n.106, 291.",
    "Chinese JIL (2021)\n\n43. Part of the SCO Agreement defines war as the “confrontation between two or more States in the information space aimed at damaging information systems, processes, and resources, critical and other structures”. Under this part of the definition, those confrontations that happen without any physical damages would not qualify as attacks and therefore be lawful under LOAC. The remaining part, namely, inter-State confrontations in cyberspace aimed at “undermining political, economic, and social systems, mass psychologic brainwashing to destabilize society and State, as well as to force the State to [take] decisions in the interest of an opposing party”, is unlikely to fall into the scope of attacks under LOAC either.\n\n44. On Article 49 of Additional Protocol I, the *Bothe, Partsch and Solf Commentary* underlines that attacks refer to “those aspects of military operations that most directly affect the safety of the civilian population and the integrity of civilian objects”.¹¹⁸ It would be difficult to assert that political, economic, social, or even psychological effects of cyber operations could be deemed most directly affecting the personal safety of civilians or the physical integrity of civilian objects. Dissemination of propaganda, espionage, embargoes or other non-physical means of psychological or economic warfare does not fall under the concept of attack in LOAC.¹¹⁹\n\n45. LOAC endeavours to regulate methods and means of war and the treatments of different groups. Under LOAC, a State wants to protect its civilian population and objects, and at the same time, be able to use lethal force against the belligerent party once an armed conflict commences. An overinclusive definition of “attack” will subject the civilian population to catastrophic consequences that would have been avoided by applying the present definition with a high threshold. Such consideration partly explains why most States remain silent in the face of cyberattacks.¹²⁰\n\n46. The SCO Agreement’s definition of war demonstrates the six countries’ concerns of adverse impacts by acts that do not qualify as attacks and coincides with Russia’s proposal for non-proliferation of information weapons. But, unlike biological and chemical weapons, the usage of so-called information weapons does not necessarily lead to unnecessary suffering of humans\n\n¹¹⁸ Michael Bothe, Karl Josef Partsch &amp; Waldemar A. Solf, New Rules for Victims of Armed Conflicts: Commentary on the Two 1977 Protocols Additional to the Geneva Conventions of 1949 (1982), 325.\n\n¹¹⁹ Ibid., 289.\n\n¹²⁰ See, e.g., Gary Brown, Why Iran didn’t admit Stuxnet was an attack, 63 Joint Force Quarterly (2011), 71.",
    "Jiang, Decoding China's Perspectives on Cyber Warfare 285\n\nand might even reduce physical harm compared to the usage of conventional forces regarding the accomplishment of the same military objective. This feature of information weapons makes them not a proper subject matter for a total (or partial) ban. By their features and consequences, unqualified cyberattacks are more suitable to be regulated by regimes other than LOAC for the time being. As demonstrated by the final UN GGE report, leading SCO members, including China, Russia, and Kazakhstan, no longer dispute the applicability of LOAC to cyber operations during an armed conflict, although controversies over, for example, the qualification of single cyber exchange as attacks under the meaning of LOAC, remain unsettled. Hence, the SCO members may continue to advance the broad interpretation of “attack” to build up consensus for new norms while resisting the application of the existing LOAC rules on the threshold of armed attacks.\n\n## III.B. Dual-use infrastructure and war-sustaining facilities\n\n47. As a “cardinal principle”¹²¹ of LOAC, the principle of distinction requires that a distinction be made between military and civilian persons and objects and prohibits attacks against civilians and civilian objects in an armed conflict. Article 52(1) of Additional Protocol I defines “civilian objects” in a negative manner as “all objects which are not military objectives”.¹²² Military objectives are those “by their nature, location, purpose or use make an effective contribution to military action and whose total or partial destruction, capture or neutralization, in the circumstances ruling at the time, offers a definite military advantage”.¹²³ According to Rule 39 of the Tallinn Manual, an object cannot be civilian and military simultaneously; its status is either one or the other.¹²⁴ Therefore, the entire dual-use object becomes a military objective from the moment it is used for military action, even if its military use is only “marginal” compared to its civilian use. Such observation represents today’s prevailing view on the qualification of dual-use objects as targetable military objectives.¹²⁵\n\n¹²¹ Legality of the Threat or Use of Nuclear Weapons, Advisory Opinion, ICJ Reports 1996, 257, para.78.\n¹²² Additional Protocol I, above n. 100, Art. 52(1).\n¹²³ Ibid., Art. 52(2).\n¹²⁴ Tallinn Manual, above n.21, Rule 39 and its Commentary, para.1.\n¹²⁵ See Droege, above n.107, 562; Michael Schmitt, The Law of Cyber Targeting, Tallinn Paper No.7 (2015), 11.",
    "Chinese JIL (2021)\n\n48. From the perspective of civilian protection, the “potentially non-lethal nature of cyberweapons”¹²⁶ draws concerns over an “expanded target list”¹²⁷ and an obscured assessment of the legality of an attack. In a world where a large part of civilian infrastructure and services are highly reliant on international cyber infrastructure, including the Internet, servers, routers, cables, satellites, and computers, the danger of loss of function, partial damage or complete destruction is evident. For example, approximately 98% of US government communications use civilian-owned and civilian-operated networks.¹²⁸ Under LOAC, belligerent parties can easily target cyber infrastructure as military objectives because mere containing, storing, or transmitting a tiny percentage of military data would render the entire infrastructure a legitimate target.\n\n49. Several scenarios of consequences of attacks against dual-use cyber infrastructure entail humanitarian concerns for civilian protection. The past decade witnessed the increasing use of cloud computing, the users of which are usually unaware of which server their data is stored on and whether military data is stored on the same server. Cyberspace is an artificial battlefield, where, unlike natural theatres of war, such as land or airspace, travelling military data or weapons (e.g., malware, botnet, or malicious codes) can make not only itself a legitimate target but also the transmitting infrastructure a military objective. It can be a computer system, a communication network, a server or router, a major cable, a satellite, or in the worst case, the entire Internet network system.¹²⁹\n\n50. The Tallinn Manual provides that “the circumstances under which the Internet in its entirety could be attacked [are] so highly unlikely as to render the possibility purely theoretical at the present time”, and that “virtually any attack against the Internet would have to be limited to certain discrete segments thereof”.¹³⁰ Nevertheless, it also acknowledges that “it may be impossible to know over which part of the network military transmissions, as distinct\n\n126 Jeffrey T. G. Kelsey, Hacking into International Humanitarian Law: The Principle of Distinction and Neutrality in the Age of Cyber Warfare, 106 Michigan LR (2007-2008), 1439.\n\n127 Eric Talbot Jensen, Unexpected Consequences from Knock-on Effects: A Different Standard from Computer Network Operations, 18 Am U ILR (2003), 1149.\n\n128 Eric Talbot Jensen, Cyber Warfare and Precautions against The Effects of Attacks, 88 Texas LR (2010), 1534.\n\n129 See, generally, Droege, above n.107, 562-65.\n\n130 Tallinn Manual, above n.21, Rule 39 and its Commentary, para.5.",
    "Jiang, Decoding China's Perspectives on Cyber Warfare 287\n\nfrom civilian ones, will pass. In such cases, the entire network (or at least those aspects in which transmission is reasonably likely) qualifies as a military objective.”¹³¹\n\n51. In the physical world, the irrelevance of dual-use objects’ civilian part regarding the principle of distinction is no longer in dispute. In cyberspace, the broad interpretation might lead to extreme situations where nothing civilian remains. More importantly, being a military objective will incur not only attacks in cyberspace but also fatal kinetic attacks. As a result, the fundamental rule that civilian population and objects enjoy general protection against dangers arising from military operations becomes an empty shell, leaving such situations only subject to protection under the principles of proportionality and precaution.\n\n52. Almost all States and legal commentators agree that the element of “make[s] an effective contribution to military action” in Article 52(2) of Additional Protocol I includes a contribution towards “war-fighting” or “war-supporting” capabilities of the belligerent party.¹³² War-fighting objects refer to those used in combat, while war-supporting objects are what military operations rely on in some “relatively direct sense”.¹³³ In the cyber context, typical war-supporting objects are factories producing hardware or software or other kinds of information weapons,¹³⁴ all of which qualify as military objectives. Controversy on this element concentrates on the “war-sustaining” object policy of the US, which has been adopted by a few States so far.¹³⁵ The majority of Tallinn Manual independent experts refused to include war-sustaining objects into military objectives due to the remote relationship between them and military operations.¹³⁶\n\n53. The Commander’s Handbook on the Law of Naval Operations of the US extends the expression of Article 52(2) to “effectively contribute to the enemy’s war-fighting or war-sustaining capability”.¹³⁷ The term “war-sustaining” encompasses objects within “an economy or governmental financial system”\n\n¹³¹ Ibid., para.3.\n¹³² Schmitt, above n.125.\n¹³³ Ibid.\n¹³⁴ Tallinn Manual, above n.21, 131, para.16.\n¹³⁵ Schmitt, above n.125, 12.\n¹³⁶ Tallinn Manual, above n.21, 131, para.16.\n¹³⁷ Department of the Navy and Department of Homeland Security and U.S. Coast Guard, The Commander’s Handbook on the Law of Naval Operations, NWP 1-14M/MCWP 5-12.1/COMDTPUB P5800.7A (July 2007), para.8.2.",
    "Chinese JIL (2021)\n\nrelied on by the enemy to fund participation in the conflict.¹³⁸ For instance, the revenue from cotton export during the US Civil War enabled the Confederate States to finance and therefore sustain its war.¹³⁹ Contemporary examples are oil industries of the terrorist groups in the Middle East, such as the Islamic State of Iraq and Al-Shams, whose funding of war relied on revenues from oil exports.¹⁴⁰ The rationale behind the war-sustaining approach in the sense of traditional warfare is that the destruction of certain economic objects that are not absolutely “indispensable to civilian survival”, yet currently protected under LOAC, would shorten a conflict and therefore reduce the potential casualty toll and generate societal changes.¹⁴¹\n\n54. The different effects of cyberattacks and kinetic ones might make cyberattacks against war-sustaining objects more effective in achieving the expected military goal. Using cyber operations to paralyze the infrastructure upon which a central banking system is built, or delete funds from accounts, or change account balances, or manipulate the stock market, will lead to a collapse of the enemy’s confidence. According to the applicable law, many of such cyber operations may not even qualify as attacks under LOAC. Despite the unique advantage of cyberattacks, the military advantage of cyber operations on war-sustaining objects might be indefinite and difficult to articulate.¹⁴² Critiques of war-sustaining objects within the sphere of traditional warfare can apply indiscriminately to cyberspace. There would be no limits to warfare, providing that substantially the entire economy of a country can be considered as war-sustaining.¹⁴³ Consequently, a much broader scope of military objectives that include the enemy’s research and development capabilities would devastate the humanitarian values upheld by the principle of distinction.\n\n55. To sum up, the Chinese scholars’ view that applying some existing rules of LOAC to cyberspace would potentially “open a gate for humanitarian\n\n138 Schmitt, above n.125, 12.\n139 US Naval War College, Annotated Supplement to the Commander’s Handbook on the Law of Naval Operations (1997), 400, n.11.\n140 Schmitt, above n.125, 12.\n141 See Charles J.     "Jiang, Decoding China's Perspectives on Cyber Warfare 289\n\ndisasters” is reasonable, given that attacks against dual-use infrastructure are currently lawful in most cases. Unless there is a breakthrough in law, attacks against major cyber infrastructure would remain subject to the legal safeguards for civilian protection embodied in the principles of proportionality and precaution. As with Rule 80 of the Tallinn Manual, targeting highly dangerous infrastructure, such as dams, dikes, and nuclear electrical generating stations, violates the established rule enshrined in Article 56 of Additional Protocol I, which explicitly prohibits targeting listed infrastructure even if they constitute military objectives.\n\n56. Some may argue that, instead of denying the existing law, a government should assume its responsibility to ensure that military data or weapons do not taint civilian facilities. Unfortunately, the present level of technology and the indiscrepable relationship between civilian and military components in global cyberspace holds little promise for such complete separation.\n\n57. Another alternative proposal pertinent to the Chinese scholars’ argument is to expand the list of “works and installations containing dangerous forces” in Article 56 of Additional Protocol I by analogy so that critical cyber infrastructure could not be made targetable objects.¹⁴⁴ But the hurdle for adequate State support for this effort remains high. It would be difficult to convince States that the potentially nonlethal effects of attacks on cyber infrastructure could be made comparable to that of radioactive materials leak or flood.\n\n58. China has never embraced the “war-sustaining” approach. As demonstrated by the SCO Agreement’s definition of war, China’s perception of threats to the safety and normal functionality of its cyber infrastructure is more oriented towards cyber operations below the threshold of attacks under LOAC. In other words, a lower bar of attacks capable of triggering the application of LOAC is demanded. Meanwhile, the Chinese scholars who expressed concerns over allowing attacks against dual-use and war-sustaining objects under LOAC might want to remove these objects from LOAC’s list of legitimate military objectives. To simultaneously realize the objectives of the SCO members and the mentioned Chinese scholars would require any cyber operations falling under the SCO Agreement’s definition to only attack objects exclusively used for military purposes and dual-use objects that are neither highly dangerous nor counted as cyber infrastructure. Such handling\n\n¹⁴⁴ Robin Geiß &amp; Henning Lahmann, Cyber Warfare: Applying the Principle of Distinction in an Interconnected Space, 45 Israel LR (2012), 390.",
    "Chinese JIL (2021)\n\nmight significantly reduce the legitimate functioning space for cyberattacks and prevent them from doing what they are best at, namely, accomplishing military advantage precisely without causing non-reversible damages of critical civilian infrastructure and having the potential to stay non-violent and reduce collateral losses. Such consequences turn out to be contrary to the humanitarian intentions of these Chinese scholars to reduce the harms suffered by victims of war.\n\n## III.C. Proportionality of cyberattacks against infrastructures\n\n59. Given that the interconnectedness of military networks and their heavy reliance on civilian cyber infrastructure has left the principle of distinction virtually empty of contents, the principle of proportionality becomes an ultimate rule for protecting civilian persons and objects. This principle prohibits attacks “which may be expected to cause incidental loss of civilian life, injury to civilians, damage to civilian objects, or a combination thereof, which would be excessive in relation to the concrete and direct military advantage anticipated”.145 In light of the harsh challenges imposed by the unique features of cyber warfare, the actual role that the principle of proportionality can play could not be overstated.\n\n60. Under LOAC, what can be considered as “excessive” incidental damage to civilian objects in comparison with the expected concrete and direct military advantage remains controversial. The principle of proportionality is “more easily stated than applied in practice”. As a matter of fact, findings of excessive incidental damage to civilian infrastructure are very few and far between as compared to the military advantage.146 Moreover, the proportionality assessment in LOAC is made ex-ante when expected collateral damage is weighed against the anticipated military damage.147 The practical difficulties in ascertaining the expected effects of cyber operations prevent commanders from precisely assessing the potential collateral damages to civilian objects. How to apply this principle in cyberspace hinges on the development of both legal interpretation and technology, the uncertainty of which may jeopardize\n\n145 Additional Protocol I, above n. 100, Art. 51(5)(b).\n\n146 ICTY, Final Report to the Prosecutor by the Committee Established to Review the NATO Bombing Campaign Against the Federal Republic of Yugoslavia (13 June 2000), para.19 (www.icty.org/x/file/Press/nato061300.pdf).\n\n147 Schmitt, above n.125, 19.",
    "Jiang, Decoding China's Perspectives on Cyber Warfare 291\n\nthis principle’s ability to prevent significant collateral damages to civilian objects in cyber warfare.\n\n61. In the digital era, incidental damages to civilian objects will no longer be limited to physical ones but also the loss of functionality of civilian cyber infrastructure. Therefore, in order to accommodate the special needs of cyber warfare, several opinions calling for modifications of the assessment of “collateral damages to civilian objects” have emerged. For example, it is suggested that more weight should be given to temporary consequences regarding cyberattacks, for the temporary incapacity of critical systems would incur more severe consequences than mere inconvenience, such as in situations where loss of life may be caused by the inability of hospitals to communicate vital information.¹⁴⁸ But existing LOAC fails to provide any legal basis for this. The paradoxical applicable law is described as:\n\nwhereas the destruction of a single civilian car would amount to legally relevant, albeit rather insignificant, ‘collateral damage’, the disconnection of thousands or millions of households, companies and public services from the Internet or other communication services, or the severance of online financial transactions for a country’s entire economy and the corresponding economic and societal effects as such would not count as relevant elements to be factored into the proportionality calculus.¹⁴⁹\n\n62. Similarly, some scholars propose to include “knock-on effects” of cyber-attacks in the proportionality calculations when such an effect would not have occurred “but for” the attack.¹⁵⁰ “Knock-on effects” refer to those generated by the initial effects of the attack.¹⁵¹ Both the 1990-1992 Gulf War and the NATO action in the former Yugoslavia illustrate that the knock-on effects of targeting electricity grid may cause more harm to the affected civilians than the direct effect of these attacks themselves.¹⁵² Although existing law has not touched upon this issue, most scholars seem to agree that knock-on effects\n\n¹⁴⁸ Oona Hathaway, et al., The Law of Cyber-Attack, 100 California LR (2012), 851.\n¹⁴⁹ Geiß &amp; Lahmann, above n.144, 397.\n¹⁵⁰ Michael Schmitt, Heather Harrison Dinniss &amp; Thomas C. Wingfield, Computers and War: The Legal Battlespace, Background Paper Prepared for the Informal High-Level Expert Meeting on Current Challenges to International Humanitarian Law (25-27 June 2004), 8-9 (www.hpcresearch.org/sites/default/files/publications/schmittetal.pdf).\n¹⁵¹ Ibid., 8.\n¹⁵² Dinniss, above n.109, 205.",
    "Chinese JIL (2021)\n\nshould be part of the proportionality analysis to the extent they are “reasonably foreseeable”,[153] which resonates with the term “expected” in Additional Protocol I.\n\n63. Commentary to Rule 51 of the Tallinn Manual includes both direct and indirect effects of attacks in the proportionality assessment.[154] The former means “the immediate, first-order consequences, unaltered by intervening events or mechanisms”, and the latter refers to “the delayed and/or displaced second-, third-, and higher-order consequences of action, created through intermediate events or mechanisms”. Without deliberately using the same term, the Tallinn Manual adopts the “knock-on effects” approach, factoring “any indirect effects that should be expected by those individuals planning, approving, or executing a cyberattack” into the proportionality evaluation.[155] Such indirect effects can be exemplified by accidents involving transportation systems or malware inserted into a military computer system spread to other civilian computer systems and thereafter disables them, where those risks are or should have been expected. Such indirect effects may result from blocking the Global Positioning Satellite data or disrupting the Global Positioning System.[156] Inconvenience, irritation, stress, or fear caused by cyber operations are explicitly excluded from collateral damages to civilian objects.[157]\n\n64. The Chinese scholars' view on the theoretical and practical difficulties in applying the present law on proportionality concurs with the mainstream view among international law commentators. The Tallinn Manual's rules and commentaries on this principle are early attempts to codify the prevailing treaty interpretation, contributing to an enhanced relief valve of attacks against critical cyber infrastructure. The Chinese scholars' critiques of Rule 80 of the Tallinn Manual, which permits attacks against highly dangerous infrastructure, were not made in conjunction with Rule 51, becoming an interpretation out of context. The proportionality assessment under existing law disillusions those who wish to use it to make up for the failure of rules regarding the principle of distinction in protecting civilian safety. If the applicable LOAC rules regarding the principles of distinction and proportionality remain unchanged, the principle of precaution would be the only safeguard left.\n\n153 Schmitt, above n.150.\n154 Tallinn Manual, above n.21, 160, para.6.\n155 Ibid.\n156 Ibid.\n157 Ibid., para.5.",
    "Jiang, Decoding China's Perspectives on Cyber Warfare 293\n\n## III.D. Targetable civilians\n\n65. Article 51(3) of the Additional Protocol I¹⁵⁸ and Article 13(3)¹⁵⁹ of the Protocol Additional to the Geneva Conventions of 12 August 1949 and relating to the Protection of Victims of Non-International Armed Conflicts provides that, if civilians engage in conducts amounting to “direct participation in hostilities”, their protection against direct military attacks would be suspended. In cyber warfare, “for such time” as civilians directly participate in hostilities, they not only become legitimate targets of military operations but also are bound by LOAC rules governing the conduct of hostilities. Furthermore, such civilians should not be factored into the proportionality calculation. They are not considered for the principle of precaution that aims to avoid or minimize incidental harm to civilians.¹⁶⁰\n\n66. Civilians may be targeted for direct participation in hostilities. Currently, given the complexity of this issue, there is no authoritative guidance on which activities qualify as direct participation.¹⁶¹ The present State practice, the jurisprudence of international judicial bodies and prevailing academic views adopt a case-by-case determination method through exemplification rather than illustration.¹⁶² To address when civilians may be targeted, the ICRC sponsored a five-year research project in 2003 and produced its *Interpretive Guidance on the Notion of Direct Participation in Hostilities under International Humanitarian Law* (“Interpretive Guidance”).¹⁶³\n\n67. In this document, the ICRC proposes three “constitutive elements” of direct participation in hostilities: (1) an act that negatively impacts the enemy’s military effort, or in which harm is intended (threshold of harm); (2) a relatively direct nexus between that act and the resulting harm, or that act constituting an “integral part” of a coordinated military operation likely to cause the said harm (direct causation), and (3) linkage to the armed conflict\n\n---\n\n158 Additional Protocol I, above n. 100, Art. 51(3).\n\n159 Protocol Additional to the Geneva Conventions of 12 August 1949, and relating to the Protection of Victims of Non-International Armed Conflicts, 1125 UNTS 609 (7 December 1978), Art. 13(3).\n\n160 Melzer, above n.109, 27.\n\n161 Michael Schmitt, Deconstructing Direct Participation in Hostilities: The Constitutive Elements, 42 NYU JILP (2010), 699.\n\n162 Ibid., 705-09.\n\n163 ICRC, Interpretive Guidance on the Notion of Direct Participation in Hostilities under International Humanitarian Law (prepared by Nils Melzer) (May 2009) (www.icrc.org/eng/assets/files/other/icrc-002-0990.pdf).",
    "Chinese JIL (2021)\n\n(belligerent nexus).¹⁶⁴ Although these criteria were generally accepted, the Interpretive Guidance has drawn strong criticism from scholars.¹⁶⁵ These scholars argued that it is both underinclusive as to improperly exclude some forms of direct participation and overinclusive as to incorrectly permit attacks against some civilians and civilian property.¹⁶⁶\n\n68. There is no reason to distinguish cyber operations from kinetic operations regarding how civilian conducts qualify as direct participation in hostilities, as most controversies are not cyber-specific. Critiques of the Interpretive Guidance in conventional warfare do not necessarily stand in cyberspace. According to the “threshold of harm” element, an act amounting to hostility does not have to qualify as an attack within the meaning of LOAC, which indispensably entails the infliction of death, injury, or destruction on military personnel and objects. “Essentially any consequence adversely affecting the military operations or military capacity” of an opposing party would satisfy the test.¹⁶⁷ Compared to the difficulties in arming civilians with traditional weapons, the technical barrier to cyber armed civilians is almost non-existent. It is too easy for civilians to have the know-how to conduct harmful cyber activities.¹⁶⁸ Therefore, in cyber warfare, “the pool of targetable individuals could be extremely large in future conflicts, far more than is the case in classic conflict.”¹⁶⁹\n\n69. Espionage activities, including gathering and disseminating intelligence of military tactics and operations by cyber means, or hacking into the enemy system to identify enemy vulnerabilities, would both suffice. Engaging in developing cyber defence systems, such as encryption technology, firewalls or anti-virus software, also falls under this category. The objectives of China’s normative proposals\n\n76. The narrow construction of the right to self-defence and countermeasures under the Tallinn Rules demonstrates the reluctance of the International Group of Experts to permissibly authorize a State to undertake unilateral acts that would result in effects in the territory of another State, in another word, a strong pro-sovereignty inclination of the Tallinn Rules. In contrast, the US and the UK argued that sovereignty did not by itself constitute a specific rule of international law that cyber operations might violate, but rather a foundational principle of international law that undergirds specific rules of international law, such as the prohibition against the use of force under Article 2(4) of the UN Charter and the rule of non-intervention under customary international law.     "Chinese JIL (2021)\n\nexpress their legal positions to shape the codification process, many States maintained a persistent policy of silence and ambiguity on the specificities of existing or emerging norms regulating cyberspace.²⁰⁹ Meanwhile, the International Group of Experts of the Tallinn Manual 2.0, together with the Dutch Ministry of Foreign Affairs, convened two consultative meetings in April 2015 and February 2016 with representatives from more than one hundred States, including China.²¹⁰\n\n84. The technological difficulties in credibly attributing responsibility for cyber operations, the ongoing controversies over which existing rules apply to cyberspace, their contents, the suitability of the prevailing international legal framework as the primary method to regulate inter-State behaviour in cyberspace, and political and strategic considerations that have prevented States from making public attributions and invoking their rights to take responsive measures, all have contributed to the “wait and see” approach adopted by most States towards utilizing rules and norms of international law, including the Tallinn Rules, to regulate cyber operations.²¹¹ These factors cast doubt over the ripeness of codifying applicable international law in these areas. The limited State practice and opinio juris partly explain China’s “wait and see” stance, which is in line with the mainstream approach in order to preserve a degree of operational flexibility in the face of technological development and the dynamic international environment.²¹²\n\n85. To summarize, China’s long-term insistence on the non-applicability of the right to self-defence and some LOAC rules to cyberspace does not only conform to the development trend of international normative discourses but also contributes to fuelling this momentum. Sovereign control of cyberspace has been increasingly reviving, and the focus of international legal discourse has shifted from the military paradigm concentrated on the jus ad bellum and the jus in bello to the prism of general rules of international law governing State behaviour in peacetime. They are underscored by the elements of cyber sovereignty proposed by China that call for the prohibition of using ICT, information and communications networks to carry out hostile activities or acts of aggression or arms race, and the OEWG resolution's reiteration of the need for introducing additional rules of behaviour regarding States' right to combat interference in their internal affairs through the dissemination of false and distorted news and States' duty to abstain from engaging in such activities. One is external threats posed by more powerful States which may utilize their digital advantages to threaten China's national security and social stability, and the other is external limitations, either from emerging norms of international law or other established powers, of China's exercise of regulatory power over content transmitted in cyberspace to combat such threats.\n\n87. Therefore, in addition to the mentioned concerns addressed by the mainstream State practice, China has employed its generalized and vague resistance to the applicability of some rules of the jus ad bellum and the jus in bello to cyberspace as bargaining leverage to achieve another two objectives in international legal discourse: (1) to build up consensus for a new treaty regulating all use of cyber forces, or a disarmament treaty banning all or at least some types of information weapons, and (2) to block the formation of new law that would limit its domestic regulatory power over cyberspace and prevent disfavoured existing law from binding on its exercise of sovereign power in cyberspace.\n\n## IV.A. A disarmament treaty &amp; national security\n\n88. The first objective of China's opposition to an explicit affirmation of the right to self-defence and the applicability of some LOAC rules to the cyber context, namely, to build up consensus for a disarmament treaty on the use of information weapons under the auspice of the UN, emanates from the nature of States' right to self-defence. It is an inherent right reserved for States to",
    "Chinese JIL (2021)\n\nresort to force by its own decision after the enshrinement of a general prohibition of uses of force in the UN Charter.²¹³\n\n89. As evidenced by the controversies over anticipatory self-defence in the drafting processes of the Tallinn Rules, diverse concepts and practices regarding the preconditions for the commencement of self-defence and the limitations to the exercise of this right have been invoked and contested by States. Whether Article 51 of the UN Charter allows anticipatory or pre-emptive self-defence before an armed attack occurs has long been a major point of contention. The US, the UK, Israel and some other States have construed Article 51 in a permissible manner by referring to the Caroline doctrine under customary international law, based on which they have often resorted to force. The UNSC has condemned some of such practices; the International Court of Justice took the restrictive view in the judgments of the Corfu Channel case,²¹⁴ the Nicaragua case,²¹⁵ and other decisions afterwards.²¹⁶ The restrictive approach limits States' right to self-defence under Article 51 of the UN Charter to situations where an armed attack has already taken place, excluding anticipatory self-defence. From the perspective of the degree of compliance, the effectiveness of the general prohibition of use of force is questionable. But none of these States supporting permissive interpretations dares to bluntly admit the existence of a violation or defy this universally accepted rule, although they always use various factual and legal arguments to justify their breaches.\n\n90. In the same vein, it is not practically feasible to ensure effective observance of a norm prohibiting use of force in cyberspace, especially by these States that are frequent invokers of anticipatory self-defence. Therefore, what China and other SCO members seek is rather to influence the norm-formulation process at the UN that reflects how the international community of States characterizes a situation or act in question, e.g., as a violation of the proposed norm, and whether most States have a willingness to suppress such dubious acts. In the interim, China has not come up with a clear and concrete stance on how to develop a standard resembling Article 2(4) and Article 51 of the UN Charter in judging the legality and legitimacy of State behaviour concerning use of cyber force.     "Jiang, Decoding China's Perspectives on Cyber Warfare 305\n\nwarfare or a disarmament treaty would be more challenging than adapting existing law through interpretation.\n\n91. Cyber disarmament is more unrealistic in today's international political environment than the nonproliferation of nuclear weapons, especially in light of the recent backlashes against the Treaty on the Nonproliferation of Nuclear Weapons provoked by the Iran and North Korea nuclear crises. All nuclear-weapon States except China, which abstained, voted against a UNGA resolution proposing to convene the first UN conference aimed at achieving a legally binding ban on nuclear weapons.²¹⁷ On 22 January 2021, the Treaty on the Prohibition of Nuclear Weapons, the first multilateral agreement that bans nuclear weapons, entered into force. Although 85 States have signed and 50 of them have ratified this treaty, the non-participation of all nine States possessing nuclear weapons renders the efficacy of the treaty questionable.²¹⁸ Additionally, as manifested by Cuba's objection to an endorsement of the right to self-defence in the 2017 UN GGE report, the States that do not enjoy conventional military superiority over their adversaries may have asymmetric advantages in cyberspace, which they are reluctant to give up.²¹⁹ Therefore, a cyber disarmament treaty would lack the support of both major cyber powers and the rest of the weaker cyber-armed States.\n\n92. In the aftermath of the Snowden Disclosures in 2013 and the WikiLeaks disclosures lasting from mid-2016 to date, a rising trend of nationalism has taken place in many countries that used to stand in line with the US-EU camp, such as Brazil and Germany, pushing these countries to start thinking how to defend their \"data sovereignty\". The rise of cybersecurity nationalism has undermined international norm-making efforts, including trade negotiations between the EU and the US and the US attempts to promote norms of Internet freedom globally.²²⁰ There is no reason that cybersecurity discourse would stay intact.\n\n²¹⁷ Tariq Rauf, 2017: The Year in Which Nuclear Weapons Could be Banned?, Stockholm International Peace Research Institute Commentary (20 March 2017) (www.sipri.org/commentary/essay/2017/2017-year-which-nuclear-weapons-could-be-banned).\n\n²¹⁸ See generally, Treaty on the Prohibition of Nuclear Weapons (22 January 2021) (www.nti.org/learn/treaties-and-regimes/treaty-on-the-prohibition-of-nuclear-weapons/).\n\n²¹⁹ Arun M. Sukumar, The UN GGE Failed: Is International Law in Cyberspace Doomed as Well?, Lawfare (4 July 2017) (www.lawfareblog.com/un-gge-failed-international-law-cyberspace-doomed-well).\n\n²²⁰ Mueller, above n.25, 555.",
    "Chinese JIL (2021)\n\n93. Given the unique features of cyber operations and the Internet, even a treaty in the style of the Treaty on the Nonproliferation of Nuclear Weapons would have little practical significance in deterring the abuse and misuse of force in cyberspace. The refrainment of most States, including the US, in most cyber tensions with other States, from resorting to the prevailing international legal framework in dealing with inter-State cyber relations, highlights the limitations of normative approaches in functioning as a general taboo for irresponsible activities in cyberspace by not only State but also private actors.\n\n94. Compared to conventional and nuclear weapons, the technical barriers to entry in cyber warfare are so low that non-State actors and countries that are conceivably weak by the standards of hard powers can play a significant role on par with powerful countries at low levels of cost. Cyberattacks can be conducted by any actor having an electronic device and connected to the Internet. The interconnectivity of the network enables any actor to stay geographically remote from where they commit cyberattacks. Simultaneously, unlike classic military operations that rely upon territorial linkages, this interconnectivity severely decreases the degree of State control over actors and activities. The life of a treaty, particularly a disarmament treaty, rests in its enforcement. The construction of a credible monitoring and enforcement mechanism would prove to be the utmost hurdle for a cyber disarmament treaty.\n\n95. Probably having realized the lack of feasibility and political will among States to negotiate a cyber disarmament treaty, China has softened, to some degree, its stance against the alleged militarization of cyberspace. In the most up-to-date white paper on China's military strategy issued in 2015, China plans to \"expedite the development of a cyber force, and enhance its capabilities of cyberspace situation awareness, cyber defence [...] so as to stem major cyber crises, ensure national network and information security, and maintain national security and social stability\".[221] The ISCC further confirms that \"enhanced defence capability in cyberspace is an important part of China's endeavour to modernize its national defence and armed forces\",[222] while restricting China's development of a cyber force to defensive capability.[223]\n\n221 State Council Information Office, China's Military Strategy (May 2015), Chapter IV: Building and Development of China's Armed Forces (www.chinadaily.com.cn/china/2015-05/26/content_20820628_4.htm).\n\n222 ISCC, above n.17, Chapter III: Strategic Goals.\n\n223 Ibid., Chapter I: Opportunities and Challenges &amp; Chapter III: Strategic Goals.",
    "Jiang, Decoding China's Perspectives on Cyber Warfare 307\n\n## IV.B. Sovereign control over the Internet vs non-intervention\n\n96. The changes in the global context of disarmament and China's position regarding use of force in the cyber context have rendered the proposed second objective of China more salient. The central bone of contention in the normative competitions between the SCO members and the Western powers rests upon whether information and data transmitted in cyberspace shall be made subject to the jurisdiction of the territorial State, although both sides have reached a consensus on the applicability of sovereignty as part of international law in cyberspace. At the core of this debate is how to draw the lines between the realms of domestic law and international law as consensual erosion of State sovereignty to be applied equally to all States.\n\n97. The US holds the view that, although sovereignty gives a State the right to control over cyber infrastructure and activities within its territory, the exercise of such jurisdiction by the territorial State, encompassing the use and access to the Internet, must comply with that State's obligations under applicable international law, particularly international human rights law. While noting that the freedom of expression may be restricted in situations such as the incitement of imminent terrorist violence, the US considers \"certain censorship and content control, including blocking websites simply because they contain content that criticizes a leader, a government policy, or an ideology, or because the content espouses particular religious beliefs\" as constituting State violations of international human rights law.²²⁴\n\n98. China likely views this reference to international human rights law as a pretext for Western attempts to conceptually undermine the scope of sovereign powers by narrowing the content of *domaine réservé* in the context of Internet governance. China claims for cyber sovereignty that includes not only cyber infrastructure within its territory but also its jurisdiction over data and the regulation and monitoring of the content of information flowing over cyberspace.²²⁵ Consciously aware that the scope of a State's internal matters and the international legal limitations to that State's exercise of sovereign power over internal matters evolve over time, China has consistently resisted non-reciprocal and non-voluntary restrictions on its exercise of sovereignty.\n\n²²⁴ Egan, above n.45, 15-17.\n\n²²⁵ See, e.g., National Security Law of the People's Republic of China (2015), art. 25; XI Jinping, Keynote Speech at the opening ceremony of the 2nd World Internet Conference (16 December 2015) (www.wuzhenwic.org/2015-12/16/c_47521.htm).",
    "Chinese JIL (2021)\n\n99. From Beijing's perspective, the nature of the Tallinn Manual 2.0 as a product formulated under the domination of Western powers was not changed solely by the increased diversity in the composition of the International Group of Experts participating in the drafting process, because the newly-added matters reflect foremostly Western perspectives and concerns. The Tallinn Manual 2.0 does not touch upon the sovereignty of a State over potential data; it only mentions sovereign power over any cyber infrastructure located within States' territory and activities associated with that cyber infrastructure. Similar problems exist in the Tallinn Rules concerning jurisdiction, which overwhelmingly emphasize the limitations imposed by international human rights law to the exercise of sovereignty in cyberspace.²²⁶\n\n100. In the domestic sphere, China invokes cyber sovereignty to underpin its regulation over data and information in cyberspace. As shown in the SCO Agreement's wording of \"mass psychologic brainwashing to destabilize society and State, as well as to force the State to take decisions to the interest of an opposing party\", China is always wary of potential foreign interference. The propaganda and liaison roles played by online social networking servers, such as Facebook and Twitter, in the \"Arab Spring\" that led to social unrest, political turmoil and regime-changes in Northern African and Western Asian countries, and the exposure of the massive surveillance by the US National Security Agency in the PRISM program have strengthened the Chinese conviction of the need for Internet censorship to block and filter information in cyberspace that is harmful to China's social stability and national security.²²⁷ In the trend of the global revival of cyber sovereignty, China strengthens its sovereignty-based regulatory power by referring to similar censorship practices of other States, such as the US, Australia, Italy, Germany, France, the UK, and Korea that once held opposing views, regarding the information about terrorism, incitement to hate crimes, pornography, violence and other crimes involving the usage of the Internet.²²⁸\n\n101. In the international sphere, China has employed cyber sovereignty as a shield against some Western States' attempts to compel it to change the\n\n²²⁶ HUANG, above n.212.\n\n²²⁷ HUANG Zhixiong, Regulation of Cyber Information: A Component Implicitly Covered by Cyber Sovereignty, 3 Guojia Zhili [Nat'l Governance Wkly] (2016), 33-34.\n\n²²⁸ Xinlian, From the US to Australia: How States Regulate the Internet, China Daily (17 May 2016) (http://world.chinadaily.com.cn/2016-05/17/content_25321844.htm).",
    "Jiang, Decoding China's Perspectives on Cyber Warfare 309\n\ncurrent model of Internet governance by either resorting to non-legal advocacy for Internet freedom or invoking relevant international law, especially the rules of international human rights law on the right to freedom of expression, association, and the media, and the right to access to information. Google's withdrawal from the Chinese market in 2010 was a representative example of the former means where a leading multinational company threatened the Chinese government for a policy change under the instructions of some Western countries.²²⁹ Additionally, the Chinese government has been alarmed by soft law norms applicable in peacetime that are proposed by some Western countries, such as relevant code of conduct on responsible State behaviour in cyberspace at the 2016-2017 UN GGE meetings. Such non-binding norms are intended to circumvent the advocacy of Russia and China to formulate new rules to regulate State behaviour regarding cybersecurity in the form of a treaty at the forum of the UN and may gradually harden into binding law.²³⁰\n\n102. This argument likely explains why Cuba, Russia and China refused to explicitly affirm the right to self-defence and the applicability of international humanitarian law in the cyber context in the 2017 UN GGE report, while having accepted the general applicability of existing *jus ad bellum* and *jus in bello* to cyberspace since the publication of the 2015 UN GGE consensus report. The crucial factor that prevented these States from reaching a consensus with the Western countries was the opposing camp's intention to introduce \"clear and direct statements on how international law applies to States' use of ICTs\"²³¹ in the UN GGE report, which threatened to restrict States' right to regulate the content of and access to information. The UN GGE report is a non-binding statement, but it may serve as proof of State practice and *opinio juris* in ascertaining whether certain international law applies to a participating State signing onto the consensus report and the extent to which the included law limits the endorsing State's right to regulate domestic affairs. Although these countries have recognized the applicability of LOAC to cyber operations during an armed conflict upon the adoption of the final UN GGE report, residual disagreements over how specific LOAC rules apply to ICT-related activities remain prominent between them and the Western countries.\n\n²²⁹ HUANG, above n.227, 34.\n²³⁰ HUANG Zhixiong, Norms of Responsible State Behavior in Cyberspace: Origin, Impact and Response, 1 Dangdai Faxue [Contemporary LR] (2019), 68-69.\n²³¹ Korzak, above n.70.",
    "Chinese JIL (2021)\n\n103. The law governing the right to self-defence and means and methods of warfare is dominated by the practice of remarkably few established powers because the major ground of resorting to anticipatory self-defence and a large portion of LOAC is customary international law, which has been developed by these “specially affected” States to advance their interests.²³² For newly rising powers such as China, failing to meet the requirements of “persistent objector” before and after the birth of a rule at concern would not relieve their obligation to comply. A successful example where a contrary practice of a large number of weaker States makes a few powerful States switch from an established rule of customary international law to an emerging new rule is rare.²³³ It is extremely difficult for a militarily disadvantaged State that lacks field experience to replicate such a strategy in areas involving force.\n\n104. To prevent coercive erosions of its sovereignty, China’s strategy is to embed a firewall at the most representative and democratic lawmaking forum to obstruct the convenient transplantation of power disparity from the *jus ad bellum* and the *jus in bello* to the special regimes of international law that constitute cornerstones of an evolving global system of Internet governance. A treaty negotiated at a more egalitarian forum such as the UNGA would enable the Chinese perspectives to carry greater weight in forming international law among a large number of similarly disadvantaged countries. And lawmaking in the form of treaty allows a less advanced State such as China to pick and choose elastically from treaties and their provisions according to its goals.\n\nV. Conclusion\n\n105. To summarize, the above analyses suggest that behind China’s general and vague opposition to an explicit affirmation of the applicability of specific LOAC rules to cyberspace and the right of self-defence in cyberspace is China’s profound concern that doing so would acquiesce to the encroachment of its sovereignty and unlock Pandora’s box of coercive external interferences with its independence in determining the mode of domestic Internet governance and the path of development.\n\n106. Has China’s growing strength in Internet technology, military capabilities and digital economy driven it to pursue a more proactive and enterprising approach to reshaping international law governing the domain of cyber\n\n²³² Alan Boyle &amp; Christine Chinkin, The Making of International Law (2007), 28-29.\n²³³ Ibid., 29.",
    "Jiang, Decoding China's Perspectives on Cyber Warfare 311\n\nwarfare so as to build up a competitive advantage against the established powers? At first glance, Beijing's long-term resistance to confirming the applicability of existing *jus ad bellum* and *jus in bello* to cyberspace before the adoption of the final UN GGE report, amid the exaggerated normative rivalry between the Russia-China Camp and the US-EU Camp, appeared to corroborate this argument. However, closer scrutiny reveals that, the conceptual generalization and ambiguity in China's resisting stance stems from the same premises underpinning the mainstream \"wait and see\" approach of most States towards utilizing international law as the primary means to regulate or justify their cyberoperations. Following the \"wait and see\" trend of State practice, China has agreed to the general applicability of the *jus ad bellum*, the *jus in bello*, and law on State responsibility for international wrongful acts, but still resists the applicability of some specific rules in cyberspace, e.g., the right to self-defence and some LOAC rules, to allow for flexibility in responding to cyber technology development in attribution and the evolvement of international law.\n\n107. Despite the recent developments in its cyber defensive capacity, China remains disadvantaged as a rising power with weaker military capacity and less normative influence. China's normative proposals, exemplified by the ICCIS, serves more as bargaining leverage to protect itself from being bound by the existing or emerging law supported by the established powers, but unfavourable to itself, and also to move the focus of international legal discourse from the paradigm of military responses to cyberattacks concentrated in the *jus ad bellum* and the *jus in bello* to that of international law governing State behaviour in peacetime. China's normative efforts are largely defensive, given that Beijing chooses to prioritize its interests in defending against possible use of force either triggered by an alleged cyberattack or carried out in the means of cyber operations, over its offensive interests in staying less constrained in the use of cyber force.\n\n108. Because of the special features of how existing *jus ad bellum* and *jus in bello* were made, the normative influence of China and its SCO allies is not sufficient, at this moment, to change the practice of the frequent users of force, to come up with a norm promising effective observance by these States, or to veto the formation of new law proposed by these States at concern. The return of sovereign control in cyberspace and the focus shift of international legal discourse result from a set of factors, e.g., the limitations of current technologies and existing law, with the normative efforts of the SCO members having contributed to this global trend.",
    "Chinese JIL (2021)\n\n109. But these countries can still resist the imposition of non-consensual norms upon themselves in the domain of cyberspace, obstruct the codification of disfavoured norms, and influence how other States characterize and respond to a situation involving cyber operations. This is why the seemingly unfeasible idea of an international cyber disarmament treaty concluded under the framework of the UN remains on the table. The UNSC's monopoly of authorizing the use of force and the UNGA's feature as one of the most egalitarian forums for international lawmaking make the UN the favourable forum relied on by rising powers such as China to build resilience against other lawmaking processes where established powers play a greater role, e.g., the development of customary international law or soft law in less representative forums."

    "abstract": "This article examines China’s concerns over the adequacy of existing jus ad bellum and jus in bello to address cyber warfare, particularly the rules on cyberattacks governed by the jus in bello, dual-use infrastructure and war-sustaining facilities, the proportionality of cyberattacks against key infrastructures and the targetability of certain categories of civilians. This article argues that China’s resistance to applying some rules of the jus in bello to cyberspace is in line with the “wait and see” approach of most States. But there are two distinctive objectives behind this generalized stance: one is to protect its domestic regulatory power over cyberspace from being bound by disfavoured emerging and existing law, and the other is to build up consensus for a treaty regulating uses of cyber force under the United Nations framework.",
